profile.name: Bart Blommaerts
profile.bio:
Bart Blommaerts is a passionate Software Architect at Ordina, who believes closing the model-code gap is essential to make rapid, agile delivery sustainable. Bart has a strong focus on API design, reuse, automation and security. He is always looking for technical challenges. Bart also is the chairman of the different JWorks Competence Leads at Ordina.

Before Ordina, Bart led the EMEA Java Community at HP and was chairman of the HP Java Governance Board in the Benelux.

talk.title: 10 tips to become an awesome Technical Lead
talk.description:
As you grow in your career, chances are that one day you will end up as the Technical Lead of 1 or more projects. Often not by choice. The role of Technical Lead is quite different from the role of (senior) Software Developer and this talk will bring you answers on questions like:

* How do I do technical interviews?
* How do I lead a team? How do I lead multiple teams?
* How do I cope with my new responsibilities?
* How do I cope with success / failure?
* How do I prevent losing focus on the technical challenges?
* ...

In summary, everything you want(ed) to know on your first day as a Technical Lead and that you can use every day from that point onwards.
talk.notes:
I've been a Technical Lead for over 10 years .. a role I never requested. I worked with small teams (2 people) and with larger teams (20+ people) as a Technical Lead. And a couple of times, I needed to do some firefighting on other projects, because of the missing experience of the Technical Lead (eg. when leading a team of offshore developers).

I started a Technical Lead training program when I was back at HP to overcome issues senior developers are likely to face when becoming a Technical Lead (eg. how to do technical interviews .. Which questions are useful? Should you focus on the resume? etc. ).

I would like to share my personal experience on this topic, because I believe a good Technical Lead is a key role within most (/ all) development teams.
talk.abstract: Everything you want(ed) to know on your first day as a Technical Lead and that you can use every day from that point onwards.

ratings.comments: I don't see the tie to Software Architecture.  If he was a Software Architecture tech lead, then I could see the relevant tie.
I would very much like to see this 15-minute talk narrowed to fewer questions, all in a single area -- any of technical reviews, dealing with people, planning, etc.
Find the topic relevant, its experienced based, but hard to see how it relate to architecture and what are the takeaway from attending the talk. I have also some doubts about 15 minutes length.
These are all interesting topics for architects as leaders but also interesting to glean from books and available leadership literature.

The topic sounds interesting and pragmatic.

However it is not clear on how the topic is related to one of the topic themes for this year's conference. 

https://www.sei.cmu.edu/saturn/2017/call.cfm

In case the author could justify and provide more clarity I would think of considering it for a short time slot.

feedback.body:
Bart-

Thanks for your submission!

Your proposal sounds interesting, but I'm concerned about squeezing 10 tips into 15 minutes. Have you given this talk before?
I'm also concerned that this topic comes up a lot in blogs and other forums - how is your talk going to be different?

Thank you.

Hi John,

Thank you for considering my proposal.

It is a brand-new talk. I will present it, for the first time, in Riga, in a 50 mins slot.
I have experience with "slicing" talks into different time frames. For a 15 mins slot, I'd focus on the key takeaways and invite those interested to discuss the 10 tips in detail after the talk. Should you prefer it, I can also do 5 tips in more detail during the slot.

My talk will be different, because all the tips will come from personal experience. I've been a technical lead for different projects (in size, budget, team composition, location, ...)  for the past 10 years and I want to share my personal "lessons learned". 

Kind regards,
Bart Blommaerts

Thanks for the proposal. The topic sounds interesting and pragmatic.

From the guidelines for the conference could you please elaborate on how the topic is related to one of the topic themes for this year's conference. Link given at the end for your reference.

One of the themes talk about “how to ensure that architecture work gets done in environments without formal architect roles”. Is the talk about role of the Team Lead in an environment with or without a formal Architect? Also, what is not fully clear is whether the talk is about some of the management related activities a technical lead need to do or much on the technical side with or without an Architect.

Similarly, there is a theme that talks about “developing software architects, including coaching, mentoring, certification, professional training, and college education”. Is that the area the topic is going top focus.

Would it make sense to split the talk on roles and responsibilities of the technical lead without the interviewing aspects, as that would allow better focus for the limited time. I am also concerned about the 15-minute time window.

https://www.sei.cmu.edu/saturn/2017/call.cfm

Hello Yogeshwar,

Thank you for your feedback. Those are really good and useful questions!

When first submitting this talk, I intended to make two versions: a high-level version, suitable for a 15 mins slot and a more in-depth version, suitable for a 50 mins slot. For Saturn, I wanted to do the high-level version and invite the attendees to discuss the different tips in detail after the talk.

However, I like your idea of splitting the talk in two talks: 
- Focus on the roles and responsibilities of the technical lead (related on "build"): eg. architecture without having a formal architect role + governance over this architecture. This is (coincidentally) exactly what I'm doing in a current Microservices project for the biggest telecom operator in Belgium (IoT project in the smart automotive area). 
- Focus on the management aspect of a technical lead: eg. the interviewing process, facilitating estimations, etc.

I can do both talks, if you would like me to. I will likely split my "in-depth" version in these two topics as well. So thanks again for your feedback.

Most content of the talk(s) will come from personal experience and I intend to give a lot of anecdotes, personal stories and of course the "lessons learned" from these.

Kind regards,
Bart Blommaerts
Thanks for the details! All the Best!

I find it relevant and interesting but is concerned with 15 minutes. I would have liked to see the five core takeaways, and how does this role relate to the architecture of the actual system?

//Einar

Hello Einar,

Thank you for considering my proposal. It appears that PaperCall does not share the questions and comments from reviewers, because I received very similar comments from Yogeshwar Srikrishnan and John Klein. But that really shows the question is spot-on :)

My initial goal was to give 10 high-level tips and then invite the interested attendees to discuss more in-depth after the talk. But after the feedback from you and your colleagues, I proposed to split the talk in two talks:

1. Focus on the roles and responsibilities of the technical lead (related to “build”): eg. architecture without having a formal architect role + governance over this architecture. This is (coincidentally) exactly what I’m doing in a current Microservices project for the biggest telecom operator in Belgium (IoT project in the smart automotive area). 

2. Focus on the management aspect of a technical lead: eg. the interviewing process, facilitating estimations, etc.

I can do both talks, or the one you and your colleagues esteem best suited.


I'd like to thank you for your feedback, because I believe its really valuable. I do hope the different reviewers share their comments and my responses to them. It would be a shame if the responses got lost, due to the way PaperCall shares them.


Kind regards,
Bart Blommaerts

Thank you for the submission. It's great to share your experience and expertise in leading architecture-related projects. This submission can fit into topics dealing with the process of architecting in either track 1 or 3.

I share the concerns of some of the other reviewers (whose comments I am able to read in PaperCall, by the way) about content versus time. I like the questions you pose in the abstract, but it may be difficult to give them all enough attention in 15 minutes for audience members to get enough information to really absorb and later apply the answers. I like the idea of splitting the talk. 

If you stick with the short, 15-minute TED-style talk, please consider focusing on fewer questions in one particular area -- any of technical reviews, dealing with people, planning, etc. Alternatively, consider expanding the  presentation to a 30-minute experience report. I realize that you have plans for two versions, and were targeting the shorter version for SATURN.

Hi Anthony,

What would Saturn prefer?

a) 30 mins talk on "10 tips"
b) 15 mins talk on 5 "technical" tips
c) 15 mins talk on 5 "management" tips

I can do 2 talks (b and c) if Saturn would like me to. All content will be influenced a lot by my personal experiences. I never had the opportunity to attend Saturn, so it's difficult to determine the best match with the above choices. I'll happily write two abstracts (b and c) if needed.

Regards,
Bart Blommaerts

Hi Bart,

I'd expect either (b) or (c) to work out best. Other reviewers, please add your thoughts.

You have more information too, so if you find you have more time during the talk, you can always add a bonus tip or two. No one will complain if you advertise five tips and deliver six or seven!.

I'm hoping to hear what experience or problem led to each situation and what resulting tip resolves the problem. I want to hear more than just a flat list of tips. I want to hear your great stories behind them.

Hey Anthony,

Spot on. The number is actually not 10 tips .. but that's the first tip :)


Bart

Hi Bart,

This talk sounds interesting but appears to be aimed at new technical leads rather than architects.

As an experienced architect what do you think that you would take away from this presentation?

In your description you hint at an interesting architectural perspective regarding the importance of the role, such as the firefighting required due to the lack of good technical leads.

Is it possible to re-frame the talk to aim it more specifically at the architect?  For example, what roles do you think the architect plays in the development of good technical leads?  Do you believe that developing technical leads is an essential step towards developing good architects?#

Regards, 


Ged

profile.name: Jim van der Waal
profile.bio: I'm an IT Project Manager at bol.com, the biggest e-commerce company within The Netherlands and Belgium. With my creativity and passion I try to develop a drive in the company that will make things happen.

talk.title: Abuser stories: how we embedded a security culture within our business.
talk.description:
With bol.com we experienced the flight ecommerce took the last decade. As the biggest ecommerce company of the Netherlands and Belgium security risks grew exponentially. But it’s not scalable to let your security team grow with the same rate. That’s why we also focused on creating a security culture within the company: making security a responsibility of everyone, not only the security team.

To not only create this culture in IT but also in the rest of the company, we organized Abuser Story workshops for Product Owners and Business Analysts. Abuser stories are a fun way of thinking about the security of your new features. It triggers to think of unhappy flows, think of thresholds to monitor and so on. Making the systems Secure by Design, something really relevant for architects. We saw that Product Owners consulted the security team and architects way more for advice when designing new systems, they gave room and time to developers to write secure code, and discussions between the Security and development teams were actually constructive. It helped to get the “security, we are in this together” mindset. 

In this talk Jim will tell the journey of bol.com, the growing importance of security, and the way we tried to cope with it in a fun way. The lessons learned are valuable for every (growing) company that struggles with making security scalable, and assuring that you will not only be secure today or tomorrow but also in 5-10 years.
talk.notes: Creating awareness in (IT) companies regarding security is becoming really important, and we saw that this awareness should extend way beyond IT. This is really necessary if you want to work agile, and I experienced that first hand. That is why I came up with this concept to extend the security culture to the business as well. Since it is more or less something I came up with myself I am very enthusiastic and passionate to talk about it. Especially since I experience the succes from it every day now in my projects.
talk.abstract: How do you cope with the growth of security risks? Creating a security culture in your company becomes more important every day. Providing your IT teams with the right tools is one thing, but new features start way before it reaches the development phase. So how do you create such a culture?

ratings.comments:
This is a talk that I would like to see.  It cover three topics that I find interesting that are identified within the submission guidelines.

It promises to provide a successful case study on helping to assure quality from a security perspective.

More importantly, it focuses on creating a culture of security awareness within agile teams.  That is not easy to achieve, and I would be interested in finding out how it has been done.

Personally I would like to see a longer session with practical elements such as role playing an workshop.

Given that security is an after thought in most development organizations, this topic can possibly bring to light how to truly make everybody think about security.  Also, since security is quickly becoming on of the "ility" requirements, applicable to SATURN.

I like it, I'm also an advocate for addressing safety and security requirements early. Safety and security can't be something we try to fix afterwords. That said, I found it hard to see how this fits with the architectural thinking of a system.
I like this workshop but I don't see a clear connection to architecture design in the abstract.  As a requirements elicitation method it seems quite interesting.

The talk is about disseminating a security culture across the organization and eliciting security requirements for applications (as "abuser stories"). Apparently, it does not get to discuss security as a quality attribute and design driver or tactics and approaches to achieve security.

feedback.body:
Hi Jim,

Thanks for your submission!  I'm a huge fan of misuse cases and simple threat modelling for specifying security requirements.  This is a great topic but I could use some additional information to understand the scope of the proposed talk.

It sounds like the focus of this talk will be on requirements elicitation using the abuser story workshop?  Could you share some details about what that workshop looks like?  A tentative outline for your talk would be extremely helpful.

How is this workshop different from other security requirement  elicitation methods?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Micheal,

Nice to hear from you. I will try to answer your questions below and give some additional information.

About what I will tell about how we embedded a security culture in the company:
So how do you already get that security mindset embedded in earlier stages. How do you get people excited to think about security? Security has the prejudice that it is boring, that is something you have to do, maybe because someone else says so. Like the security team/department. But security can also be fun! Fun? Yes! By stimulating the employees to think like a hacker, either technical or functional, they got motivated to think of security requirements by approaching it from the other side. This in combination with the right tools really helped to get our security level to high standards.

Some more information about the Abuser Story Workshop:
With abuser stories we touch on a subject everybody worked with: user stories. Normally with user stories you define new functionality that you develop with the customer in mind. But how can this functionality be abused? We stimulate the colleagues creativity to think evil and create a hacker mindset for themselves. Turn it around: write an Abuser story: As a hacker, I want…, So that… We were surprised by the evilness of our colleagues – we had some real hackers among us. We do this by introducing a simple proces, let one team think about abuser stories (so how could you as a hacker abuse this functionality), and the other team about user stories on how to avoid abuse. After that the 'Attacking' team presents its abuser stories, which the other team needs to 'Defend' with one of their user stories. We then stimulate the Product Owners to braintorm about abuser stories at the kickoff of each new functionality, more or less facilitate their own workshop. The outcome is then translated in requirements for the different user stories.


There are actually two ways of how you can approach this talk. 

1. A (comprehensive) talk about the journey of bol.com and how we embedded a security culture, where I will deep dive more in how we did this with the use of Abuser Story Workshops. This focusses more on how we created this security culture, and the lessons we learned from this proces.

2. A short talk about the journey of bol.com and how we embedded a security culture, and facilitating a Abuser Story Workshop to illustrate how we did this. This focusses more on teaching you how you could facilitate these workshops yourself. 


Relevance for audience: the first is relevant for a broader audience, where the second talk (workshop form) is more relevant for Analysts and Product Owners.

I hope this gives you more insights. If you have any questions or you want me to elaborate a bit more, just let me know.

Regards,

Jim
Thanks, Jim.  Your responses are helpful.

Hi Einar,

Thanks! The safety case method is new to me. Within our company we have very little formal methods and formal documentation, so it is not a surprise that I did not come across it before.

Jim

talk.title: Accessibility Testing Tools for Developers
talk.description:
You don't have to be an accessibility expert to make your projects accessible, but you do have to make your projects accessible. 

Identifying accessibility issues as early as possible can save an organization or project a substantial amount of money, time, and headaches over trying to augment a web site or application after initial development. Using a testing tools during development for accessibility will definitely help with this process. 

For developers that are novice to web accessibility this presentation is a great introduction into key aspects to consider while developing. For developers that are more familiar, this presentation exposes tools that will make accessibility easier. All users will gain from learning how to build accessibility into their development workflow using a variety of testing tools, from simple to intricate.
talk.notes: This is generally a 60 minute presentation that can easily be expanded to fill 90 minutes.
talk.abstract: You don't have to be an accessibility expert to make your projects accessible, but you do have to make your projects accessible. This presentation can serve as an introduction to web accessibility by exposing what to look for, via a variety of tools, to help developers make projects inclusive to all
talk.talk_format: Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes - please specify the exact time in the Notes section)

ratings.comments: I don't see the tie to software architecture.

I find this topic relevant. There is a question if it should be done as an introduction, aimed at architects or more as a in depth workshop aimed at coders. 

What are the you guys thinking?
Topic is relevant and important. Details for a 90 minute slot are sparse.

feedback.body:
Hi Einar, thank you for your consideration. Perhaps an intro to web accessibility would be better suited, if you feel it is a unknown subject to the audience? If not, I can gladly add a few lines to describe the purpose and benefits.

Regarding the duration, 90 minutes would allow me more time to go through the code demonstration at then end, the gran finale, which is usually rushed due to questions/ conversations throughout the presentation.

Please let me know if you need additional information. Again, thank you for your consideration.

Thank you Gerard. It might be the case that a introduction is better. There are more software architects than programmers here. But lets see what the other PC members think. In its current form, I think a 90 minute workshop is better than a 60 minutes. In introduction to the topic I guess is better done in 30 minutes.

Einar, since there are more architects than programmers then maybe this isn't the right forum for my presentation? My presentations on web accessibility are for front-end engineers using HTML, CSS, and JS that impact end-users. Software architect are a little too high level for this information. Thoughts?

Hi Gerard,

As an architect I'm curious, because I believe that accessibility is such an important quality attribute.  However, I'm not so interested in the implementation details.

I would love to see a talk provide an good, practical overview of the topic for the architect.  This is an area of debate for architects, so I think it is a very relevant field for discussion.

For example, in the first addition of "Software Architecture in Practice" the statement was made: "Making a system's user interface clear and easy to use is primarily a matter of getting the details of a user's interaction correct … but these details are not architectural."

In later editions this position was retracted with a section called "Usability Mea Culpa (or that’s not Architecture)" but other architects still disagree.  Consider this blog post that insists that usability is important, but still not architecture: http://enterprise-it-architecture.blogspot.co.uk/2013/04/usability-is-not-architecture-quality.html

As somebody with a passion for and experience of achieving accessibility, could you explain to architects why this is an important quality attribute and the role that architects play in improving it?

If you could include some well defined quality scenarios [1] and relevant architectural tactics [2] that would be very desirable.  The testing approach would be covered by the tactics and you might want to focus on this in particular.

I appreciate that this would be quite a deviation from your current proposal.  You may think of something closer to what you already have that will help to convince architects that this is something they need to be interested in.

[1] http://www.informit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=1959673&seqNum=4
[2] http://www.informit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=1959673&seqNum=5

profile.name: Pradyumn Sharma
profile.bio:
32 years of experience in IT industry. Been a programmer, designer, architect, project manager, DBA, tester, business analyst, and now mostly trainer, coach and consultant. I have worked on the architecture, design and implementation of many applications, in various domains including banking, insurance, retail, logistics, process control. talk.title: Agile Architecture and Design
talk.description:
Agile software development methodologies are mainstream now. But one of the nagging questions teams face is: how to establish the architecture for a system the agile way? After all, architectural decisions have a key impact on various qualities of a system, and therefore, these decisions have to be taken early and carefully. How does this fit with the incremental and iterative nature of agile methodologies? 

In this session, I'll cover the following aspects: 

* Creating an architecture vision, including desired architectural qualities, during Sprint Zero 
* Identifying potential strategies for achieving the desired architectural qualities, without creating an ivory tower architecture
* Prioritizing the architectural qualities and adding them to the Product Backlog along with the functional requirements 
* Implementing and verifying architectural qualities with the help of real stories from the Product Backlog.   

I will take concrete examples from projects on how to apply the above concepts.
talk.notes:
I have been in the IT industry for 32 years. Been a programmer, designer, architect, project manager, DBA, tester, business analyst, and now mostly trainer, coach and consultant. I have worked on the architecture, design and implementation of many applications, in various domains including banking, insurance, retail, logistics, process control. 

I regularly conduct training programs in the fields of Agile with Scrum, Agile Engineering Practices (XP), Solution Architecture, Enterprise Architecture, and Writing Good Programs.

I have presented various sessions relating to Agile Architecture in many SATURN conferences, as well as Scrum Gatherings, Agile Conferences.
talk.abstract: How to establish the architecture for a system in an agile way? How to avoid BDUF, and yet meet the architecture requirements and mitigate the risks aggressively? Concrete examples from projects to understand the concepts as well as practical insight.

ratings.comments:
This submission is an experience report on providing some guidelines for establishing an architecture in an agile way. The author correctly identifies that despite the acceptance of agile methodologies and recognition of the importance of architecture a lot of teams struggle marrying them both.

While I appreciate the motivation, I lack the actual experience piece of this talk. The points that the author lists are those that can be found in any blog post or article. The SATURN audience would like to see how these actual experience that work in practice. Unfortunately, this point is only made in passing as "I will take concrete examples from projects on how to apply the above concepts." What are the nature of the concrete examples and what lessons can be taken from them are missing for me to be able to judge this experience piece of this talk objectively.

This talk addresses a key question in the "Digital, Virtual Software Architect": How can we be effective in fast-moving agile environments?

I'm particularly interested in learning about the experiences behind Sprint Zero activities and how the managing of quality attributes on the backlog.
I think talks about architecture and agile should always be welcome.  Especially those that have come from experience.

I’ve attended talks by the speaker and he is well versed in architecture principles. I would categorize those talks as more basic than intermediate. It is possible that the presentation has evolved though there is not enough description to know for sure. The SATURN audience may want something with a little more substance.

Agile and architecture has been discussed often and there are many talks on it at SATURN and elsewhere.  There's really nothing that new proposed in the talk.  But it's always good to see experience reports that show how these practices are used in practice.
Sounds as a relevant, well structured talk by a experienced speaker.
Looks like just the sort of session that can help us build a bridge between developers who are familiar with agile development and the software architecture practices.

feedback.body: Thank you for an interesting submission. I think this topic sounds very interesting.

Hi Pradyumn,

Thanks for your submission.  On the one hand this looks like the same things we've seen for a while with agile architecture discussions.  On the other hand, this looks like an experience report with clear lessons and a tight focus on a topic many people care about.

I'm intrigued by the idea of design without a _paper architecture_.  What do you mean by this?  Why wouldn't a paper architecture be a desirable thing?    Paper prototyping is a wonderful technique for exploring design options quickly and cheaply.

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael,
Thanks for your feedback. Silly me! I meant to say "ivory tower" architecture. I am embarrassed.
Let me see if I can correct the submission now.
Pradyumn

profile.name: Babu Samuel
profile.bio: I have been working in IT for about 20 years. For the past 7 years, I am working as an architect and a technical lead in SIEMENS healthineers at Princeton, New Jersey.

talk.title: Agile With Architecture
talk.description:
Over the past few years, there is a question central to many discussions surrounding agile approaches to architecting software: In agile process, is the architecture of the system designed up-front, or does it emerge over time as the result of the agile software development process? Also there is an importance of supporting evolution and change to a software-intensive system, and the practical implications of creating a change-ready system. The ability to adapt these changes is driven by two factors, Architecture and Agile Practices. This presentation shows some of the techniques an architect can use to be effective in the fast moving agile environments.
1.	A hybrid form combining both explicit and emergent architectural techniques. This approach explains
	      (i) How alignment is the part of architectural work where an architect makes sure that the solution fits its mission?
	      (ii) How distilling the direction of change, and designing the domain essence are explicit architectural activities?
	      (iii) How creating the detailed structure, and designing the domain essence can be done in an emergent way
2.	Trace the history of software development practices from waterfall phases through iterative design to agile techniques. These include
	      (i)The implementation of a project lifecycle selection framework
	      (ii) An approach for tailoring any defined method
	      (iii) A consideration of all elements of a development environment
	      (iv) Incremental adoption of change
	      (v) The implementation of a CoE (Center of Excellence)
3.	How to identify the right amount of architecture by looking at the problem being addressed from a different perspective?
4.	How to minimize rework through reasonable foresight and prototypes?
5.	How to accelerate delivery through early integration, continuous testing and automated deployment pipeline?
talk.notes: Over the past few years, I am working on projects where the requirements are not fully defined up front. Also we are following an iterative approach to refine the requirements. So creating architecture and bringing the changes in each iteration is a real challenge. In this talk, I am going to talk about how the hybrid technique (using explicit and emergent architecture) will help to overcome some of the challenges. Also my talk will be based on the challenges I am facing on my current projects.
talk.abstract: In agile process, is the architecture of the system designed up-front, or does it emerge over time as the result of the agile software development process? The ability to adapt and innovate is driven by Architecture and Agile Practices. This paper shows the techniques an architect can use in agile.

ratings.comments:
This another talk addressing the question in the "Digital, Virtual Software Architect": How can we be effective in fast-moving agile environments?

This talk differentiates itself by focusing on design.  The promise of techniques for identifying the correct level of architecture in order to avoid rework is of particular interest.

My only concern is the time available.  There seems to be a lot to cover in just 15 minutes.
Seems like it is covering too much for 15 minutes.
The focus is improving though still a concern. The abstract communicates the general concept. I'd like to understand what personal experience the speaker will bring to the presentation.

This talks needs better focus. As proposed, it is covering a wide range of information in only 15 minutes. That will not result in a powerful talk.

Focus may be narrowed and improved based on feedback.

feedback.body:
Thank you for the submission. Agile architecting is a topic of interest as development times continue to shorten.

Could you explain more about what type of agile development you are addressing? You have mention "agile software development process" (lowercase agile) and "Agile Practices" (uppercase Agile). There can be differences, and audience members may make incorrect assumptions. Will the talk address how architecting activities relate to some specific Agile methods (for example, sprints) or is it more about architecting in a less strictly defined but still rapidly changing environment?

It may be difficult to present all the proposed content in 15 minutes. The abstract describes five topics, some with subtopics. If you need to shorten it, I suggest that the history information (waterfall to iterative to agile) could be trimmed out. That is information audience members can find in other places (for example, on the Web).

How you specifically combined architecting tasks and work produces with agile timelines, and how you are able to continually revise the architecture without big tear ups and lost work will be most valuable to audience members. I suggest a focus on those aspects (that is, your topic 3).

For which track is this talk proposed? Track 1 or 3 seem applicable.

Thank you for the feedback. Please see below my answers to your questions.

In this topic, I was trying to address how architecting activities relate to Agile Software Development (ASD) methods (for example Scrum). In other words  how architects can be effective in iterative, incremental and evolutionary development . I agree that it is difficult to cover the topics I put in my abstract in 15 minutes. So I am thinking of concentrating what you proposed which is mostly on topic 3. So here I will concentrate more on how to continually revise the architecture without big tear ups and lost work or how to avoid design erosion.  

I think this will fit on Track 1 (how architects can be effective in fast-moving, agile environments)

So here is my revised abstract on this topic.

Over the past few years, there is a question central to many discussions surrounding agile approaches to architecting software: In agile process, is the architecture of the system designed up-front, or does it emerge over time as the result of the agile software development process such as Scrum? However, according to the followers of Agile Software Development (ASD) methods, upfront design and evaluation of Software Architecture are likely to consume lot of time and effort without providing a valuable deliverables. The proponents of Software Architecture believe that sound architectural practices cannot be followed using agile approaches. This presentation shows how software architects embrace change by systematically altering design activities with iterative architecture assessment and refactoring.

talk.title: An Architect's Framework for Navigating Complexity
talk.description:
We want our organizations and systems to be agile. We want them to evolve with the needs of the business, its customers and stakeholders, and to be resilient in the face of ever changing market conditions and the external environment. This level of adaptability and responsiveness needs to be supported by the architecture of the systems we create. The complexity of the environment that architects find themselves in is increasing in recent years, with cloud, DevOps, continuous deployment, micro services and other elements adding to the factors that architects must consider. With this growing complexity, architects need to be supported by effective decision-making approaches.

Size is also a factor. Larger systems and larger organizations have, by definition, a larger number of dependencies (internal and external) that must be managed, and a larger number of stakeholders (internal and external) whose needs must be addressed. The architecture of larger systems can involve hundreds or thousands of people, creating dozens to hundreds of products, components and subsystems that all need to work together. Maintaining the conceptual integrity of the architecture under such circumstances, and over time, presents many challenges and a greater need for coherence. 

To navigate all of this, agile architects need to be adaptive; they need the ability to dynamically shift their decision-making approach to match the complexity of the circumstances they face. This session will describe how lessons from complexity science, and in particular, sense making and the Cynefin framework, can help architects to be more agile in how they work, and in turn, help them develop architectures that are more agile and adaptive to the needs of the organizations they serve.

### Learning Outcomes
* Applying sense making in the context of architecture
* Applying the Cynefin framework to architecture problems and decisions
* Examples of architecture problems and decisions that can be mapped to the different domains represented by the Cynefin framework (obvious, complicated, complex, chaotic and disorder)
* How to manage the transition of architecture problems between these different domains
* Implications for organization structure and communications
* How such an approach leads to a more resilient architecture, and a more antifragile organization
* How complexity thinking and the Cynefin framework supports emergent architecture
* How complexity thinking and the Cynefin framework help the organization and the architecture to be more agile

### Format
For a 90-minute workshop I typically use the following format. 

Part 1 (5 minutes):
Introduction

* Overview of concepts

Part 2 (10 minutes): 

* Architecture descriptions
* Using narrative to understand architecture

Part 3 (40 minutes):

* Sense Making analysis of architectures and their influence on the organisation
* Analysing the patterns that emerge from the sense making activity

Part 4 (30 minutes):

* The Cynefin Framework, and how it applies to architecture
* Designing experiments

Part 5 (5 minutes):

* Debrief and wrap up
talk.notes:
The majority of the session is highly participatory. All five parts outlined in the session description have some element of participation. Parts 2-4 are the major parts of the session. In part 2, I guide participants through sketching their architecture and creating narrative about their architecture. In part 3, I guide participants in analysing their architecture/sketch/narrative using a sense making framework. In part 4, I guide participants in understanding the Cynefin framework in more detail and designing an experiment to address complex challenges that emerge in the analysis. Parts 1 and 5 have less activity, but still have dialog and interaction.

I will bring all the supplies that I need to run the exercise. It is more effective if the room is set up “banquet style”, with round tables that set groups of 6-10. 

I have been working with sensemaking and complexity for a few years now, and have run variations of this activity many times, both inside Cisco and at conferences and other forums. At the heart of this is the concept of applying sensemaking and the Cynefin framework to managing the complexity faced by architects. That complexity is not just in the architecture itself, but also in the problem domain, the organization, and the wider context within which architects do their work.

My background is in software engineering and architecture, in the context of product and systems development, and in transforming engineering organizations around the world. I use the techniques I present here in my own work, and I also help architects, engineers, and others, apply these techniques in their work.

In part 2, I guide participants through sketching their architecture and creating narrative about their architecture. In part 3, I guide participants in analysing their architecture/sketch/narrative using a sense making framework. In part 4, I guide participants in understanding the Cynefin framework in more detail and designing an experiment to address complex challenges that emerge in the analysis. Parts 1 and 5 have less activity, but still have dialog and interaction.

Regarding the article you refer to: yes, there is a relationship. We both draw on some of the same reference material. I draw on a broader set of Dave's work, as well as other work in sense making and complexity. I also take participants through how to apply this work in practice.

Regards,
Ken

talk.title: Android libraries I wish I knew about when I started
talk.description:
There’s no sense in re-inventing the wheel when you’re working on Android apps, especially if you’re just starting out. This talk will cover a range of libraries you can include in your Android apps that will help you tackle the problems other people have already solved. Whether you’re loading data from a web api, showing & caching images, or storing & syncing data there’s a library you can pull in to help you out!
No prior knowledge of any of these libraries required. Libraries covered will include: Butter Knife, Picasso, Gson, Retrofit, Realm, Dart & Henson.
talk.notes:
This talk will last 30 minutes. This presentation won't need anything special besides A/V setup.

Having learned the hard way when starting out in developing for Android, I have an experience that can help better inform others who are starting out. I learned a lot of lessons while starting out developing for Android and I seek to share those in this talk.

talk.title: An In-Depth Look at Event Sourcing with CQRS
talk.description:
Although Event Sourcing has been around for many years, it remains outside the mainstream paradigm of software development--much to our detriment.

With Event Sourcing, we place the highest value on the simple capture of essential business events without attempting to interpret them. We can then relegate all interpretations of those events to subsystems that are easy to build, change, and replace when necessary. The resulting systems have single responsibilities and are decoupled from each other, which makes them simple to modify. Event Sourcing can enable us to move faster by supporting rapid experimentation with new perspectives, new user interactions, and new insights into our business.

Event Sourcing is agnostic of technology stack and language style, but it goes well with another pattern called CQRS: Command Query Responsibility Segregation. In this talk, we will do a deep-dive into the two patterns and scope out a system that has:

* Receiving and validating Commands that, if successful, result in Events (with pseudocode to illustrate how it might work).
* Interpreting Events into denormalised projections for very fast reads.
* Single responsibility services for reacting to Events by creating other events and, if necessary, triggering external behaviour.

We will also cover more in-depth topics, such as:

* Strategies for evolving events and event schemas over time.
* Dealing with eventual consistency.
* Popular technologies for various system components, such as how to store and distribute events.
talk.notes:
This is a 90 minute talk. I gave a 30 minute version of this talk at SATURN 2016, which was very well received. I thought I'd see if there was interest in a longer version to expand on the many questions that followed. You can see the 2016 talk here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_TeMYF_JjNg

Since last year, my involvement in building Event Sourced systems have grown exponentially. My company, Envato, has continued building Event Sourced systems and has emerged as a leader for this particular pattern in Australia. As the principal Software Architect at Envato, I have been a key part of this journey, which has also involved speaking with a variety of other companies about their Event Sourcing experiences.
talk.abstract: Event Sourcing is an approach to building software with a long track record of success. By placing business concepts at the heart of our code, we can decouple systems into small services that can be quickly built, changed, and replaced. This talk will show you how.

Thank you for your submission. I have a few comments/suggestions:

# In the description, instead of "completely disposable subsystems", I'd rather say something like "subsystems that can be turned on and off."  That sentence BTW is quite long. Please consider breaking it into two. 

# If you want to make the Description shorter, I'd suggest loosing this sentence: "Without needing to predict the future, we are in a much better position to respond to it when it arrives."  I can't connect it to the previous sentence without appealing to intuition.

# You could be more specific where you say "Popular technologies for various system components." Maybe mention what components...

# You may already be planning to, but I suggest showing key code snippets or pseudo-code for processing a command that results in Events.

Anyway, there is a connection between Event Sourcing and EDA (imagine that the command itself arrives at the system as an event...), so I think it would be interesting to mention that connection in the tutorial, in case it fits within the information flow.
Oops. Sorry for the font size. It was supposed to be an ordered list but it seems I used the wrong markdown symbol.  :^b

talk.title: An invisible app? An Introduction to Inclusive Design & Fundamental User Experience Best Practices
talk.description:
An invisible app? An Introduction to Inclusive Design & Fundamental User Experience Best Practices
I know what you're thinking. You want to know what the triple-A app titles already know. It's Inclusive Design, a process to deliver intuitive usability; it is the heart-and-soul of great User Experience and innovative interactions. Your app is in a cosmic battle with the Uninstall button; inclusive design changes the nature of your app, tipping the scales in your favor. Appeal to your largest audience, provide cohesive experiences, and reduce development costs. It is an investment with one of the best returns in all of software. It's simple, cheap and awesome.

Application security is fundamental to software from initial design to every line developed. Security should not be an afterthought. Similarly, usability has this same ubiquity throughout the life-cycle of software. The fastest, most secure, most scalable software can end up in the trash because it misses the most important success criteria for any program in the universe - user acceptance. Software architecture profoundly impacts usability. Usability profoundly impacts acceptance. Architects may not choose app colors, error messages, and device layout, but they certainly make choices that enable and constrain designers options that make our software better. Like security is everyone’s responsibility at some level, so is usability at some level.

What will attendees learn? Inclusive design isn’t only usability; it’s recognizing that your user base changes as their social and environmental contexts change. If your user is standing in the sun, waiting for a train in the snow, holding a baby, riding a bus, visiting a library or watching the big game in a sports bar, applications can account for the one type of user that, given a certain context, looks and acts like another type of user. Inclusive design helps developers understand these contexts. It applies these to our implementations to add modalities, flexibility in workflows, and intentional tolerance for user mistakes. Developers will learn to recognize contextual assumptions and apply new, potential contexts to their existing user base so they can serve them best while consequently serving a new, larger user base.
talk.notes:
This is a 90 minute talk.

The structure of the talk includes:
1. Introduction to basic user types
2. Introduction to core user contexts
3. Examples of design assumptions
4. Examples of coding mistakes
5. Examples of app wins
6. Easy changes to the UI you can make today
7. Easy changes to the code you can make today
8.  Fundamental changes to code you can make next time

feedback.body:
Jerry -
A couple of questions:
- Are you proposing a 30-minute or 90-minute talk? Unfortunately, there is no way to specify this in the submission template - seems like a less-than-inclusive design?

- Your proposal doesn't say much about your talk. How will you structure the talk, e.g., a running example? What will attendees learn, e.g., do you have a design process or checklist? 

- SATURN attendees are software architects, not UX designers. What is in this talk for an architect?

Thank you.

Thank you for your submission. 
I have a few suggestions from the perspective of a conference participant looking at the conference program:

1) Because SATURN is focused on software architecture, the word design is more readily associated with software architecture design. In your talk, design is User Interface design if I'm not mistaken. Not a problem, but it would avoid someone the confusion if you explicitly said UI desing somewhere (example: "Inclusive UI Design"). 

2) In the Description, it would be useful to qualify app as "mobile app" in at least one place. 

3) This sentence is not clear to me: "inclusive design changes the nature of your app, tipping the scales in your favor."  I'm not sure changing the nature of my app is a goal to pursue. What I want primarily is to improve its quality (usability, performance, badwidth utilization, power consumption, portability, maintainability, security, etc.).

In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

This is really great feedback. Consider security. It is fundamental to software from initial design to every line developed. Security is not an afterthought. Similarly, usability has this ubiquity throughout the life-cycle of software. The fastest, most secure, most scalable software can end up in the trash because it misses the most important success criteria for any program in the universe - user acceptance. Software architecture profoundly impacts usability. Usability profoundly impacts acceptance. Though architects may not choose app colors, error messages, and device layout, they certainly make choices that enable or constrain designers and the options they might employ. Like security is everyone's responsibility, so is usability. Inclusive design, on the other hand isn't only about usability; it's about recognizing that your user base changes as their social and environmental contexts change. If your user is standing in the sun, waiting for a train in the snow, holding a baby, riding a bus, visiting a library or watching the big game in a sports bar, applications can account for the one type of user given a certain context looks and acts like another type of user. Inclusive design helps developers understand these contexts and apply them to the implementation of their software for to add more modalities, flexibility in workflows, and intentional tolerance for user mistakes.

I wanted to reply one quick thing to John about the word "design". I did not make up the term Inclusive Design, and I understand the word design has a meaning to developers and designers. But I can't change it because it's the real name of the approach. I added a lot of context in the description that I hope will make it clear to developers that this is for developers and not designers (designers would likely appreciate the content). And this is about using our development decisions to make the design better. I hope this makes sense.

talk.title: Architecture Decision Records in Action
talk.description:
Documenting architecture design decisions is commonly considered a good practice but few teams take the time to write down the decisions they make.  In my experience this happens for a few reasons:  architecture documentation is rejected as being too heavyweight, documentation is typically out of sight and out of mind, and many developers don't know what to document.  Architecture Decision Records (ADRs), a lightweight documentation approach [proposed by Michael Nygard](http://thinkrelevance.com/blog/2011/11/15/documenting-architecture-decisions), solves these problems by recording design decisions in a simple markdown template in the same repository as the code affected by the ADR.  In this talk we will share our experiences and lessons using ADRs over the past year while working on multiple projects for IBM Watson.

By the end of this talk you will be able to create effective ADRs, introduce them to your team, and avoid common pitfalls with the method.
talk.notes:
This talk is intended to be a 30 minute experience report.  I can't figure out how to change the session type to match this.

The talk will have the following tentative outline.

1. Introduction / Problem overview: teammates don't have architectural context, decisions aren't communicated and are lost over time
   * Failed attempts to solve the problem -- wikis, dedicated repos, "official" documentation
2. ADRs Overview
   * Nygard's proposal
   * Connection to other work and research
3. How we use ADRs
4. Exercise: Create an ADR (optional, may fall out depending on timing, at most this is a 5-7 minute exercise)
5. Case Study: IBM Watson Information Retrieval Enhanced team
   * This section will include the proposed lessons and tips for adopting and using ADRs based on our experiences
   * Create a common template that everyone agrees to use
       * examples from case study
   * Identify an architecture champion to point out when architectural design decisions happen
   * Add ADR creation tasks to the backlog
   * Use pull requests and peer reviews to teach people how to record a decision and to
       spread konwledge about decisions
   * Use ADRs to grow architects on your team
       * Creating an ADR is a small slice of design responsibility.  It turns out to be a great way to
           infuse the team with architectural thinking and train new architects
   * Store ADRs with the code
   * Works great with microservices where small groups of people and the code
       they create work autonomously within a light governance framework
   * Revisit old ADRs every so often to update them and ensure you have accurate reflection of current thinking
6. Problems we ran into with ADRs and are still working through
   * Plain text diagramming is a pain point.
   * ADRs emphasize architectural decisions for a single component.  This is great for smaller projects and
      individual microservices but falls apart when multiple architectural components stored in multiple code
      repositories are involved.
      * Our solution was to create an "Architecture" repository, which stored ADRs that cut across multiple
         architectural components, linking to refinement ADRs as appropriate.
   * Overemphasis on design decisions at the expense of other design documentation
       * The team became awesome at recording ADRs to the point where they wouldn't document anything else!
       * ADRs were smashing success.  Complementary methods that are as simple and lightweight are needed for
          design concepts other than decisions.  examples: alternatives, governance policies, general design guidance,
          quality attribute scenarios and other architecturally significant requirements
7. Conclusion
   * closing thoughts on using ADRs as a way to "sneak in" architecture
   * great way to create a history of the project and explain not only where we are but how the system arrived at this point
   * Show where ADRs fit as part of an documentation strategy 
   * Links to additional resources
talk.abstract: Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) capture key architectural design decisions in a lightweight, easy-to-create, plain text template stored in your existing version control system.  In this talk we will explore case studies from the IBM Watson IR Enhanced team and learn how to use ADRs.

feedback.body:
Michael-
The SEI Views and Beyond book discusses documenting architecture decisions (Section 6.5). That discussion was based on work by Jeff Tyree and Art Ackermann (https://www.utdallas.edu/~chung/SA/zz-Impreso-architecture_decisions-tyree-05.pdf). It might be worth including some comments in your talk about how your/Nygaard's approach compares and contrasts with this earlier work.

Hi John,  Thanks for your feedback.  I am familiar with the Tyree/Ackermann paper.  I actually [referenced the same paper as a comment on the blog](http://disq.us/p/18d4i4r) about 8 months ago in an attempt to point out the same thing!  We also include a link to Nygard's blog and that paper in our ADR template as background information.

I am certainly planning to make this connection in the talk, if accepted.  The two templates have the same goal in the end but collect slightly different information.  The ADR is significantly simpler, if nothing else.  I think a key difference and the thing that is kind of unique about Nygard's approach is in what is done with this information.  It sounds simple, but storing the design decisions in the version control system acted almost as a stealth way of injecting some of the ideas from Views and Beyond into the team.  What's more a small ecosystem of tools has sprung up around ADRs.  See https://github.com/npryce/adr-tools and https://github.com/holytshirt/dotnet-adr as examples.

Finally, Thougtworks recently [classified ADRs as "trial" methodology](https://www.thoughtworks.com/radar/techniques/lightweight-architecture-decision-records).  It is my hope that an experience report like this might provide additional backing for either making this practice a recommended approach, or at least recommending it with caveats.

Regards,

Michael

That's a great topic and thanks for submitting. I first encountered the importance of maintaining Architectural Decisions ass a part of the SEI Views and Beyond book. I have been a great advocate and have used them ever since. I think its an important technique that needs good attention and would help many Architects attending the conference. The approach of understanding software architecture in terms of a variety of architecture decisions is now widely recognized.

However, I do have a suggestion. Instead of the talk just focusing on ADR as suggested by Michael Nygard, what would be even useful is discussing the approaching of Documenting Architecture Decisions as a whole, which decisions to document and not, the payback/benefits and the variants available for documenting them along with your case study.

Also, I am concerned about the idea of just storing the Architecture Decisions in isolation without many other significant Architectural Artifacts. I understand that the Thoughtworks seems to recommend including them in the “trial” methodology. However, I am just concerned with the misnomer that these are the only set of significant artifacts for all cases. Could the details be presented more on the lines of Evolutionary Architecture.

Hi Yogeshwar, thanks for your feedback!

I share your concerns and plan to address them in the talk.  I mentioned the points you raise under section 6.  I am certainly not suggesting this is the only set of artifacts required and recognize this is a trap teams easily fall into -- one of my teams did!

With respect to deciding when to document a decision vs. not, I plan to cover that under 5.4 and 5.5.  It turns out that people don't always know or recognize when an architectural decision has been made.  Pull requests and explicit architecture tasks combined with pairing was how we worked through some of those issues, in addition to including clear guidance in our template.  Basically we created situations for on the job training over time.

My goal is to attempt to place this technique within the context of the broader literature, as you suggest.  As you also point out, the idea of recording decisions is not new and is a commonly understood good practice.  The point of this talk is not to retread old ground but to look at good practice from the perspective of a newer method that people actually use and seems to resonate well with developers.  These ideas have been around for a while, and yet few teams practice them.  Why?  I think this method is another incremental step in the right direction.  By the end of the talk people will be armed with the knowledge they need to be successful with the method, not just try it out.

Regards,

Michael
Thanks for the detail! All the very best.

Looks like a very interesting session, Michael. I think maybe I would drop the exercise in a 30 min talk, the coordination can be potentially time consuming. Just a thought. Otherwise it looks like a solid outline.

talk.title: A software architect and a big band drummer walk into a bar, and their parallel universes collide.
talk.description:
The software architect is the lone carrier of DNA for the vision of the product, but does not work alone. He/she is placed on a project (“situation”) where he/she must still deliver. The big band drummer can single handedly guide a band, and is placed on a gig (“situation”) where he/she must deliver. What is at the core of the big band drummer’s DNA to bring about success and what parallels might we draw between the two? Come and find out.

Sometimes the most efficient way to a fresh perspective is to sit in the seat of someone else from a totally unrelated field. Reading Harvard Business Review, competitive companies seek advice from totally unrelated fields to solve their most difficult problems. So why should it be any different for software architect?  The software architect’s role in leading teams and influencing business decisions cannot be overlooked. 

John Ryskowski would love to reveal the big band drummer’s strategy for success and its attendant parallels to the software architect’s “situation.”  Of course, band stories and drumming demonstrations will be included.
talk.notes:
Session Requirements:
1) To start a conversation that will last throughout the rest of the conference. 
2) To obtain a “fresh perspective” by taking folks down the path of a totally unrelated field and drawing pertinent parallels for and with them. 
3) As an architect one must create and nurture the vision for the DNA of the product, in spite of the project situation. The big band drummer must nurture a good sound from the big band, in spite of the gig situation. The parallels between the two should be realized, discussed, and brought to grounded historical experiences for each attendee. 
4) To introduce some new language that may help put project situations into perspective allowing one to return to clarity of thought. Psychologically speaking we get some relief from having name for some events or techniques. For example, I need to vary my intensity to get the group affect that I desire.

The session breakdown:
Handouts: The actual drum chart for the subject of the talk- Kubis’ arrangement of “A Train,” and the “Clapping at Camp” chart written for audience participation. Big sticky papers will be on the walls of the room. 

1) Explain how one path to a fresh perspective is to experience something that is totally unrelated, but at the same time reveals grounded parallels to your situation. Executing a big band chart requires a strategy with known techniques but the flexibility to grab opportunities to inspire and transcend the moment. Through subtle and timely queues, the drummer can instill a sense of confidence and inspire the band to play better than they imagined. The techniques we discuss could have the same effect for the people on the architect’s project.
2) Through demonstration, we discuss some of the possible variations the drum set can offer. This would include the elements of the drum set with each of their different sounds, the 4 limbs of the body, and just some of the combinations thereof. We will stick with the combinations that are most pertinent for this talk, and don’t forget the eyes and brain play a role as well. 
3) We get into a discussion about some of the situations the big band drummer must deal with. Does the band leader know little about music (or does the manager of the program or product owner know little about the technology)?  Does the lead trumpet think he is with the Count Bassie band (or is your development principle unaccustomed to this environment)? Can the bass player not play in time (or does your development principle have no sense of time)? Is the drum set in the absolute worst location to work with the rest of the band (or are you stuck without a reasonable means of communication with the rest of the team)? I will demonstrate how the big band drummer overcomes each of these situations. 
I then ask each member of the audience to choose which situation they resonate with most. Audience members will then join 1 of 4 groups to discuss their personal situations, their solutions or possible solutions then elect the top 3 solutions to brief the rest of the other groups. 
4) Two vital techniques in big band drumming are then discussed: “Distinguishing signal from noise” knowing the current location of the chart without listening to anyone’s sense of time, and “Some of your great ideas may not be so great.” The audience will then be asked to verbalize their own parallels, and If the interest and energy are present, we can briefly split into two groups, discuss and brief.
5) The “Kubis” chart is then projected on the screen and actually played on the drum set asking the audience to try and observe, as best they can, all that is going on with the drum set performance. We then deconstruct each element of successful drum chart execution. Each element and a lesson to take away:
a) Element- Initiating and maintaining a tempo for the band. Lesson- What is least exciting for you may be most important to them.  You set the tone for what is to come and instill a sense of calm. Sometimes you’re just a piece of leverage. Wow that last one hurt.
b) Element- Identify milestones. Lesson- Marking points in time to celebrate progress, ensure social/technical alignment, and instill confidence.
c) Element- Vary intensity as needed. Lesson- Selectively applying energy at the right times and in the right places, balancing support, teaching, and inspiration.
d) Element- Special care. Lesson- Sometimes hand-holding is necessary.
e) Element- Set them up for success. Lesson- Anytime you set someone up for success, they feel good and want to work with you. 
The audience is once again, asked to choose which of these they resonate with most. Audience members will then join 1 of 5 groups and discuss their personal situations (or parallels) amongst their group. Each group will then brief the other groups. 
6) The “Clapping at Camp” chart is introduced. I show how without even being able to read music (or a rhythm chart) I can still set them up for success. We rehearse the sections of the chart. Then we perform the chart together and they clap in time like they were born to do it. It’s really fun.

Presentation History
This topic has been presented at Agile West, Las Vegas, 2016. 
Summary score of 8.69. Total attendees 45. Total of 4 written comments here verbatim:
1- Fun! Fun! Fun! Perspective and musical metaphor
2- Novel application and most engaging session by far! 
3- Very unique, engaging, and appropriate. One of my favorite presentations and many parallels were illustrated.
4- Content was delivered in a muddled way. Good points were buried in musician stories and metaphors.

References to Speaking Ability
I like to pull people out of their everyday situations, immerse them into something completely different that is fun and interesting, then help them to draw parallels back to their everyday situations. This is an efficient path to a fresh perspective, which is the most valuable take-away from any conference.  
The ideal reaction cycle I strive for is: a) I wonder what that would be like, b) cool I didn’t know that, c) whoa I need to try this out. 
I have spoken at Agile West, CMMI Institute Conferences, Pacific Norhwest Software Quality Conference, National Defense Industrial Association. I have also delivered good and bad news to leaders of many corporations. 

References: 
Kerry Trujillo,  Kerry_Trujillo@raytheon.com, see linkedIn recommendation
Michael West, michael@naturalspi.com
talk.abstract: How does the architect ensure a great product, in spite of, well, the situation at hand? How does a big band drummer ensure great music, in spite of, well, the situation at hand? The parallels will entertain and surprise you, and maybe, bring about a fresh perspective that is difficult to achieve.

feedback.body:
I realize the presentation for Agile West was for a different audience with an emphasis on team leadership. I’m curious if any parallels to architect or architecture surfaced during your presentation at that venue. This proposal fits Topic 3, “The software architect’s role in leading teams and influencing business decisions” in the call for presentations. There are different ways to approach this, with perspectives on people, process, or product. It is not necessary to cover all perspectives though I’d like to better understand where you will probe for parallels. Do you think the product (software architecture) will be a point of discussion or will it be more about stories of people and process?

Your notes provide a good sense of the topics covered and the flow through the session. A little more information about timing within the 90 minutes would be helpful. The breakdown into element and lesson gives a sense of the parallels between drummer and leadership (in general). Would you say more about the points you will make about how these relate more specifically to the architect’s “situation”.

Hi Robert- I appreciate the interest.

Timing and did any parallels to architect surface at Agile West- The Agile West presentation was limited to 45 minutes and so had a lot less group participation than what I am proposing for SATURN.  The group participation discussed in steps 3, 5, and possibly step 4, in the SATURN proposal are an addition to this version of the talk. These group exercises will allow for a richer processing experience for the folks than what happened at AW. All this added up gives me about 35 minutes for 2 or 3 group participation exercises which should be no problem. This is general time estimate, if specific time allocations are required I would be happy to add them.  Additionally, in this limited time, at AW no parallels to architect came up at AW.

As for being under topic 3, I am happy to go with that. People, process, or product- the parallels will focus mostly on people. People are the common point between BB drumming and architects. But to be honest with you, I am not sure where these group exercises will go. One of the verbal comments after my talk at AW was that I did not presuppose to know the parallels exactly, and left space for attendees to formulate their own. It is the opening of this space that is my objective, less so giving a direct answer.   

From you- The breakdown into element and lesson gives a sense of the parallels between drummer and leadership (in general). Would you say more about the points you will make about how these relate more specifically to the architect’s “situation”. 

Response- From the 5000 foot perspective, the BB Drummer and architect have the same challenge. Take responsibility for the vision and integrity of the product without being given any authority or owning any of the resources. From lower altitude I am happy to make some adjustments though I do worry about anchoring, or disrupting where participants can go with their parallels. How do you feel about the “additions” below?

5a) Element- Initiating and maintaining a tempo for the band. Lesson- What is least exciting for you may be most important to them.  You set the tone for what is to come and instill a sense of calm. Sometimes you’re just a piece of leverage. Wow that last one hurt. Addition- While trying to balance creativity, risk, stakeholders and the responsibility to change the world, it is good to have a basic rhythm that all can operate to. 

5b) Element- Identify milestones. Lesson- Marking points in time to celebrate progress, ensure social/technical alignment, and instill confidence. Addition-  Is there a build and release rhythm you can work to?

5c) Element- Vary intensity as needed. Lesson- Selectively applying energy at the right times and in the right places, balancing support, teaching, and inspiration. Addition- The creative process comes down to a give and take in real time. You must dabble in interactions with people in the “known” before you can step over to the “unknown.”

5d) Element- Special care. Lesson- Sometimes hand-holding is necessary. Addition- Sometimes you don’t have to blow up the village in order to save it. Education and patience can pay off. 

5e) Element- Set them up for success. Lesson- Anytime you set someone up for success, they feel good and want to work with you. Addition- Introduce people to the patterns that you see with grace and composure to assure overall success. 

Best- John

talk.title: Automate ALL the Things: Taking Advantage of Free Tools to Automate Your End-to-End Release Pipelines
talk.description:
A myriad of point-tools, frameworks and infrastructures are involved in your software delivery process – from development, through build, testing, deployment, all the way to a Production Release.

While many of these tools are free/open source, the operational and technology overhead of orchestrating the hand-offs from one tool to the next in the process are not without cost.

To improve developer productivity and resource utilization – and to enable enterprise-scale, cross-project visibility and shorter time to market – organizations are working to automate and orchestrate the entire tool chain across the end-to-end delivery pipeline.
“Automate All the Things” is a key tenant to any DevOps or Continuous Delivery initiative.

This presentation will use a real case study to show how you can orchestrate your entire software delivery pipeline. Learn how to create a fully-automated release pipeline, tying-in common tools that you likely use in your process from CI build to Release: including Git, Jenkins, Selenium, Chef, Docker, and more.

Learn how to:

Seamlessly orchestrate third-party tools to automate your entire process- from start to finish

Get visibility into your end-to-end application release pipeline

Deploy any application to any environment using any tool-set – for free.
talk.notes:
As Global Technical Account Manager at Electric Cloud, I work with some of our largest customers, and help them use our solutions to improve their software development and delivery processes.  I help with overall strategy deploying our software across large organizations, design and implementation, as well as looking ahead to make sure the solution support future growth plans. Before joining Electric Cloud, I worked as a kernel developer at IBM for five years. 

I have previously presented at StackWorld 2016, StackWorld Virtual 2016, and Merge 2016. 

Outline: 

1. What does your software delivery pipeline look like?
2. What is a Commit Pipeline vs. Release Pipeline
3. How do you ensure fidelity of processes, environments, configuration and artifacts across the pipeline- from code check-in to Production
4. What point tools are involved in your pipeline, how many are open source/free?
5. What are the challenges with managing a myriad of tools, across different teams
6. Don’t replace your existing tools, orchestrate.
7. What is the difference between automation and orchestration
8. What do you need for end-to-end orchestration
9. A little bit about ElectricFlow – a free devops orchestration platform
10. What are the benefits and ROI of orchestration of the pipeline
11. Consider a common pipeline using free tools- from developer check-in with Git, through CI with Jenkins, Publish to repo w/ Docker, then to Staging for testing, run Selenium tests, upon success- deploy to Docker in Prod.
12. DEMO of this pipeline – orchestrating all the free tools with ElectricFlow.

feedback.body:
Thank you for your submission. I have a few suggestions: 
1) Include in the Notes section an outline of your talk. It can be a tentative outline. 
2) Remove the hyphen in this phrase in the Talk Description section: "in the process – are not without cost."
3) Revise the last item of what attendants will learn ("Deploy any application to any environment using any tool-set"). I might be wrong, but it sounds like a bit of an overstatement because "any environment" would include embedded systems, mainframe platforms, and others that are possibly not covered by your solution. 
4) Minor point: the items under "Learn how to" can be a bulleted list. Just use '*' or '+' or '-'.

Hi Avan,

When you say "Deploy any application to any environment using any tool-set – for free," is that including the costs of orchestrating the hand-offs?

Are you presenting a technique that makes those orchestrations unnecessary?  Is this technique generally applicable, or restricted to a specific tool-set?

Regards, 


Ged

Paulo and Ged - 

Thank you for your feedback. We have updated the description and notes section per your requests. 

Re: “Deploy any application to any environment using any tool-set”:

Actually, a LOT of ElectricFlow users use the platform for deploying of Embedded devices (Huawei, Qualcomm, General Motors, MIP, automotive manufacturers, etc.)- so it’s not just for web applications. Ged - do these updates answer any of your questions as well?

Let me know if this helps. 

Thank you, 

Avan

Hi Avan,

Thank-you for your response.  The updates do help to answer my questions, but it does leave me with a couple of concerns.

The first is still regarding the the claim: "Deploy any application to any environment using any tool-set – for free." 

When you say "free" do you mean free of licensing cost, or free of the cost of "the operational and technology overhead."
