talk.title: Building composable abstractions
talk.description: Do you want to create robust and composable abstractions? In this talk Eric Normand will present an iterative process to define the essence of a domain and build composability into the core. The resulting abstractions lead to more robust code at the core of your application, and can give your business a competitive advantage. We will apply this process to the Processing graphics library to develop a composable vector graphics system.
talk.notes:
This is a 60 minute talk.

After attending the talk, the attendee will be able to:

1. Know the difference between Newtonian-style abstractions and Aristotelian-style abstractions. Aristotelian abstractions are built up piecemeal and are full of corner cases, like Aristotelian physics. Newtonian abstractions are elegant, formal, and composable.

2. Follow a design process for developing an algebraic abstraction that can compose and easily express solutions (Newtonian style). Building data transformation pipelines is the step most people who are learning functional programming get to from reading and experimenting. Building algebraic abstractions is the next step, but there isn't much literature on the topic (outside of academia)
    1. Elaborate a physical metaphor
    2. Describe the meaning of your metaphor as mathematical statements
    3. Construct the meaning using constructs from the language
    4. Implement the abstraction by refactoring the meaning
	
	The physical metaphor is an important first step that gives us an anchor from which we may use our intuition. We then query our metaphor for its properties and write them in math, which usually means types and equations. After that, we can construct a runnable version of the meaning, being careful to build it out of parts constrained by our statements from step 2. Finally, the implementation becomes an easy matter of refactoring our runnable version.


This topic idea comes from my experience teaching functional programming to people with all levels of experience. There seems to be a logical progression of insights that people go through as they learn about functional programming. I don't see many people getting past the "data transformation" step, so I want to present something further. It's hard to say whether it's THE next step, but it is at least one step beyond transformations.

A lot of the thinking comes from my experience as a professional Clojure and Haskell programmer and the work of Conal Elliott, John Hughes, and Gerald Sussman.

I have given a version of this talk at Clojure/conj 2016: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jJIUoaIvD20 I would love to adapt this to a language like JavaScript. The example code will be given in JavaScript.

talk.title: Building Secure(r) applications using Language-theoretic security.
talk.description:
Building Secure(r) applications using Language-theoretic security
=============

Language-theoretic security is the approach of recognizing and handling all input before processing it. Traditionally, almost every software development project mixes this recognition of input and processing of the input. If the recognition wasn't done right, then poor input can be processed and lead to exploits. 
Language-theoretic security suggests, that the recognition be separated from the processing making it easier to audit the code, and fundamentally prevent parser bugs from recurring. 
In this talk, I would present an overview of Language-theoretic security and describe the parser combinator library hammer. I would then describe the approach to building language-theoretic security compliant implementations of some popular application layer IoT protocols like MQTT, and discuss the performance overhead in this approach.
talk.abstract: Parser bugs in the recent past have been infamous -- Heartbleed, Android Master Key, Apple's Goto. In this talk, I would present a  methodology using parser combinator libraries to building web and IoT applications to ensure it isn't susceptible to the same category of vulnerabilities.

talk.title: CD for DBs: Database Deployment Strategies
talk.description:
As organizations invest in DevOps to release more frequently, there’s a need to treat the database tier as an integral part of your automated delivery pipeline – to build, test and deploy database changes just like any other part of your application.

However, databases (particularly RDBMS) are different from source code, and pose unique challenges to Continuous Delivery - especially in the context of deployments. Often, code changes require updating or migrating the database before the application can be deployed. A deployment method that works for installing a small database or a green-field application may not be suitable for industrial-scale databases. Updating the database can be more demanding than updating the app layer: database changes are more difficult to test, and rollbacks are harder. Furthermore, for organizations who strive to minimize service interruption to end users, database updates with no-downtime are a laborious operation. 

Your DB stores the most mission-critical and sensitive data of your organization (transaction data, business data, user information, etc.). As you update your database, you’d want to ensure data integrity, ACID, data retention, and have a solid rollback strategy - in case things go wrong …

This talk covers strategies for database deployments and rollbacks:

• What are some patterns and best practices for reliably deploying databases as part of your CD pipeline?
• How do you safely rollback database code? 
• How do you ensure data integrity?
• What are some best practices for handling advanced scenarios and back-end processes, such as scheduled tasks, ETL routines, replication architecture, linked databases across distributed infrastructure, and more.
• How to handle legacy database, alongside more modern data management solutions?

Michael, 

Thanks for the feedback. Please find more information you have asked for below.

What is your definition of chaos engineering?

In our definition, Chaos Engineering is a discipline where we will simulate real world failures which occur rarely and cause catastrophic losses to the systems. This is much more important in cloud environments where we have completely relinquished the infrastructure management and high level service management to the cloud provider. Traditional testing mechanisms do not cover such self inflicted failures. Using Chaos Engineering tools, applications can subject themselves to failures and measure their resiliency.

How do you commonly work with teams to improve their microservices?

As part of integration and performance testing of applications, we engage them and set them up with cloud detour, the chaos engineering tool. The application teams can then start registering various failures against the application and infrastructure. For example random termination of servers and high CPU simulation affecting the processes. This will help evaluate how the microservice performed against the failures and if it still met the NFRs.

how generally applicable the solution you use at Capital One is or whether it is highly specific to your needs

The solution is very generic for applications deployed in AWS. Any AWS deployed application will be able to use the various aspects of solution whether the application just uses Infrastructure services like EC2 or higher level application services like ECS/S3

Additional information on AWS and general availability

The tool received a great feedback in its initial pilot and currently being aggressively adopted by various divisions. talk.title: Component Systems in the Field: Integrating and Controlling System Services Easily using Connectors
talk.description:
We view software architectures as systems of connectors. A connector is a self-contained, physical (i.e. binary), identifiable special-purpose component that isolates interfaces from communicating components. This way interfaces contained in connectors become pivotal architectural elements.

Through interfaces in connectors, components can be supplied with extra-functional services, such as the monitoring and budgeting of system-resource usage, the profiling of architecturally relevant components, and the checking of communication protocols. These services are beneficial for industrial systems that are maintained and evolve in the field. Connectors are a means of realizing blue/green deployments, canary releases, and performance monitors; all of which are necessary for DevOps scenarios that work in industrial environments. Connectors take over these tasks. Components can focus on their core businesses.

Even without any extra-functional services, connectors provide two significant advantages to the development and operation of resource-constrained, safety-critical embedded systems. Firstly, connectors physically decouple communicating components, in the sense that components depend on connectors but connectors do not depend on components. Secondly, connectors do not need heavyweight component frameworks for implementation. 

Connectors can be built for and operated in rich runtime environments such as .NET CLR, and in thin runtime environments such as crt0 for the C++ system. The basic system need only support state-of-the art interface-based programming and linkable compiling units. To build connectors of different kinds, we use several techniques and design patterns of different pattern languages in different combinations, for example Factory, Strategy and Decorator from E. Gamma et al., Registry from M. Fowler, Bounded Context from E. Evans and Insulation from J. Lakos.

The presentation is divided into three parts. In the first part we introduce the minimal connector and explain the consequences and benefits for developing, testing and configuring component systems. In the second part we develop the minimal connector into light connectors containing plain interfaces (call and callback) and then into heavy connectors with additional extra-functional services. In the third part we apply connectors for structuring a system whose development follows the DevOps methodology.
talk.abstract: Physically independent connectors decouple components without performance costs. Services optionally built into connectors intersect orthogonally with component functions. Connectors considerably simplify DevOps scenarios in industrial environments.

feedback.body:
HI Thomas,

Thank-you for your submission.  The experiences you have to share sound very interesting.  Can I ask for a little more detail about the approach used?

When I hear of standardising on a common data model I think of the canonical data model pattern [1].  In recent years this approach has been  criticised [2] by those who favour the use of bounded contexts [3].

Do the pattern and solution from CRA relate to these patterns?  Are there other relevant patterns?  Does your experience reinforce or contradict any of these existing patterns?

Regards, 


Ged

[1] http://www.enterpriseintegrationpatterns.com/patterns/messaging/CanonicalDataModel.html 
[2] http://blog.xebia.com/microservices-architecture-principle-3-small-bounded-contexts-over-one-comprehensive-model/
[3] https://martinfowler.com/bliki/BoundedContext.html

Thank you for your insightful questions.  The first paragraph is the short answer and the next two paragraphs are background and explanation.  Your interest is greatly appreciated!

The model at CRA uses standards we developed for first data model for data collection which is bounded context.  In the ESRI data model we leveraged the Subtype and domains, where different subtypes drive the domains.  When we morphed the model into the ESRI standard electric utility model, the same holds true as the model is denormalized by mapping feature(i.e. transformer has a transformer layer rather than being one point feature in the point layer).

The modeling we applied has a time element.  There is a data collection stage of most any project which will require data to be normalized to geometry (points, lines and polygons representing features as electrical apparatus in the real world).  After this phase there is an information modeling aspect that requires use of standards to apply various third party tools and integrations.  The integrations vary depending on what solutions need to be integrated.  As budgets and priorities come into play the priorities are often different between power utilities.  However, Power utilities require Network Analysis and Power Outage Management Systems to maintain high systems availability.  The return on investment is staggering to implement the outage management and network analysis systems.  In addition the mapping must always tie to Work Management Systems.

Depending on the Utility size, microservices are typically used, however, there may need to be some cost saving, less expensive integrations such as ETL to move data into another format (i.e. daily job).  This is what happened with CRA and happens with most Power Utilities (even most very large ones).  There is a second reason for the reason web services cannot always be used – much of it has to do with the industry needs a network model that has sufficient performance.

Hi Thomas,

Thanks for your submission!  What are the top 2-3 key take aways you want someone who attends your talk to learn?  What will attendees be able to do after your talk that they couldn't do before?

Regards,

Michael

Michael,

These are good questions.  

The strategy of implementation may need to consider phases of information modeling
over time in advance.  

Those attending the talk will learn realistic information systems implementations will need to be executed through
flexibility of information flow and technology.  Reuse of microservices and interchangeable software components will be applied when available and economical.  Understanding of reuse will be discussed through patterns of conjunctive models(actually requiring different data models at different phases of a project) over time.  

There is a little bit of an agile flavor to solving information modeling and using conjunctive models with microservices and other integrations.

Thank you for your interest!

talk.title: Connected Teams, Connected Code, and the Connected Device: The Challenges of IoT Software Delivery
talk.description:
Developing software for the Internet of Things (IoT) comes with its own set of challenges.  Security, privacy, and unified standards are a few key issues.  In addition, each IoT product is comprised of (at least) 3 separate application components: the software embedded in the device, the backend service, and the mobile application for the end user’s controls. Each component is developed by a different team, using different technologies and practices, and deployed to a different stack/target – this makes the integration of these separate pipelines and the coordination of software updates for IoT more problematic.  How do you coordinate the diverse moving parts that must come together when developing your IoT product or updating each of its components?

In this session we’ll deep dive to some off the challenges and share tips and best practices used by IoT developers to streamline and accelerate their product design, development, test and manufacturing

talk.title: Continuously Cooking: Our Path to Continuous Delivery
talk.description:
Four years ago, The New York Times launched NYT Cooking, a cooking-specific vertical showcasing 165 years of New York Times Recipes. That Rails Monolith is still in use today, delivering recipes, guides, and how-to videos to millions of users a month. 

After three years of legacy and working on a deprecated infrastructure, we were lucky if we shipped once every few weeks, and even then often led to deployment failures. Since then we've gone from shipping our monolith with very our fingers crossed to shipping every day with confidence. We'll look at how we changed our development practices, improved what and how we test, and automated our workflows. We'll also examine some of the unique enterprise concerns around continuous delivery and how we adapted and evolved our process so our engineering team works in tandem with design, and product to ship as often as possible.

Intended Audience: Developers, DevOps people who are working on complicated/large scale applications and haven't been able to recognize the benefits of continuous delivery. Audience members should walk away with some actionable takeaways about how they can ship faster, and how they can sell shipping faster to the rest of their organization.
talk.abstract: It's easy to continuously deliver a relatively simple app with low traffic, but the stakes get a lot higher when you have millions of users and four years of legacy code. We'll talk about how NYT Cooking has gone from shipping stale code every few weeks to shipping fresh code everyday.

feedback.body:

talk.title: Continuously Validating Architectures in an Agile Centric World
talk.description:
Architecture validations are a key component of the software delivery life cycle, and they are essential to the successful implementation of modern IT systems. Architecture validations are becoming part of the processes used by IT groups to ensure software quality, and architecture review knowledge, reference materials and trained resources are becoming increasingly available. 
Continuous customer feedback is the best way to validate a software product and indirectly its architecture. Unfortunately, the system needs to be fully delivered in order to get that valuable feedback, and the cost of adjusting a software architecture after the system has been delivered is usually very high. The objective of the architecture validation techniques we describe in this presentation is to ensure that the future system meets its business objectives and quality attribute requirements, without slowing down the pace of delivery associated with Continuous Delivery.
Architecture validations deal with far more than just the technical issues, since business drivers are a key force in shaping an architecture. One of the key benefits of continuous architecture validations is that they periodically review the relations between business goals and architecture. As a result, they ensure that the system is designed, built and delivered in a way that provides the greatest benefit for its stakeholders.
This presentation describes how our approach can be leveraged to validate architectures in any type of project, and especially in a Continuous Delivery project.  First we define what we mean by Architecture Validation. Then we focus  on when to conduct Architecture Validations. We then discuss the roles required in an Architecture Validation. We finally detail how we can conduct architecture validations by describing some industry recognized techniques such as questionnaire-driven approaches, scenario-based approaches (including SEI's ATAM) and decision-based approaches (such as DCAM).
In order to illustrate the concepts introduced in this presentation, we will use a real-life example of Continuous Architecture Validation, showing how various approaches can be combined to effectively validate a project.
talk.notes:
Murat Erder (Deutsche Bank, London) will be a co-presenter. This presentation builds upon our presentation on Continuous Architecture at SATURN 2016, and is the result of significant research and practical and extensive experience in this field. Further details can be found in our "Continuous Architecture" book (Morgan Kaufman, Nov 2015), and especially in Chapter 6 of that book.
     
The tentative outline of the presentation would be as follows:

1. Introduction: Why do we need to continuously validate the architecture? ***Note: this section will introduce a case study which will be used throughout the presentation to illustrate the concepts 
 
2. What do we mean by ‘Architecture Validation’?***Note: this section will introduce the concept of Continuous Customer Feedback

3. When do we need to validate the architecture?

4. Who should validate?

5. How should we validate?

    a. Checklist-driven architecture validation

    b. Scenario-Based architecture validation

    c. Decision-Centric architecture validation

6. Summary & Recommendations

talk.title: Crowdsourcing Software Architecture – The Distributed Architect
talk.description:
Software Architects need to have it all: exceptional technological know-how, up-to-date programming experience, good people skills, ability to abstract, knowledge of important architectural styles and tactics, visionary leadership a.s.o. It has always been difficult to find all of these aspects in a single person. Modern development efforts set in highly dynamic, agile contexts and the emergence of polyglott technological environments make it even more challenging.

This talk introduces alternatives to the classic role of the software architect that showed a boost in delivery speed, overall product quality and organizational flexibility in real life projects of various domains: 

* The work without formal architect roles
* The idea of ‚marshals‘ for architectural concerns or important drivers and 
* A variant of the architecture owner role

All of them do well in an agile project setup and embody a distributed approach of handling architectural concerns. Important factors for choosing between these approaches are shown as well as the core concepts that make them effective even in more complex environments - including low viscosity design, architecture communities and tests of quality attributes.
talk.notes:
This talk can be held as a *short introduction* (30 mins) or as an *interactive tutorial* with one or two small exercises (90 mins), which ever fits the conferences schedule best.

All of the concepts I present are field-tested. I wrote a published book on agile software architecture in 2013 (for the renowned German publisher 'Carl Hanser') that also covered the agile view on the role of the software architect. Since 2008 I worked with companies like Lufthansa, Volkswagen, Postfinance, Hamburg Süd and others in agile transformation initiatives to establish these role ideas that are presented and illustrated in real-life examples.

talk.title: Customer Experience Architecture Hands On
talk.description:
Architecture is about the customer. If you create an architecture that doesn’t give value to the customer you are wasting your time. When I talk to customers I often hear horror stories about how their current systems were developed by someone in an ivory tower who didn’t understand them or their work. So how do you make sure that you are bringing value to the customer through your architecture? Use customer centric design processes often called Contextual Design or Design Thinking. These are fundamental parts of Lean and Agile and this session shows how to use them in architecture with hands on experience. In this highly interactive session participants redesign a system by interviewing a customer, creating a prototype, reviewing it with the group, and getting feedback on their design. Using the methods taught in this class you can create value for your customer through your architecture and become their hero, or at least not the person in the ivory tower who is ruining their life.

Objectives:
Participants will learn basic methods of contextual design and design thinking and how they apply to the architecture of a software system
Participants will learn customer interviewing techniques to gain knowledge of the customer's functional and non-functional requirements
Participants will learn creating prototypes of their architecture
Participants will learn how to give constructive feedback on an architecture
Participants will learn how to receive constructive feedback on an architecture
talk.notes:
My goal for this session is to help architects learn a customer centric design process. I learned this method from the "Deciding what to Design" course at Carnegie Mellon. The method is often called Contextual Design or Design Thinking. Its a fundamental part of Lean and Agile. I've rarely seen people show how these methodologies apply to architecture, so thats my goal for class.

I use this process in my own work at GE and previously at Verizon.  I lead the End to End Customer Experience efforts at Verizon and enabled our architects and software engineers to talk to customers. I gave a talk on that experience at a past SATURN that generated a lot of interest.

At GE I am using this method to design a new CI/CD system for our Industrial Internet of Things platform called Predix. Customers (anyone who gets value from the system you are creating) really appreciate working with me. I find out very surprising things by using this method and create much better systems.


A slightly modified version of this session has been given before at Code on The Beach and was well received.  I used the "App for adding contact to network" use case and it ended up being a common but complex enough task that the groups had plenty to design. The Code on the Beach session was 60 minutes long and I assigned roles to each team member. I didn’t have time to have feedback given to each group, but I think it is an effective way to leverage the knowledge in the room. I didn’t have time to fit in the last wrap up session either, which I think is critical for people to concrete the new information. I've added those two parts to this 90 minute session.

Objectives:
Participants will learn basic methods of contextual design and design thinking and how they apply to the architecture of a software system
Participants will learn customer interviewing techniques to gain knowledge of the customer's functional and non-functional requirements
Participants will learn creating prototypes of their architecture
Participants will learn how to give constructive feedback on an architecture
Participants will learn how to receive constructive feedback on an architecture


The participatory session will include the following:
15 minutes
Introduction to Customer Experience Design
Introduce the hands on Exercise: Design a new system for adding a contact to your network (Linkedin, google+ , etc.)
Divide session into groups of 4 or 5 people.

10 minutes
Activity 1: Determine what matters to the customer including their functional requirements and quality attributes by watching how they do the task in their natural environment and asking lots of “why’s”. I will ask each group to select someone in their group to be the "customer." Each group will watch their customer collect a business card from a person and add a contact to their network of choice.

25 minutes 
Activity 2: Design the system around the customer’s needs and document it in a prototype. The prototype should be as interactive as possible, not just a flow chart. Prototype should show the architecture elements. Because the “customer” is involved, the team should be constantly getting input from the customer on their on going design. They should also write down any assumptions they are making and any reasons they made design decisions. Finalize the prototype, the assumptions, design decisions, and what they learned from the process.

30 minutes 
Activity 3: Review the prototype with the group. Receive feedback on design. About 5 minutes each group.

5 minutes
Wrap up: Allow the small groups to meet one last time to discuss the feedback and make any changes to their design.

10 minutes
Final Group discussion: Discuss what they learned from the session. Find out what they learned from receiving and giving feedback.

talk.title: Deep Learning for Software Development
talk.description:
How can we apply machine learning (and visualization) to aid software development - specifically, software developers? While there is some work in this field, most of it has been devoted to metrics and estimates. Metrics are shadows of snowflakes, and thus not particularly informative when seeking to understand the purpose of a system or the behavior of a component. Improving estimation, while an interesting application and a laudable goal, likewise does not directly help developers create better software faster, nor manage the growing complexity of real-world systems. Can we apply ML in ways that help guide development, inform software archaeology, and reduce effort for developers? If so, can these things help us take on the systems-of-systems-of-systems of the future, where million-line code bases will be considered "quaint"?
After a brief survey of existing/past work in the area, we'll investigate the question of "what does software look like", examine the more interesting question of "what does good software look like", and use these insights to explore how we can enable developers to create and manage ever-larger software systems. No ML experience or math required. Lots of pretty pictures.
talk.notes: I've been research the applications of AI/ML/DL to software development, and experimenting with some unique approaches specifically intended to aid software developers, including the notion of 'semantic drift' (the 'distance' between classes and stories in semantic space) and topic-based clustering of software subsystems as a guide to refactoring. This talk avoids complex math, instead offering an intuition for how the main deep learning approaches work and why they work, includes a lot of pretty pictures, and outlines some future directions in software development principles and practices.

Thanks, I'm glad you like it! To your questions -

- I will show some of the 'semantic drift', clustering, and visualization work that I've been doing, which *should* be open-sourced by the time of the conference
- re 'design systems differently to take advantage of the work': yes and no :) Using latent semantic analysis on software systems works best when the software source code uses relevant words from the domain (otherwise the software just talks about itself, i.e. what it is doing in stead of why it is doing things); the more domain knowledge/model/words that are embedded in the code, the better. I am explicitly using domain-driven design structures (bounded contexts, context maps) married with semantic visualizations (topic maps derived from natural language processing word-vector vocabularies) as a yardstick for what "good" software looks like .
- yes. My work in this area started because of a real problem: trying to quickly understand a 2-million-line codebase. I have applied earlier versions of the tools to real-world projects (e.g. mapping 72,000 stories and 8,000 classes into the same semantic space), and continue to do so. However, the purpose of the talk is not to present something as 'solved', but to introduce developers and architects (et al) to the intriguing possibilities in this space (which are largely unexplored) and to encourage them to get involved.

Thanks!

talk.title: Designing with NoSQL Databases
talk.description:
Schema design for NoSQL databases requires a very different approach from relational databases. The NoSQL databases have very high emphasis on huge data volumes, high and scalable performance, high availability and agility. As a result, the traditional concepts such as normalization, foreign key, join, strong transaction support, etc are done away with. How does one then design schema for various business applications?

In this session, we'll look at the concepts and best practices of schema design for three prominent NoSQL databases (MongoDB, Cassandra and Neo4j), with the help of diverse use cases, such as content management, single view, product catalog, social networks, system logs, fraud detection. We'll also look at the features for data analytics in these platforms. We'll also briefly look at when, why, and how to use polyglot persistence.
talk.notes:
I have presented tutorials on NoSQL in two earlier SATURN conferences. While those were beginner-level sessions, this one is for intermediate-to-advanced level users. 

I use NoSQL databases extensively in my work (architecture, teaching, consulting), and I have been helping organizations, primarily in the banking and retail sectors, in using NoSQL solutions for their business applications.

talk.title: Developing a High Performance Security Focussed Agile Team
talk.description:
Quality (security included) does not have to be neglected when you're planning, building and running a high performance development team.

Kim will set the stage with how and why Agile Development Teams fail, explained with a familiar anecdote taken from his new book "Holistic Info-Sec for Web Developers", coupled with how you can change this.

Kim will then discuss and demo a set of light weight processes, practises and tools, that when combined have proven their value in:

1. Aiding high throughput (reducing time to market)
2. Significantly increasing quality (finding and removing bugs)
3. Without descoping

and all while reducing total project cost (fact).
If this sounds like breaking the laws of physics, or to good to be true, then this workshop is for you.

Kim will finish off with the habits of top developers and how we can make them part of our lives.
talk.notes:
This is a workshop requiring some attendee setup. Further details provided upon acceptance.

## Workings

### Provide brief context of the following to set the stage:

* [30,000' View](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#starting-with-the-30000-foot-view)
* [10,000' View](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#10000-foot-view-and-lower)

### Step (2)

Within every Sprint:

* Cheapest Place to Deal with Defects
* Establish Security Champion (must be within team, not external)
* Along with Test Conditions, create Evil Test Conditions -> basis for your "Security Focussed TDD" -> get these into your CI.

* Pair Programming (needs to become part of your culture)
* Code Review (incl automation)
* Linting, static and dynamic analysis
* Static Type Checking
* Consuming free and open source (don't need to stop doing this, address the issue, processes, practises and tooling to mitigate the issue)
* Security Regression Testing (hands on: [https://github.com/binarymist/NodeGoat/wiki/Security-Regression-Testing-with-Zap-API](https://github.com/binarymist/NodeGoat/wiki/Security-Regression-Testing-with-Zap-API)). ### Step (3) Forming Habits and Sharpening Skills

talk.title: DevOps, architecture, and security in a cloud
talk.description:
The success of your DevOps team depends on the collaboration between developers and cloud operations teams, maturity of development processes, security architecture, guiding software architecture principles, and the ability of the team to automate the delivery of software and infrastructure to customers. These factors along with the infrastructure management and integration challenges will be amplified in a cloud or hybrid environment. 

In this presentation, we will describe our DevOps implementation plan from inception to cost management; share our operation automation practices, security guidelines for cloud-based services as well as solutions integrated with on-premises systems; compare deployment automation options and high availability solutions based on 2 container management approaches. 

At the end we will review how security architecture principals can be applied to transient and permanent Big Data clusters ensuring data security and providing all players with appropriate level of access to PHI and PII data.
talk.notes:
Last year we worked out an all-encompassing plan for the DevOps initiative at UPMC Enterprises.  The materials of the ‘DevOps and Continuous Delivery: Practices, Architecture, and Security’ workshop presented at Saturn 2016 were used as a foundation for the plan. We have completed 2 phases of this effort addressing the security, continuous deployment/delivery, and integration requirements with minimal architectural debt. 
Due to the nature of the UPMCE structure our development environments have diverse infrastructure, development tools and platforms. They often combine building blocks that come from the AWS cloud as well as UPMC data centers. 
In this initiative we leveraged packages provided by several vendors (Amazon, Microsoft, Dell, and others) and open source software such as GitHub, Artifactory, Jenkins, Docker, Kubernetes, etc.

talk.title: Django & Twitter bootstrap in the workplace: build 'em fast and furious
talk.description:
The modern web developer has an unenviable task. Users have become familiar with popular web applications, and expect perfect uptime, bug-free experiences, simple and intuitive UI, and perfect security. Fortunately, the proliferation of high-quality frameworks for virtually *everything*—front-end, back-end, infrastructure—has made the job of the developer significantly easier. In this talk, I'll outline how my team used Django and Twitter Bootstrap to build a complete production reporting solution in under three months. These tools are incredibly powerful and can save you hundreds of hours of work.

We'll also discuss the trade-offs associated with training, and the impacts of choosing to train your team extensively or more sparsely on the tools you develop. The decision on training turns out to be more nuanced than you would expected.

Specifically, we'll discuss:

* Why Django—ORM, Security, Usability, Modularity
* Why Bootstrap—benefits of smooth, consistent, popular UI
* Django admin, CBVs—save time by getting to know the framework
* How to set up the team for success—necessary training, knowledge, etc.

We've had great success with these tools, and you can too!
talk.notes:
I've been writing django apps for a number of years now. I've managed three teams writing django applications, which gives me significant insight into what worked and what didn't, as well as what would have made it better; I would love to give that advice over to potential users. 

The talk should probably be given to either technical managers or developers who understand what a database is and know at least basics of coding.

This can be expanded into an interactive tutorial if necessary. We really can build a fully-functional website in 90 minutes, and people may be interested in trying.
talk.abstract: In this talk I'll be discussing how I used the django web framework, in conjunction with Twitter Bootstrap, to quickly build complex business applications—integrating with other data systems, authentication schemes, and more—to build user-friendly, maintainable, modular web applications.

talk.title: Efficient Debugging: Taking bisecting to the next level
talk.description: One of the most useful techniques for debugging is applying binary search to reduce the scope of the haystack and more easily find the needle. Using binary search you can cover over 1000 revisions in 10 steps. Modern version control systems like git and mercurial have this functionality built it as the bisect command. This talk gives an overview of the bisecting – finding the commit that introduced a defect or some other issue, and how to automate that process. Knowing the faulty commit is a good first step and sometimes sufficient in itself to solve the issue at hand. In practice however, the next steps can be more complicated. The rest of the talk will discuss techniques to go beyond the initial commit and take bisect to the next level, reducing the haystack to just a few straws.

talk.title: Enterprise IT - How to avoid mediocrity
talk.description:
Enterprise IT organizations attract and foster mediocrity. We argue that this is one of the fundamental reasons that keeps large enterprises from outperforming leaner organizations even though they have greater resources on hand.

This talk describes a fictional (albeit slightly inspired from reality) organization with huge cultural problems, and takes it to the extreme to illustrate how bad it can be and how it came to be this way.

Half of the time will be spent on describing the mess we're in and how we got there, the other half on possible ways we could have avoided this situation and possibly how we can get out of it in a culture that shuns firing people (which perhaps would have solved it in part).

Our premise is that a solid culture of learning and continuous improvement as well as a focus on good software architecture and practices could have prevented the mess, and that it is not to late to turn it around.

I promise an entertaining talk with a lot of humor (albeit of the dark kind), and possibly some insights that you can take back to your organization so that you don't end up in the same mess (if you aren't already there).

__Key takaways from this talk:__

* Architecture governance is key to combat technical debt
* Continuous focus on learning can help avoid the knowledge rot that often comes with a mediocre software group
* The Dreyfus model of skills acquisition and the Expert beginner.
* The common fallacy of tuning your corporate messages, governance, and technology choices for the mediocre or the underperforming, and thereby alienating your best performers.
talk.notes:
I have been spending much of my time in the resent years contemplating the challenges of a large organization, and I have recently gotten some insights that I would like to share with the SATURN audience. This is partly an experience report in the guise of humor and satire, basically an attempt at making light of a very serious and very real problem that I have experienced in our own organization.

I think there is a clear leadership story in this, and it pertains both to political leaders (management) and to technical leaders (software architects). A big part of the solution to the problem is the focus on good software practices and software architecture, which is where I see the main relevance for the SATURN audience.
talk.abstract: In our presentation "What happens when you break all the rules?" from a couple of years ago we stated that "large enterprises attract and cultivate mediocrity".  In this talk I will outline why this is the case, and suggest some measures that large organizations can take to avoid this phenomenon.

ratings.comments: In practice, the prevailing culture of mediocrity in enterprise IT (which in my experience is the norm) is one of the most formidable obstacles to the adoption of software architecture best practices on real projects. So this talk should be highly relevant to many SATURN attendees who might be struggling with such organizational/cultural challenges to help them understand what can potentially be done about it. My only reservation is that I suspect that most SATURN attendees will have roles that do not give them sufficient influence to change their organizations so this might not be actionable for them - might be more suitable for an audience of enterprise IT executives.
I really doubt how relevant this topic is going to be, considering this to be a conference for Architects. I could only see lot more reasons around the political climate of the organization.

The main takeaway in the context of Software Architecture is that stronger architecture governance and a continuous focus on learning can help prevent the accumulation of technical debt and knowledge rot that often comes with a mediocre software group.

I was inspired to propose this talk when I read a few articles by an author named Erik Dietrich, on something he calls the Expert Beginner and how certain individuals can cause group rot. It builds on the Dreyfus model of skills acquisition, of which I am a big fan.

The degree to which you restrict the options for your best people, and tune your corporate messages and technology choices for the mediocre or the underperforming is in my opinion a huge piece of the puzzle.

talk.title: "Failure" as Success: the Mindset, the Methods, and the Landmines
talk.description:
"Failing fast," "failing forward" and "Learning from failure" are all the rage in the software and tech industry right now.

The tech company "unicorns" seem to talk endlessly about how they reframe failure into success. And yet, many of us are still required to design and implement backup system capabilities, redundancies, and controls into our software and operations processes. And when those fail, we cringe at the conversation with management that will ensue.

So is all this talk of reframing "failure" as success within our organizations just that: talk? And what does that look like, anyway? We'll explore mindset, the history it's rooted in, as well as effective methods to move your organization toward it and some land mines to avoid along the way.

Specifically, we'll cover:

* The history of incident/accident modeling
* What safety science research has to do with IT and large-scale Internet operations
* Methods and strategies to facilitate your organization embracing and learning from failure
* Methods and strategies for conducting "blameless postmortems" after an operational incident
* Methods and strategies for introducing resilience engineering into organizational and technical design and operations.
* Various pitfalls organizations fall into when working on reframing failure
talk.notes:
This CFP is for a 90-minute tech talk.

Included in it is a review of techniques for "blameless postmortems," which is relevant in the context of software and Internet infrastructure operations; we also talk about the history of the safety sciences, and why they are more applicable to software and software architecture than one might think.

This talk also includes interactive audience exercises, where they get to interact with me and each other (though, not enough to make what SATURN defines a "participatory session")
talk.abstract: What do Internet operational incidents and software architecture have to do with aircraft carriers and chemical plants? What is this "blameless postmortem"-thing we keep hearing about? We explore the answers to these questions and more in this tutorial, which includes interactive exercises!

talk.title: Fixing Agile
talk.description:
Agile is broken.  The SEI should know this and lead a campaign to fix it.

Agilists believe that requirements “emerge” during iterative development.  They also believe that Big Requirements Up Front (BRUF) is an Agile anti-pattern.  While BRUF may be a poor strategy for gathering functional requirements, it is the best strategy for identifying quality goals.

Most functional requirements may eventually emerge because of clearer customer understanding.  Unfortunately, most quality goals will not and those that do are unlikely to emerge early.

Internal quality goals such as code understandability and testability, will never emerge from domain understanding.  Some high-profile external goals such as safety, security, and privacy may emerge, but at unpredictable times.  Others, such as ease of use, reliability, and responsiveness, will emerge if there are gross quality failures.  A focus on functionality will delay emergence of most quality goals.

In all cases, waiting for quality goal emergence is a poor idea and unnecessary.  Waiting results in the accumulation of sizable technical debt during early iterations.  Debt piles up because quality support functions, such as exception handlers, are missing everywhere.

Use of a comprehensive quality model enables quality goals to be identified early.  It also enables the early specification of both quality achievement and quality verification strategies.  Such a quality model is freely available at www.quality-aware.com/q-a-daves-stuff.php.  The steps to fix Agile and any other incremental development process can be found at www.quality-aware.com.

SEI publications state that understanding quality goals is an important prerequisite to good architectural decisions.  This suggests that most quality goals should be identified early.  This conflicts with stated Agile beliefs and current Agile practice.  The SEI has been silent on this conflict.  It is time to speak up and campaign for Quality-Aware Agile.

This presentation will
•	Explore current quality practices with attendees
•	Describe why Agile and every incremental development process is broken
•	Describe the added tasks of Quality-Aware development
•	Simulate a review and tailoring of the LiteRM quality model in an inspection overview format
•	Explore objections to using these proposals with attendees

talk.title: From REST to gRPC: An API Evolution Story
talk.description:
The APIs for components in fine grained service-oriented architectures strongly influence the eventual properties expressed in the system.  REST over HTTP is a popular choice for microservices APIs because it promotes openness, self-discovery, and simplicity.  One alternative to REST is [gRPC](http://www.grpc.io/), an implementation of Protobuf.  As an RPC-based API, gRPC inhibits openness and self-discovery but promotes performance and, depending on the implementation, can provide stronger compile-time (or at least call-time) guarantees which help developers avoid mistakes.

In this talk we will share our experiences migrating a REST-based microservice to gRPC, as well as lessons learned implementing gRPC APIs in a suite of backing microservices for the Watson Discovery Service.

By the end of this talk, attendees will know

* What gRPC is and how it is different from REST
* How to organize code to make API transitions easier
* The benefits of functional testing using Cucumber and tips for creating extensible gRPC API tests using Ruby
* How to implement common REST patterns in gRPC
* Common pitfalls for using gRPC in a microservices architecture and some solutions
talk.notes:
This talk will have the following tentative outline.

1. Set the stage / Context
     * What my team was building
     * Why switch to gRPC?
2. Our architecture evolution plan
     * Spike -- gRPC prototypes and plan our transition
     * Phase 1: Design gRPC API, influenced by the current REST API
     * Phase 2: REST + GRPC
     * Phase 3: Transition functional tests written in Cucumber with Ruby
     * Phase 4: Remove REST functionality
3. Spike
     * What is gRPC?
     * Example with code
     * Required tools
     * REST facade was a bust
4. Design gRPC API
     * Killing the hypermedia dream
     * REST is not RPC -- need to rethink resources and relationships
     * One request, one response
     * Everything is optional
     * Impossible to send bad values: choose types wisely
     * New constructs: repeated, streaming
     * Enum names
     * method and message names
5. REST + gRPC: run two servers side-by-side
    * Spring boot: seemed like a good idea at the time...
    * Layers worked extremely well
    * Health checks
6. Transition functional tests
    * We implement functional tests in Cucumber and Ruby, quick example and benefits
    * Transition plan allowed us to run tests against gRPC and REST endpoints, useful for incremental evolution
    * Tips for testing gRPC endpoints using Ruby (meta programming FTW!)
7. Remove REST Functionality
   * As simple as deleting the REST API package
   * We were able to fork the microservice into a REST facade.
8. Microservices governance concerns: and our solutions
   * Usability tests are important
   * Health checks
   * How will you discover APIs?
   * How will you manage and version `.proto` files?
   * Documenting APIs (REST has standards and more tools)
9. Conclusions
   * Classic example of an architecture evolution
   * Classic example of how clean abstractions in static structures (layers in this case) can make it trivial to deal with certain kinds of change
   * gRPC practice is still emerging, we covered several useful patterns and our approaches to some common problems.
talk.abstract: An existing REST-based microservice.  A new requirement to use gRPC.  A team under pressure to ship.  In this talk we will describe how we moved backing Watson Discovery microservices from REST to gRPC and the lessons we learned in the process.

talk.title: Functional programming invades architecture
talk.description:
A few decades ago when the first architecture books were being written, today's large-scale web systems were an oddity but now they are mainstream.  Our architecture pattern languages have changed as have our development, deployment, and operating procedures (DevOps).  

During this transition, one source of ideas has been the functional programming community.  Functional programming itself mostly happens within a module and indeed many software architects treat it as an implementation choice, unrelated to architecture.  But it turns out that some ideas from the FP community are helpful in architectural design: statelessness, immutability, and pure functions.  They underlie DevOps practices and are at the core of many distributed systems patterns at the core of our architectures.

## Why now?  
Functional programming ideas have been around for a long time but conditions are ripe.

1.  Coping strategy for complexity.  As systems get bigger but our brains stay the same size, we invent tech to cope.  Statelessness, immutability, and pure functions make it easier to reason about how a system behaves.
2.  Problems grew in size.  No single computer big enough to run a system.  FP ideas suited to parallelism and concurrency, so many smaller computers can solve big problems.
3.  We have more money than sense.  You can buy 100 cloud machines for less than one junior developer.  So why not do Continuous Integration with every source code commit?  Why not have a farm of servers running different versions of your code during deployments?  Why not burn RAM with immutable data structures?

## Functional ideas in modern architectures

1. Client-side.  Reactive patterns and frameworks.  Eg React, CycleJS, Elm.
2. Server-side.  So-called "serverless" pure functions.  REST architectural style.  Reactive services.  Event queues between services.
3. Persistence.  Append-only datastores.  Event sourcing & Command Query Response Segregation (CQRS).
4. Batch sequential & pipeline architectures:  Big data processing (Hadoop, Spark), Map-Reduce, Tensorflow and other machine learning graph-based functional transformation.
5. Devops infrastructure.  Version control everything (append-only).  So-called "immutable" and "idempotent" infrastructure set up by running code, not by Linux admins.

## Reactive programming
1. What is it?  Evolution of Observer pattern.  Observable = Observer pattern plus onError and onCompletion.  Hot and cold streams.
2. Use in UI architectures.  Strong competitor to Model-View-Controller and sibling patterns.  

## What you will learn in this talk
The amount of innovation and hype in web technologies is intense and often overwhelming.  If you haven't been staying current, this talk should give you a mental map to start your learning.  If you have stayed current, this talk should reveal how functional ideas weave throughout modern web architectures and perhaps provide insight into why they work.

The talk surveys how modern web systems are built with FP patterns.  It will dig into one client-side example and show how FP ideas can simplify this task.
talk.notes:
I propose this as a 30-minute tech talk.  I can scale the material to fit into 22 mins + questions.

I have plenty of material so I'm happy to do a 90-minute tech talk that digs into more details if you think the topic is sufficiently interesting.  90-minute slots are rare at SATURN, so I don't want to presume.  

If you think 90 minutes is better than 30, please consider this as a participatory session.  If the audience is really new to FP ideas, it can take time to see how to accomplish work using these patterns.  There is a great game we could play a few rounds of ([Cube Composer](http://david-peter.de/cube-composer)) to warm them up (go ahead and try it now).  Then we could design a system using event queues and discuss the quality attribute tradeoffs, or go further into the UI reactive example.
talk.abstract: Functional programming (FP) has invaded architectures. UIs are built with reactive patterns, servers are stateless, DBs are append-only, and big-data / machine learning patterns are function graphs.  This talk surveys FP architecture ideas, shows how they work, and why they are increasingly popular.

talk.title: Get management attention and transform your software: communicating architecture with value proposition design
talk.description: Getting the right attention and setting priorities for development projects can be hard, especially now that many product businesses try to adapt to a world of online services and new revenue targets. As an architect you understand the value of all the tasks on your backlog but limited budget and deadlines force you to prioritize. Inspired by the Strategyzer book, we have applied value proposition design to build transformation plans for some of ASSA ABLOY Scandinavia's software products. We profiled our customer's jobs and pains and try to match these to values enabled by our software products. Gaps between the stories of our customers and the functionality in our software help us to prioritize our backlog and build a plan that our sales and business colleagues understand.
talk.notes:
Strategyzer's business model canvas and value proposition design books gathered a large following in both start-ups and businesses reinventing themselves. The customer jobs concept core to their customer profile translates easily to Scrum and UX design stories. Customer pains and gains may translate to quality attributes or stories. Therefore, Strategyzer's tools should get a place in the architect's silver toolbox. The value proposition design book came out in 2014 and to the best of my knowledge it has had limited or only modest coverage at SATURN. The presentation will be based on my experience in applying the concepts on two software products at ASSA ABLOY Scandinavia. The material has not been presented before. 

Learning objectivesAfter the talk the audience should
-  have a basic understanding of the Strategyzer business model and customer value proposition canvases
- understand the relevance of Strategyzers tools to architecture practice for collecting business drivers and requirements
- be able to judge when to apply the Strategyzer tools

Rough outline
	- Problem statement: turning products into services
	- Introduction to Strategyzer business model canvas
	- Introduction to Strategyzer value proposition canvas and design method
	- Story of how we applied Strategyzer's value proposition design at ASSA ABLOY
	- Summary of lessons learned
talk.abstract: Overcome lengthy backlogs and tight development budgets. Win over your stakeholders by talking about how to deliver customer value quickly and iteratively. You'll learn how to use Strategyzer's value proposition design method to prioritize and communicate your development plan.

talk.title: git gone wild: how to recover from common git mistakes.
talk.description:
"Oh no! I just typed something into git and now my work is gone! Ahh!"

Don't panic. Contrary to popular belief, git is one of the most non-destructive version control systems available. When used right, git
never loses any data, and even when misused, chances are very high you can still recover.

This talk will present turn-by-turn directions on how to recover from a wide array of common git mistakes, and also provide some workflows
to minimize them.

Examples include, but are not limited to:
* Changing spelling errors in commit messages.
* Split commits into multiple commits with logical separation.
* Combining multiple commits into one.
* Resetting the base commit when you accidentally branch off of the wrong branch.
* Recovering from merge conflicts.

As well as more advanced topics, such as:
* Extracting parts (e.g. sub-directory) of a repository as a new repository.
* Merging multiple repositories into one while retaining version history.
* Removing confidential data accidentally committed.

talk.title: Global Applications & Architecture: What does it take to survive and thrive in the Global Jungle?
talk.description: When you can make a product successful across the “entire” globe you can provide incredible value to your business.  Although doing so is much much easier said than done.  Pitfalls and dangers exist at every turn in the Global Jungle (data sovereignty, currency, scale, right to left languages, legal risk, regulations, hackers, latency, global benchmarking/analytics… even natural disasters to name a few).  Most applications either barely limp through or don’t survive this unforgiving jungle.  Where do you start if you are building something from scratch?  What about if someone else built it but only built it thinking about their country (or for their limited users)?  In this session I will share my experience and equip you with the gear you need to survive the next time you enter the Global Jungle.  This will include over 20 architectural guidelines and considerations.  And maybe just maybe your next project can evolve to be a king in the jungle.
talk.notes:

WHAT MAKES ME THE BEST PERSON TO SPEAK ON THIS SUBJECT? I have lived and breathed this successfully for many years in a dynamic diverse large organization that rapidly develops large numbers of systems by numerous countries and development teams across the globe. I have had to take everything from a system done by a few inexperienced but resourceful business users that offered tremendous value to integrating large systems that were built in silos and now needed to work together and scale globally. When disruption and innovation are critical to your organizations success, you have to know how to balance all of the factors and make appropriate architecture decisions. feedback.body:
Hi Scott,

Thanks for submitting!  Reading your proposal this looks like a good survey of many topics with an emphasis on getting your software system "production ready."  As a topic I think this is probably appropriate as long as the context is well established.  Reading your proposal I'm not sure what you mean by "global jungle" and whether the systems I work on would apply or not.  What is the context for the systems you are discussing?  Keep in mind that the SATURN audience comes from a variety of experiences from from cloud-based web services to embedded spacecraft control systems and more.

I'm worried this is too much information to cover during a single session.  How deep are you planning to go into each of the topic areas?

This seems closely related to your experience (good!) but seems to stop short of sharing a generally applicable lesson.  Where did your checklist come from?  Do you have any thoughts or advice on how someone might tailor your list to better fit their "jungle"?

Regards,

Michael

I have tried to respond to each of your comments below:

Production ready/Context/Jungle?
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
I think characterizing it as emphasis of getting your system “production ready” is fair, although I think many systems consider themselves “production ready” and then fail in numerous ways when they try to grow/reach/impact the whole globe since they failed to consider key factors that could easily have been done ahead of time. This is not altogether different for how small startups often stumble or fail when they try to transition to the big leagues. As far as context goes, I think this applies to any web, desktop or mobile system (internal to an organization or used by the public) that is intended to be used by individuals in multiple countries across the globe. In particular if you are dealing with private or sensitive data. When I refer to the “global jungle” I am talking about the multitude of things that you often don’t think or worry about when you "first build" your solution for your "first user base", but can be a catastrophic problem when you try to transition to a new region or the globe (and forces you back to the drawing board or worse yet becomes a fatal flaw and threatens your overall business model). What do you feel is the best way to clarify the context due to its broad nature?

How Deep?
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
My goal in this session is not to attempt to make anyone an expert in any given area. Instead I want to give them an awakening so that they walk away with a new found appreciation that there are a bunch of other things they should spend some critical time on; since by spending it now it may very well either save their project from an unanticipated problem or differentiate them since their competitors failed to consider them. Think back to when you first heard the horror stories around security and that had a lasting impact on your belief that it is something that shouldn’t be ignored. I want to try to do the same for many other aspects that few people take seriously until it’s too late.

ADVICE/TAILORING?
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
This listing is what I have cultivated over the years and have used successfully to make both large and small systems “globally ready” and successful for the largest business unit of a 36.8 billion dollar company (for both internet and internal facing solutions). The last few parts 7, 8, 9 are where I would try to give them some structured advice on how to balance all of these considerations so that they can prioritize and mitigate the risks while still having rapid agility in "their jungle".
Thoughts? Appreciate the input btw!

I easily have enough material for 45-60 min right now without doing much work.  Been thinking about adding some more supporting details to extend it a bit plus leaving some time for Q&A.  Alternatively,  if you felt it would be more impactful and leave a more significant impression (shock n awe), I could keep the energy really high and go rapid fire and squeeze it down into 30.  Btw was my earlier message response sufficient to clarify the context questions you had before?  or should I go and modify the actual submission?  Thanks again for the input!

Thanks! I'm going to tag it as 30 or 90 and let the reviewers and tech committee decide which would fit best into the program. I'll also ping Michael to see if you've answered his questions sufficiently. Thanks again. :)

talk.title: Hemispheric Data Capsules for Non-intrusive Testing of Time-Triggered Real-Time Systems
talk.description:
Without doubt, modularization and modules that apply the information-hiding principle – as originally described in Parnas’ “On the Criteria” paper – sustainably help to develop and manage systems that are complex and flexible, yet comprehensible. Modules are design-time units with fixed domains and hidden design decisions. Modules particularly promote systematic correctness analyses. However, these beneficial properties disappear once the modules have been integrated into and deployed on target machines. For embedded systems that run within tight real-time constraints, modules may even hamper integration tests and fault analyses, due to the inaccessibility of modules' internals. Hence, for an HW/SW-integration platform of an X-by-wire eCar, we developed HDCs in order to non-intrusively trace and test the behavior of single and multiple modules (HDCs) integrated into one or more platform nodes.

HDCs transfer modules from design-time entities to runtime entities. HDCs can be tested in integrated systems during field operation, without code instrumentation and probing effects. For this purpose, the HDC runtime environment captures data structures that flow within and between HDCs for one macro cycle (e.g. lasting 10 ms) of the time-triggered system; each macro cycle anew. An HDC can access only internal and parametric data structures. The probe is the only HDC with full access to all data structures, including its own. Because they are half-open for the probe and half-closed for all other HDCs, we call these data capsules hemispheric.

In the presentation, we will first reveal requirements behind HDCs originating from an industry study on an HW/SW-integration platform providing safety services to a fail-operational eCar (www.projekt-race.de/en). We will then sketch tests that can be run for HDCs. This motivates the design and implementation of general HDCs and the probe, which we will describe afterwards. We will critically reflect on our experiences with HDCs during development, in the lab and in the field, and present further ideas related to HDCs and beneficial to a HDC system as a basis for discussion.
talk.abstract: A Hemispheric Data Capsule (HDC) is a runtime entity of a module with externalized data structures. One probe, itself a HDC, suffices to reliably test a self-contained, time-triggered real-time system in terms of dataflows within and between HDCs.

talk.title: High-Performance Multi-Threaded Immutable Store for C++
talk.description:
We present an architecture for collaboration between loosely-coupled actors that share their state using an immutable store and a publish-subscribe pattern. This is different from the well-known [Actor model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actor_model) (Implemented for C++ in [[1]](https://github.com/actor-framework) and [[2]](http://www.theron-library.com/index.php)), which uses private state and peer-to-peer messaging, and is closer in spirit to the [Flux application architecture](https://facebook.github.io/flux/docs/in-depth-overview.html#content) and [Redux](https://github.com/reactjs/redux), with its single dispatcher and its unidirectional data flow.

Our data model is suitable for high performance and complicated algorithmic flows, where multiple threads require access to shared objects. We have implemented it in C++, and used it successfully as the application framework for the [iTero intra-oral Scanner](http://www.itero.com/en) (See demos [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F_kYPyjUtbU) and [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tWuNPt33tho))

###Our architecture is based on the following principles:

1. All shared state is immutable and reference-counted
1. Each actor keeps a lightweight snapshot of the state, which consists of references to shared immutable objects
1. Actor snapshots are eventually consistent
1. Actors communicate using [Publish-Subscribe pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Publish%E2%80%93subscribe_pattern)
1. A single dispatch function is used for publishing both events and data updates
1. Persistence, replay, undo and application logging are handled by generic mechanisms
1. Objects can be marked as *invalidated*, allowing immediate, out-of-band signaling and cancellation of long-running computations
talk.notes:
##Primary track

I propose this talk for the track **"Development Tools, Frameworks, Techniques, and Patterns"**, because it introduces a new framework while referring to existing frameworks and patterns - the Actors model, Flux and Redux. The talk will be highly technical, with diagrams, code and a demonstration video. 

##Session type

This talk falls in the category of **"Technical Talks and Tutorials"** or **"Experience Report Presentation"** (30 minutes), because it is a highly technical presentation, based on my own experience and knowledge. The architecture framework I shall describe in the talk is one that I pioneered and developed, and it forms the basis for the application that drives the [iTero Element](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mdI5Pp2dVTg), a leading 3D intra-oral scanner for dentistry and orthodontics. The iTero software was developed under my technical leadership, as a chief architect and lead of the algorithms group. 


##About me

I have a Ph.D. in mathematics, and plenty of experience giving lectures. I have given 14 talks in international math conferences, including 2 Siggraph talks ([Siggraph 2006](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1141990), [Siggraph 1999](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=311541)). After 15 years of leading algorithms teams, I decided 4 years ago to become a software architect. Since then, I got a Software Architecture Professional Certification from SEI, and I have been constantly studying and teaching various domains of software engineering.

I am highly passionate about software architecture, and I love teaching software engineering and mentoring developers, as well as coding in multiple programming languages. See [My LinkedIn profile](https://www.linkedin.com/in/adi-levin-0a0a614).

I am also the submitter of a second talk, with the title **How to gain influence as a software architect**.

##Talk outline

 1. Present the challenge we faced
  - Show video and give a description of the [iTero intra-oral Scanner](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mdI5Pp2dVTg)
  - Explain the data model we use in earlier versions of iTero, and why it was inadequate for the new product
 1. Present the basics of the architecture
  - Define an "Actor"
  - Explain how actors access data and communicate via a dispatcher: All of the shared state is made of immutable data, and any modification is done by creating a new object, and broadcasting it
  - Explain the data model (each actor keeps a key-value dictionary, where the key-space is shared, and the values are pointers to reference-counted objects in the heap)
  - Explain about publish-subscribe and event handlers
 1. Explain how this architecture is different from the famous Actors Model
  - Provide links to existing implementations [1](https://github.com/actor-framework), [2](http://www.theron-library.com/index.php).
  - Explain how our model is based on shared state and publish-subscribe, while the Actors model is using private state and peer-to-peer messaging.
 1. Discuss more aspects of the architecture
  - Separation of concerns: Actors are responsible for message-passing and fetching data from the shared state, and they delegate computations to other objects that are tested in isolation
  - How an actor is created: the role of the dispatcher in making sure that a newly created actor has access to the most up-to-date state
  - A generic solution for persistence
  - Cancellation of long-running operations
  - Generic logging
  - A generic Record/Replay feature
 1. Discuss design trade-offs, and pros & cons of the architecture
  - Pros: Safe concurrency, and ease of implementing complex logic
  - Cons: Data model is flattened into a key-value dictionary, losing a natural hierarchy
 1. Shortly discuss a possible improvement of the data model
  - Use a persistent tree structure (as in [Redux](https://github.com/reactjs/redux)), instead of a flat key-value store, to restore the natural hierarchy of objects.
talk.abstract: We present a battle-proven architecture for lock-free concurrency control in multi-threaded C++ applications. Our method of managing shared state supports high performance data-driven and event-driven applications, with generic handling of persistence, record/replay and application logging.

talk.title: How the real-time communication between things can simplify our everyday life: make it more secure and economic.
talk.description:
An implicit goal of developing applications in IoT is to increase the quality of life, or the general well-being of individuals and society as a whole. The insights to be gained from data are endless. In light of this a new paradigm of the real-time communication between things has emerged, in which the quality of life of citizens in dense urban environments is increased through the security of using big data and cloud technology. Future cities are likely to feature thousands of strategically placed sensors that would record everything from air pressure and temperature to microbial content, and the data would be relayed instantly to the smart devices of actively participating citizens, who will make critical contributions to urban planning, reducing pollution, and making the best use of finite resources.
The proposed solution is the mobile connectivity that provides the network coverage wherever devices may roam. Secure cellular connection together with SIM cards and endpoints can be easily managed in real-time via the intuitive user-interface or directly from the customer’s software application via an easy-to-integrate API. Key features, development and implementation stages, as well as use cases will be discussed.  
The talk includes a lot of real working IoT use cases and their potential impact on our daily life. Their focus direct towards a more practical improvement of the quality of our life. Attendees will explore what is the potential impact of IoT, what real IoT use cases was implemented in Germany, how can we increase the quality of life with the IoT.
talk.notes: As I now reflect back on my working experience and lots of conferences, I can personally attest to the wide range of benefits that international communication provides for IT development nowadays and the insight brought about through cooperating with techs from all over the globe. My mission is to enable public to realize innovative fast secure development and implementation in the field of IoT.

talk.title: How to gain influence as a software architect
talk.description:
The best software architects combine strong creative and analytical skills, with the character traits of a leader. An architect needs to form collaborations with different teams, often with different styles of working and planning, in order to clarify the project's scope and requirements, and then design the architecture and implement it.

To achieve this, an architect needs to use all communication tools effectively: Meetings, architecture drawings, written documentation, design reviews, code reviews and informal conversations. In every opportunity, an architect should encourage the engagement of other stakeholders and must learn how to deal effectively with their concerns, and, in particular, how to deal with opposition and with conflict.

But communication techniques and technical excellence combined are not sufficient for sustainable effective leadership. To gain trust and credibility, one has to display consistent personal values and character ethics, and build relationships that are based on integrity and commitment.

In this talk, I will share with you my own experiences and lessons learned from years of working as a software architect in a global organization, and from studying dozens of the greatest writings from the field of business, leadership and communication.
