After 15 years of leading algorithms teams, I decided to become a software architect, 4 years ago. Since then, I got a Software Architecture Professional Certification from SEI, and I have been constantly studying and teaching various domains of software engineering. In addition, I have spent numerous hours studying the literature on leadership, personal growth, effective communication and influence, and I have successfully applied the techniques and principles to my work.

This will be my first talk in an international conference on software architecture. I created this talk after years of successful technical leadership in a global organization, gaining credibility with many people from remote locations and from various disciplines, in domains where I was often not an expert.

I am also the submitter of a second talk, with the title **High-Performance Multi-Threaded Immutable Store for C++**.

##Main theme

***Collaboration is power; Be genuinely interested in the concerns and challenges of others; Include them generously; Act with integrity***

All of the stories, insights, and tips that I share have the above theme in common. For example: When talking about effective online meetings, I share how useful it is to reflect people's concerns in writing and in real-time, as a way to verify that their concerns are understood correctly, and to give them the feeling that they have been heard; When naming components, I recommend to include others in choosing their names, as a way to encourage their collaboration; For dealing with opposition, I recommend to focus on a better understanding of the opposing party; On dealing with difficulties, I emphasize that this is the time to make extra efforts and display personal integrity, by being there for the developers, and by admitting and correcting one's own mistakes.

While those messages are all relevant to any leadership situation, I believe they are especially useful for software architects, whose effectiveness relies upon their ability to form a collaboration, often without the benefit of a position of authority.

##Talk outline

The talk will be filled with personal stories and examples from my own experience. The audience will be given a set of techniques that anyone can implement and principles that anyone can follow.

1. Challenges facing a software architect (based on my own experience):
  * Remote teams
  * Some teams not communicating well with one another
  * Teams not used to working with a designated software architect
  * Stakeholders from very different time zones
  * Different cultures of different teams; different levels of agility
  * Poorly documented legacy systems that need to evolve
  * Different opinions about whether to build or to buy
  * Unclear project scope
  * Unclear requirements
  * Stakeholders with prior commitments, who don’t have time to spend on your project
  * Tasks that require designing a kind of system that you have never designed before
1. How to recognize that you have influence?
  * Your designs come to life
  * People ask for your advice on various projects outside your area of responsibility
  * People want you to help them resolve disagreements
  * People tend to accept what you propose
  * People are copying your documentation style
  * People welcome your participation in meetings on any topic
1. Effective meetings (especially remote meetings)
  * Different kinds of meetings require smaller or larger groups
  * Declare the goal of a meeting
  * Publish agenda and slides up-front
  * Phrase questions to be answered during the meeting
  * Capture people's comments and opinions in writing and display in real-time them during the meeting
  * Finish in time, and share meeting notes with people
1. Effective architecture views to bring out the essence of an architecture
  * Depending on the audience, it is often better to present a simple and concise drawing, as opposed to complete sets of architecture views
  * Define names of components/modules/classes and their responsibilities. The other things follow from that. 
  * Naming something is an act of leadership. Declaring the name that someone else chose is even stronger. 
1. Use written documentation - this is especially important in a big and global organization
  * Writing is hard for people, so there’s an opportunity to stand out here
  * Make information accessible
  * Become the source of information by summarizing it better than others do
1. Encourage the engagement of others
  * Seek the subject matter experts and do 1:1 discussions with them
  * Look for opportunities to incorporate the ideas of others. If you accept someone’s idea, they will be more understanding next time you reject one of their ideas. 
  * Look for opportunities to show honest appreciation to other people’s contribution
1. Dealing with opposition, rejections and unknowns
  * If someone opposes an idea, ask questions about it - don’t just insist - regardless of how strongly you feel about your solution
  * Never get attached to a design. Recognize that there are multiple solutions and analyze both the benefits and the cost of any design decision
  * Seek first to understand, and only then to be understood 
  * When it is not clear how to make progress, phrase specific questions to be answered and ask for people's help
1. Build personal relationships with stakeholders
  * Get to know people on a personal level
  * Seek opportunities to show your appreciation
1. Be there for developers, after handing off the design to them
  * There will be unanswered questions and difficulties
  * Be there in weekly meetings and sprint planning
  * Notice the conversations between teams, and help where it's needed
1. References to literature
  * [5 levels of leadership by John C Maxwell](https://www.amazon.com/Levels-Leadership-Proven-Maximize-Potential/dp/B005SA65DI)
  * [The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People by Stephen R. Covey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_7_Habits_of_Highly_Effective_People)
  * [How to win friends and influence people by Dale Carnegie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_to_Win_Friends_and_Influence_People)
  * [Benjamin Franklin's autobiography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Autobiography_of_Benjamin_Franklin)
talk.abstract: The success of a software architect relies on his/her ability to influence development teams and decision makers and to gain trust with other stakeholders. In this talk you will learn the techniques, the mindset and the character traits that form the basis of effective technical leadership.

ratings.comments: Relevant topic. Enthusiastic speaker. What more to ask?

The topic seems good but the focus is too broad.  It's also not clear to me what the experience is.  Is this talk based on reading books and trying them or just reading books?

That said, I think this could still be a good talk for SATURN, unless there are better ones in this topic area.

Update: Based on the submitter's added details, clarified focus, and overwhelming enthusiasm I think this would be a great addition to the lineup.

feedback.body:
The talk outline seems long for the time available (30 minutes). If you need to shorten the presentation, I suggest dropping or shortening topics 1, 3, and 8. 

This sentence is not OK to me: "Depending on the audience, it is often better to present a simple and concise drawing, as opposed to complete sets of architecture views."  Here's how I think (based on "Documenting Software Architectures: Views and Beyond, Second Edition"): 
- a software architecture is described as a set of architecture views. There isn't a single diagram that shows everything.
- you should only create an architecture view if it has clear value to stakeholders (the audience for the software architecture).
- a given architecture view may consist of a simple and concise drawing. 

The following sentence is not clear to me: "Declaring the name that someone else chose is even stronger."

In the talk outline, item (4) recommends: "Define names of components/modules/classes and their responsibilities. The other things follow from that."
I think having expressive names for software elements is important, but that recommendation alone is not very helpful. In fact, item (4) is about effective architecture views and there are so many important recommendations under this topic, such as:
- Use a notation key in your diagrams (or indicate what standard notation you're using).
- Use different symbols for different types of elements and relations. 
- Use consistent symbology across diagrams. 
- If you're using a pattern in your design, name it. If the reader is familiar with the pattern, he/she will understand the design more easily.
- Use a template (standard organization) for your documentation. In particular, use the same template for all architecture views. (Subsections in a template may be N/A of course.)
- Keep the information up-to-date. If you can't update the documentation, discard, archive or mark it as out-of-date.
- Complement structural diagrams (e.g., UML class diagram) with behavior diagrams (e.g., UML sequence diagram).
- Record the rationale for important design decisions.
- Avoid ambiguity; write from the reader's point of view; review the documentation. 
These recommendations can be found in the book I mentioned above ("Documenting Software Architectures: Views and Beyond, Second Edition").

Typos:
- Notes: "trust and cooperation of *of* stakeholders"
- Notes: "Capture people’s comments *opinions* in writing "

Thanks for the thorough review, Paulo. I am going to use it to improve the presentation, and I am taking this opportunity to clarify my proposal.

My emphasis in this presentation will be on the human relations aspects and how they affect the level of influence of a software architect. 

Your comments about the architectural views are correct, and I should rephrase my intent: All of the architectural views are important for reasoning about a system's structure. I am not presenting a different theory of documenting software architecture, but I am commenting about the way in which I would present those architectural views to different stakeholders. In presentations, we often don't have time to go through all of the views; also, we may do it in a more constrained environment of online remote meetings, so we need to focus on the things that yield the most understanding and buy-in from the stakeholders. 

In this context, I claim that naming and stating the responsibilities of a component or a module, is of especially high value.  The list of responsibilities is a concise representation of the intent of the designer, which helps stakeholders review the architecture and ask good questions about it (e.g. "if this component is only responsible for X, then how come it depends on Y"?).

One way to make the most out of architectural discussions is to find opportunities where other people contribute. A very powerful application of this is when we name software elements. By asking someone else: "How would you name this component?" and accepting the name that they offer, we make them our partners in the project. Similarly, if someone proposes a modification and we accept it, we gain more of their their cooperation, and it will be wise to give credit to the contributors. 

My plan is to share other insights of this kind. This complements the more technical aspects of analysis, design and documentation, with wisdom that comes from the realm of leadership, effective communication and personal growth, and I have lots of relevant stories from my personal experience, which I think will be highly beneficial to the audience.

Indeed, I will need to shorten some of the topics - and I will shorten topics 1 & 3, as your proposed. As for topic #8, this is one I would like to emphasize, because my main point is how personal relationships make a difference.

With kind regards,

Adi.
Paulo - I also fixed the two typos you indicated. Thanks for this!

Hi Adi,

Thanks for your submission!  Overall I like the content and practical lessons in your outline, though I do agree with Paulo that it seems a bit long.  There is a lot of good lessons here!  But, focusing on 2-3 or so core lessons is about all the audience can take in 30 minutes.  You might be able to group or "chunk" your ideas in a different way to make them easier for the audience to digest.

What is the context of your experience?  Context is important for understanding how broadly applicable your lessons are.  For example, how big is the team?  What sorts of systems were you designing? Things like that.

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael. Thanks for the kind words and for your review.

Here is my context: I have been leading, and am still leading the technical design of a number of projects:

1. An application for a 3D intra-oral scanner (http://www.itero.com/en) - there were ~20 developers working on it, divided to 4 teams in two locations (Israel and Moscow). Made of C++, C#, high performance algorithms and 3D graphics, interacting with proprietary hardware and real-time components.

2. A HIPAA-compliant, scalable and highly available cloud-based storage system distributed in multiple data centers with integrations to ~10 applications. Involves ~6 development teams from 4 locations (East coast, West coast, Israel and Moscow), and other stakeholders from 3 more locations. Made of Java, NoSQL database, public cloud storage, REST API, caching layers, custom replication and workflow management, and a challenging data migration and transition strategy.

3. A scalable and highly available cloud-based architecture for enhancing web applications by server-side algorithms, with interactive-rate messaging between the web page and the dedicated server-side process. Involves 3 teams from 2 locations + stakeholders from 2 more locations. Made of Java, Websocket, REST, elastic cloud-based cluster, with fully automated deployments.

4. (Currently in early stages:) A cloud-based service for capturing, storing, displaying and manipulating doctor prescriptions. Emphasizes modifiability. Made of React, Java REST API, and document-oriented DB in the cloud.

I am also involved in multiple other projects related to identity management & authentication, cloud-based workflow management, storage, data analytics, cluster computations, and others.

----------

Regarding your main feedback: You're right - my presentation should focus on a few key messages. I think those will be:

1) Ways to get other people more engaged - this includes effective meetings, especially long-distance on-line conference calls, in which I have plenty of experience and success. For example, I want to demonstrate how I capture and display people's comments in real-time, and how satisfying this is to the participants: They know they are understood, and they know their opinion is heard, even when it is not accepted; Another example is getting people involved in the early stages of giving names to components.

2) Ways to deal with difficulty and opposition: being open to others' ideas; listening, and truly caring about the concerns of others; not being attached to a specific solution, and being ready to challenge your own ideas; This doesn't mean giving up on good design solutions: It means that you should be willing to explain both the advantages and the trade-offs in the design, not in order to defend it at all cost, but in order to truly search for the best solution, thereby laying the foundation for better collaboration in the future, regardless of whose opinion ends up being accepted.

3) Building long-term credibility. "They don't care how much you know until they know how much you care" - show commitment by being there when things are not clear, by allocating time for review and demo sessions; by providing specific feedback on detailed design decisions; by being there when teams disagree and need someone to resolve the dispute; by showing the appreciation and giving credit generously to others; And by admitting and correcting your design mistakes as soon as those come up.

I will also give useful references to literature, where people can learn more about influence & leadership.

----------

On a personal note: I attended Saturn 3 years ago. It was one of the best conferences I have ever attended, and I still remember some of the great presentations (Especially the keynotes by Dianne Marsh and Joe Justice; The course by Robert Wojcik; Scott Hanselman's great talk; And others...). I will be honored and deeply excited to be among this excellent group of speakers.

This talk is not finalized yet. I have so many stories and references to share. I am planning to use the reviewers' feedback, and to do my absolute best to make this a great presentation worthy of the high level of this conference.

talk.title: How to organize your code
talk.description: Most nontrivial software systems suffer from significant levels of technical and architectural debt. This leads to exponentially increasing cost of change, which is not sustainable for a longer period of time. The single best thing you can do to counter this problem is to give some love to your architecture by carefully managing and controlling the dependencies among the different elements and components of a software system. This session will first look at the major reasons why so many systems end up in an unmaintainable state and then show how to address the problem by using automated quality gates in combination with a domain-specific language that can be used to enforce an architectural blueprint over the lifetime of a software system.
talk.notes: 90 minutes
talk.abstract:
Why do so many software systems end up as the the dreaded big ball of mud?
This session will first analyze the major reasons and then show how to address the problem by defining an architectural blueprint for a system and then enforcing it over the lifetime of the system.
talk.talk_format: Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes - please specify the exact time in the Notes section)

ratings.comments: Unfortunately last year the SATURN audience perceived this discussion more focused on marketing and lacking objective technical evidence and discussion. Managing dependencies is definitely critical for overall architectural quality, but it for sure is not the single best thing to do. There is ample amount of evidence that as systems grow and as they start including hybrid frameworks and languages in fact dependencies do also increase. How would the lessons shared in this session allow the audience to make such trade offs, for example?
Relevant, but find it a bit hasty and unprepared for a 90 minutes. More on the negative side than the positive.

feedback.body: Alexander, thanks for contributing. Your topic is relevant, but I find it hard to grab the main takeaways from the text. It would also be beneficial if the structure of the talk was presented. 90 minutes is a looong time.

I gave this talk also on W-Jax conference in Munich and on Arch Conf in Clearwater, FL. In Munich it was 60 minutes, in Clearwater I had 3 hours and made a workshop out of it. I could integrate a practical exercise where people create an architectural model for a software of their choice, but he time for that would be very short. So I thought to go a little deeper with the talk.
 
The take aways would be
- Understand the importance of keeping an architectural blueprint for your code
- Negative impact of cyclic dependencies
- Learn to use a simple DSL to describe your architecture

talk.title: How to Perform a Rapid Assessment of any Software Architecture
talk.description: As a software architect for your organization, you may may be required to efficiently and effectively evaluate the validity, quality, health and/or maturity of a proposed, new or legacy software architecture. This presentation suggests a simple process you can follow to perform a rapid assessment of any software architecture effort regardless of its size, complexity or stage of development. The focus is on capturing the most critical aspects of the software architecture including: (a) Software Quality Attributes; (b) Key Architectural Decisions (including hardware platforms, software technology, development tools and reuse strategy); and (c) Architectural Design (primarily in the form of Unified Modeling Language or UML). Emphasis is placed on identifying and documenting references to existing artifacts. It generally requires an interview with the most knowledgeable software engineer on the proposal, development or maintenance team to identify the location of artifacts that are available and information that has never been documented. This is basically a two-day process. On the first day information is gathered and quickly recorded. On the second day, the information is analyzed, expert opinion(s) formulated, and a report is prepared and disseminated to all of the relevant Stakeholders. The process is a simple and straightforward mechanism for capturing software architecture and rapidly performing a valuable assessment during any time in the lifecycle of the product.
talk.notes:
This process is one that I developed at Raytheon for my own use as a software architect. It is my responsibility to periodically review proposed, new, and existing software architectures across the organization to maintain a consistent understanding of the validity, quality, health and maturity of our products. 

A questionnaire with the following outline is used to ensure all topics are considered in the process.

The applicable roles are as follows:
1. Software Architect performs the review, analysis and report
2. Software Technical Lead provides information
3. Software Architecture Review Board examines the report and recommends actions

It's a two-day event that requires about 24-32 hours of effort.

The process has been used for over a year on a half dozen projects to date.
It's so simple and affordable that there have been few challenges to hamper the process.

ratings.comments: I always like to see talks that provide experience with light, quick processes. I'm not sure the process here is useful to all audiences, but I sure want to hear about it.
Looks relevant to me and having been involved in such assessments myself I see the value in such process.

feedback.body:
Hi Tim,

This abstract sounds very interesting with some great potential, but I don't quite have enough information to assess it.  Would it be possible to add a few more details about the method in the notes section of the proposal?  A sample agenda would be helpful to understand what is involved.

Regards,

Michael

Tim -
This is an interesting and relevant topic. In addition to Michael's request for more details and an agenda, I had a couple of questions:
- will you be showing participant roles and responsibilities during the evaluation? can you provide enough detail so that if I wanted to use this method, I could estimate the cost of the evaluation?
- will you share any details about your experiences applying the method? how many times has it been used? what were the outcomes? what were the challenges?
- this method certainly appears to be more lightweight than the SEI ATAM. Over the years, there have been a number of lightweight evaluation methods presented at SATURN (Don O'Connell from Boeing and Jeremy Carriere from Yahoo/Intuit/Google come to mind). It was be a real contribution to the community if you could do a little bit of compare and contrast with other approaches to help attendees understand what is different here and why those differences are important (I think that this evolution of methods provides insight into where architects should focus their effort and attention).

Thank you.

...John.

Michael and John. I believe I have answered most of the concerns by adding additional information in the notes section. Although there is no comparative analysis here, there is sufficient detail now in the outline that a comparison could be supported. Thanks

Thank you for the submission. Light, quick processes like what you have proposed here, when effective, provide good value in industry, where resources and time are often heavily constrained. I appreciate people sharing experiences like this.

Not all organizations are strongly architecture-driven. Could you please explain, as part of the talk, any prerequisites or preconditions necessary for this process to work? For example, on the first day you are identifying and gathering artifacts. There are some assumptions therefore about the existence of certain artifacts.

What types of projects is this experience based on -- enterprise, web, application, embedded? What would it take to adapted it to other types of projects?
The projects reviewed were desktop, web and embedded systems.  The only change required to this process would be a tailoring of the checklist.
Thanks, Tim, for the additional information on the project types.

talk.title: Is Your Project in Trouble on System Performance?
talk.description: Performance is one of the critical architecture quality attributes. The performance Service Level Agreement (SLA) is a non-functional requirement that is used as an acceptance criteria for almost every project / system. Performance SLA also impacts the usability and user adoption rate after the system goes live. However, performance issues usually show up during the later phases of the project or during system implementation such as Load / Stress Test and / or User Acceptance Test (UAT) when data volume scales up. The probable cause is a lack of defined architecture quality attributes and vague non-functional requirements on performance at the early stage of the project such as architectural design. This presentation is to conceive and show how to salvage a troubled project with performance SLA issues that focuses on performance and storage trade-offs, and how Architecture Analysis Tradeoff Method (ATAM) is used to leverage the performance and storage trade-offs. I will discuss detailed issue resolution approaches to address performance concerns from end-to-end. I will also present examples of real-world implementation on performance and storage trade-offs to turn the project around in a very short period of time to meet performance SLA.
talk.notes:
This presentation is based on my real-world experiences in salvaging two multiple-million dollar projects in a very short period. Neither project conducted architecture quality attributes workshop (QAW). The performance issues were so severe that the projects were subject to be cancelled. The root of causes were extensive data aggregation with heavy computation and sorting on a low-end databases. One of the two projects simply tried to reuse a simple mobile application architecture with 2 search criteria and less than 100 thousand records on a PostgreSQL to a full blown application with 100 million records and over 20 search criteria. When performance issues appeared at UAT, $2 million dollars were already invested in the project. I will present a quick turnaround with tailored solutions ranging from increasing hardware / network capacity, database tuning / query optimization, API optimization, to the implementation of Solr or Elasticsearch to address the performance issue. The architectural dynamics, challenges, and impacts such as Solr indexing time impact to the existing ETL process and PaaS issues will also be presented. The practical knowledge of this presentation will benefit architects and business decision makers to understand the important of Architecture Quality Attributes and how to address performance issues with tailored solutions.  

I think the presentation belongs to Track 3: Other topics interest - Addressing quality attribute concerns, such as performance, availability, usability, security, and interoperability
talk.abstract: Why do so many projects have system performance issues at a later stage of implementation? Are projects with severe performance issues salvageable? I will present the issue resolution to these issues with real-world examples. The performance issue prevention practices will also be discussed.

ratings.comments: The abstract of this talk vaguely presents how critical it is to incorporate performance early on at an abstract level. ATAM is somewhat misused as ATAM can help you uncover the risks, but I am not clear what the author means it has helped him to manage trade offs? So solely based on the abstract I would recommend not to include this talk. However, the notes the author has included demonstrates there is some meat in this and I am willing to give it the benefit of the doubt.
Novelty and applicability outside of author's projects unclear.

feedback.body:
Summary:
The talk reminds the audience of the importance of designing for key quality attributes based on the author’s industry experience. The author applies accepted practices (for example, QAW, ATAM, UAT) during a turn-around of stranded projects. Finally, the talk would give practical guidance on the suitability of various database technologies for two projects the author worked on.

The good and to improve:
The author correctly points out the importance of designing for important quality attributes up-front and gives concrete examples of the potential cost of failing to do so. While a real world story could engage the audience, we should expect most SATURN attendees to already be aware of these risks.

Concrete guidance on dealing with performance issues could be of interest to the SATURN community. The proposal does not tell us how the ‘tailored solutions’ used may generalise to other software systems that the audience works on. I would like to see some hints about what classes of systems or problems could benefit from the solutions.

Idea:
A talk outline with rough timing could help the reviewers better judge the focus of the talk. Please also elaborate your idea on how your talk may impact the work/actions of others. You could also look at this blog for a checklist: https://insights.sei.cmu.edu/saturn/2016/11/seven-proposal-writing.html

Excellent feedback! The specific tailored solution I wanted to share is to move data aggregation and sorting from backed end database to Solr or Elasticsearch as an indexing service so that data aggregation and sorting can be indexed ahead of time and be access over http through query parameters. talk.title: It can be done! Growing an Architect's Community
talk.description:
Passionate individuals and businesses both try to create successful Communities of Practice (CoPs) for myriad reasons from honest desire to networking to a financially driven goal of sharpening worker skills. Why do some well-funded effort fail while rag-tag start-ups succeed? In this session, hear the story of my struggles and successes to grow a networked community of architects that now stretches across the globe. There is no single formula to creating a successful community. If you've got passion and take the time to really ask "Why?", your journey is starting off on the right foot! Choose vision driven techniques over old-school mechanics to jumpstart new groups or resurrect ailing ones. Attendees will talk away energized and ready to try a few of the techniques that worked including:
  • Sowing the seeds – Organic communities, whether jump started by a corporation or a hobbyist, tend to have the greatest growth and staying power. How and where to sow community seeds positions a community for possible success.
  • What are the success attributes of a boom? – How to define success and using qualitative and quantitative measures to detect a bust.
  • Value, Brand, and Localization – Communities thrive when there is ownership at all levels and pride. Understand how value definition impact a community’s charter and how building a brand provides community members with a sense of empowerment and worth.
  • Agile concepts for community leadership – Transparency, communication, and continual evaluation/reprioritization of next steps can situate community leaders to react nimbly to change and protect community health.
talk.notes:
When I joined Deloitte Consulting, there was a rag-tag group occasionally sending out an email newsletter that went straight into everyone's trash. I've taken that community of less that 40 to nearly 500 globally. While this could easily be a 30 minute session or longer, I want to energize my peers at SATURN to rethink how they are caring for and feeding their architects. I've won multiple national and global awards from Deloitte around my community building approaches. Interestingly, the journey includes needing to pivot and find ways to engage those smart millennials. Learning Outcomes: Participants will walk away energized with ideas for organizing and nurturing successful architecture communities:
  • Techniques to sowing organic growth
  • How to defining success attributes and what are associated measurement techniques
  • The impact of top-down support versus and bottom-up drive
  • Principles for defining value and brand for a community; understand the impact of localization on a community or chapter
  • Suggestions on applying agile techniques at the leadership level
talk.abstract: Growing a community is tougher than it looks!  There isn't a magic formula. There are tips and tricks from my journey building an international architect's community.  The big enabler? Asking "why" and staying true to that guiding principle.  Let's get the word out to the folks that care at SATURN!

talk.title: Keep CALM and Architect On:  An Architects Role in DevOps
talk.description:
The key concepts in DevOps are CALM:  Culture, Automation, Lean, and Measurement.  How does an architect support the transformation to DevOps in the 4 CALM areas?
Culture: Removing silos, reducing fear of making mistakes and encouraging learning and experimentation
Automation: Changing the architecture to support dynamic infrastructure, automated deployments and automated tests
Lean:  Structuring capabilities and features to deliver higher value in smaller batch sizes
Measurement:  Architecting to expose, aggregate and route the right data for monitoring, analysis and trending 

In this presentation, we'll talk about patterns, interactions and behavior that architects will want to consider to keep CALM in the face of DevOps.
talk.notes:
I.	How does one keep CALM?
II.	Architect’s Role in Culture change
   a.	Ever wonder what happens after you throw something “over the wall”?
   b.	Cross functional team support
III.	Architecture Patterns that support Automation
   a.	Deployment – Infrastructure as Code (IaC), Versioning configurations
   b.	Test – Using Code Seams, Test harnesses,  Change Impact Analysis
   c.	Dynamic Infrastructure – Infrastructure as a Service, Auto-scaling, Stateless SW 
IV.	Getting Lean
   a.	Requiring Experimentation (Working with leadership to build in HW resources and schedule)
V.	Architecture Patterns that support Measurement
   a.	Microservices with metrics support built-in and accessible with the endpoint
   b.	CI/CD Integrated Code Coverage
   c.	Measuring spikes to determine experimentation
VI.	Conclusion
talk.abstract: The key concepts in DevOps are CALM:  Culture, Automation, Lean, and Measurement.  How does an architect support the transformation to DevOps in the 4 CALM areas?  We'll talk about patterns, interactions and behavior that architects will want to consider to keep CALM in the face of DevOps.

talk.title: Location, Rewrite, Location: Tips and Tricks on Semantic URLs Architectures with nginx
talk.description:
The session will describe the best practices of semantic URL design and cache-friendly web architectures, based on the example of creating and rewriting a couple of web applications solely with the help of nginx.conf, the standard nginx configuration language.

On the example of [mdoc.su](http://mdoc.su/), we will show how it is possible to create a complete webapp entirely through nginx.conf from scratch; and on the example of [bxr.su](http://bxr.su/), we will show how to extensively modify the architecture of an existing legacy application to make it cache-friendly, and simultaneously improve the usability of the URL interface available to the user.

All of this will be accomplished through the internal directives of nginx and the machinery available through the standard rewrite module that is available and is enabled by default in all versions of nginx.

* Web applications are traditionally written in high-level programming languages such as Java, PHP, Python or Ruby.   But not [mdoc.su — a deterministic URL shortener for *BSD manual pages](http://mdoc.su/) — which stands apart from the established convention.   The whole [mdoc.su](http://mdoc.su/) web service is written in the standard and basic `nginx.conf` configuration language alone (with the help of regular expressions and dozens of `rewrite` and `location` directives), resulting in a high-performance semantic URL service without the help from any high-level programming languages like even Lua, Perl or JavaScript, being powered by [PCRE](http://ports.su/devel/pcre) and nginx.conf alone.

* On the example of [BXR.SU — Super User's BSD Cross Reference](http://BXR.SU/), we will also show how to `rewrite` the underlying architecture of Sun/Oracle OpenGrok, with the help of `nginx.conf`, without actually touching a line of the application itself. OpenGrok is written in Java, and is designed around the concept of cookies on every page (including the front page), and thus effectively cannot be cached or accelerated through a naive approach, due to the original architectural decisions that were made without considering their impact on the cacheability of the application. We will show how to successfully get rid of all the cookies with nginx, and how to greatly improve the usability and the URL interface of this Java application, all entirely through `nginx.conf`-fu.

No prior knowledge of nginx is required, but familiarity with HTTP is expected, and knowledge of regular expressions would come in handy, too.

Attendees will gain a clear understanding of how URL manipulation works within nginx, will surely be amused at the length to which the author went in creating the performant solutions, and will be able to design concise and deterministic URL shortening services using semantic URL schemes.
talk.notes: I'm affiliated with several BSD projects, being a member of the NetBSD Foundation (committer), and have already given this talk at several conferences and large crowds.
talk.abstract: Need to add support for semantic URLs to your website, but don't know where to start? Have to accelerate a legacy webapp, but have cookies coming in your way? Fear not, as we will show you the best practice on how to do both in nginx.conf, and without any non-default modules nor techniques.

I think to improve this abstract you should make it more clear _why_ someone would want to use nginx in these ways.  What are the specific use cases?  What are the pros and cons?  How do I know when this is something I should do?

Please consider revising your abstract to include some of these ideas and make a clearer connection with software architecture and design.

Good luck with the remainder of the review process!

Michael

talk.title: Making the switch to "serverless" full-stack development
talk.description:
"Serverless" is a newly-popular buzzword and as with many tech buzzwords, is a complete misnomer ("cloud", anyone?)  We're going to discuss what serverless really means, what the difference is between the various providers, why you would want to consider using a serverless architecture, and how you would go about implementing one.  We'll discuss greenfield development as well as a migration path for existing web applications.  Other interesting aspects covered will be how the development workflow will change and why, what testing will look like in a serverless world, and some pitfalls to avoid.

If you're interested in full-stack development, DevOps, containers, cutting operational costs, and/or just staying abreast with the latest application architecture approaches, this talk is for you.
talk.notes: I am an ex-IBMer who has been architecting and developing for nearly 20 years. I run a full-stack, custom software development shop in Los Angeles and Austin that's known for staying on the cutting-edge of tech.  I frequently speak at tech events (particularly JavaScript and Node.js focused events) and am passionate about designing great software.
talk.abstract: In the world of micro services and agile development, "serverless" architecture is now all the rage.  In this talk, you'll learn what it is, what it can do for you, why you would and wouldn't want to use it, and what you need to know to make the switch.  This will be a hands-on walk through.

feedback.body:
Hi David,

As this will be a hands on talk, what will participants need to bring with them to participate?  Also, what tech stack will you be using during the session?

I like that this is planned to be hands on and that you plan to discuss migration paths.  We've had a lot of proposals around server-less architecture and only a few will be accepted.

Surely server-less isn't for everyone?  In what situations would you recommend someone not adopt server-less architectures?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael!  I'll answer each question in turn below.

As this will be a hands on talk, what will participants need to bring with them to participate? 
-  Participants will need a laptop with git and node installed, an internet connection, and accounts on Amazon AWS and Github.  

Also, what tech stack will you be using during the session?
-  Full-stack Javascript: Angular.js on the front-end and Node.js on the back-end.  We'll use DynamoDB as the no-SQL database.  We'll also be discussing (and may use) some of the serverless frameworks like serverless.js or claudia.js.

I like that this is planned to be hands on and that you plan to discuss migration paths. We’ve had a lot of proposals around server-less architecture and only a few will be accepted.
-  Thank you!  We'll walk through taking an existing web application and refactoring routes over to a serverless architecture using AWS Lambda and AWS API Gateway.  Depending on time, we may get into testing, deployment, and other advanced topics.

In what situations would you recommend someone not adopt server-less architectures?
-  The biggest benefits for serverless are 1) decreased complexity for developers - abstracting away  server-level administration and devOps tasks and 2) lower costs for applications on VMs that spend time idling.  So, for those that have a mature, stable, and effective devOps infrastructure that already abstracts server complexity from developers and for those whose VMs don't have much idle computing time, transitioning to serverless probably isn't going to be cost/risk-effective.  

- There may be other reasons to not transition: risk aversion ("this is too new and unproven"), compliance ("we neither own the data center NOR manage any of the VM infrastructure??"), or simple mistrust ("how do I know it's going to scale when I really need it to?") It's important that application architects take into consideration their corporate policies, compliance and risk requirements, and organizational change tolerance when considering serverless.

talk.title: Measuring DevOps: the Key Metrics that Matter
talk.description:
How is your DevOps transformation coming along? 
How do you measure Agility? Reliability? Efficiency? Quality? Culture? Success?!
How do you optimize your software delivery processes?

You can’t improve what you cannot measure. But are you measuring the right things? Are you measuring too little (or too late), or are you drowning in disparate data points that make it hard for you to get to the bottom line: where should you be focusing on next as you optimize your process?

Having the right goals, asking the right questions and learning by doing are paramount to achieving success with DevOps. Having specific milestones and shared KPIs play a critical role in guiding your DevOps adoption and lead to continuous improvement - towards realizing true agility, improved quality, and faster time to market throughout your organization.

This session will walk you through a practical framework for implementing measurement and tracking of your DevOps efforts and software delivery performance that will provide you with data you can act on!

These KPIs include metrics related to your software delivery pipeline and technical progress, as well as cultural indicators and business impact. In addition, we will cover common use cases and real world examples for implementing these metrics to drive DevOps success, as well as best practices for how to address certain challenges and problematic areas along your process that these metrics may bring to light.

talk.title: Method for Business Function Allocation and Interface Definition in System-of-Systems Architecture .
talk.description:
System-of-Systems in Roche Diagnostics context
==============================================

Certain business processes in medical diagnostics areas involve many large scale systems (million connection points) distributed through Roche enterprise and customer clinical laboratories.  The involved systems fulfill valid purposes in their own right, can operate separately and are managed for their own purpose rather than the purposes of the whole. 

Making decisions of allocation of business functions to specific system components and definition of interfaces with significant consequences for architecture of such large and complex IT and software system-of-systems (SoS) requires data supporting decision criteria and accomodating fast evolution of the architecture in the agile organization.  

Roche Customized Method of Architecting SoS 
===========================================

For the architecting of the system-of-systems in Roche product context a customized method was defined based on the US Department of Defense Architecture Framework. 

This method involves 6 steps with start/finish criteria and deliverables for each:

1.  Business process Domain Analysis (identification of Business Drivers, Business Capabilities, Business Functions, Constraints, elaboration of User Stories and Workflows, definition of Quality Attributes).

2.  Integrated Dynamic Modeling (IDM) for multiple workflows within the business process.

3.  Derivation of Events, Activities and Resources for each workflow IDM.

4.  Alignment to elaborate Common Events, Common Activities and Common Resources for all modelled workflows.

5.  Identification of existing/overlapping/missing functionality (based on Activities) and data and processors (based on Resources) in involved systems. Preliminary allocation of the functions to the systems and verification of fulfillment of Business Criteria (based on Domain Analysis).

6.  Architecting of data, process, deployment, … models and preliminary design of interface between the involved systems.  Verification of Quality Attributes fulfillment.

Results of application of the method at Roche
=============================================

The customized method for the architecting of system-of-systems was applied to business processes related to Remote Solutions and IoT. It led to quick definition of models and derived data supporting the decision making in and allocation of business functions and resources  to existing and to be developed systems as well as identification of common resources and interfaces for their exchange.
talk.notes:
As author of this method and part of the team applying it in the real world large scale projects I can give the practitioners view and probably answer most of questions. 
My talk at the SATURN 2016 related to multiple ATAMs gave a short introduction to a small subset of the entire system.

talk.title: Microservices and Docker at Scale: the PB&J of Modern Application Delivery
talk.description:
Docker has matured, and is expanding from being predominantly used in the Build/Test stages to Production deployments. Similarly, microservices are expanding from being used mostly for green-field web services to being used in the enterprise - as organizations explore ways to decompose their monolith to support faster release cycles.

Running microservices-based applications in a containerized environment makes a lot of sense – both for Build and Test, as well as from a runtime perspective in Production.

Docker and Microservices are natural companions, forming the foundation for modern application delivery. However, managing microservices and large-scale Docker deployments pose unique challenges for enterprise IT.

This talk discusses the modern requirements for building, deploying and operating microservices on a large-scale Docker-ized infrastructure. It covers:

• Patterns for microservices-based architectures
• What makes Docker such a good fit for microservices
• How to operationalize Docker orchestration, auto-scaling and DR in large-scale Production environments – recommended typologies and patterns
• Best practices for Docker configuration and registry management to ensure consistency throughout the pipeline and stability in Production
• Tips for integrating containers into complex existing environments, supporting the hybrid state of microservices and monolithic applications
• Tips and tooling for monitoring and managing clusters of containers as a single distributed application
• Putting an end to Shadow-IT: how can IT enable Dev and Ops to use Docker for both microservices and traditional application releases - while ensuring visibility, security, governance and compliance
talk.notes: This talk was developed as a joint session with Electric Cloud CTO, Anders Wallgren: Anders Wallgren is chief technology officer at Electric Cloud. talk.title: Micro services architecture - lessons learned
talk.description:
I will be explaining the following success factors and considerations

Architecture:

•	When re-architecting a monolithic application, we achieved better success starting with the head (or customer facing functions) of the monolithic application. As we get deeper there will be more dependencies which it make it difficult to decompose the application.
•	It is important Identify the business capability and design the contract accordingly. It architecture should be aligned with product owner and clearly articulates the problem the specific micro service is solving.  
•	Use domain driven design as much as possible. It is important to define the domain and the bounded context for the micro service. This also helps to define the granularity of the micro service. If the service is too big, it replicates the monolithic. Maintainability and agility should be kept in mind while designing the micro service.
•	Architect should focus on the API contract, interplay of micro services, and ensuring the non-functional requirements are met. It is important for the architect to know where to stop in the design
•	What you design for real time may not work for batch

Devops :

•	Benefit of micro services is speed of development. Unless the code migration and deployment is automated, it is diffuclt to manage a micro services factory
•	Automate integration  testing and performance testing
•	With micro services, there will be frequent release. Hence, doing blue green deployment helps to minimize the down time
•	A cloud first approach works better for micro services
•	ATDD is a mandatory for micro services

Best practices and culture:
•	Encourage Small teams of 4-5. If a micro service takes more than 1-2 developer to understand fully, it is too big and will become unmanageable
•	Encourage pair programming
•	Encourage knowledge sharing. Leverage demos to ensure teams get the big picture. Otherwise, developers will know only their micro service and miss the big picture.
•	With small teams, teams slowly have to graduate to full stack teams that can do everything the micro service need

Communication to stake holders:

•	It is important to communicate to clients often and in detail. Write a blog and publish every detail
•	Version management in critical
•	Contract first design helps in better communication

Practical considerations

•	Level of granularity is very important.. be ready to redefine and re-architect often as you go along
•	It is impossible to have a separate support team to whom you hand off the micro sevices after they are built. The eco system gets more complex for some other team to own manage. integrate support into delivery teams
•	Alerting and monitoring is extremely important. Automate to the extent delivery teams spend less than 10% of their time on production support

talk.title: On the Architecture of a Fault-Tolerant CPS Enabling Reliable Statements on Real-Time Behavior from Tests
talk.description:
A dependable CPS correctly performs the functions for which it was conceived in its intended environment, without adverse effects. In particular, a dependable CPS responds correctly and timely even in situations where system parts have failed, either temporarily or permanently. This requirement also applies when tests check reliability, availability and performance properties of these systems in the field.

Tests of such systems pose various challenges, for example (1) stimulating selected system parts with correct data and with faulty data in rare and critical situations, (2) checking selected system parts at selected points in time, or during time intervals according to focused and measurable test goals, (3) differentiation of the system's treatment of permanent and temporary faults, and (4) absolute non-disturbance of the tested system's functionality or timing. The fourth challenge applies in particular to fault-injection tests that check system safety, or that operate near the border between the CPS and the physical process.

Meeting the challenges outlined above requires that the architecture of the system under evaluation be designed for testability. Starting from here, we first characterize the system we use as an example: an integration platform of an X-by-wire eCar (www.projekt-race.de/en). This motivates the need for reliable statements on the real-time behavior of the system from different tests, from which we derive testability requirements. Afterwards, we elaborate a series of design tactics that enable or improve the system’s testability, focusing on test probes. A test probe is a kind of Built-in Monitor (SEI: Testability tactic) or Maintenance Interface (R. Hanmer: Patterns for fault-tolerant systems) with particular demands in probe environments. When these demands are fulfilled, test probes can execute deterministic, efficient and reliable real-time tests, or act as safety monitors that observe and potentially intervene in a system.
talk.abstract: We rely on the functional safety of fault-tolerant, cyber-physical systems (CPS). Reliable statements from tests executed by test probes provide strong arguments in dependability cases. A test probe is built-into every HW/SW-component throughout its lifecycle, during development and operations.

talk.title: Planning for Huge Scale: Designing Your Pipelines for Scalability and Resiliency
talk.description:
Installing one CI server or configuring a deployment pipeline for a specific application might be easy enough. However, as enterprises look to scale their DevOps adoption and optimize their software delivery practices across the organization (to support additional teams, product lines, application releases, processes and infrastructure) -- software delivery pipeline(s) need to scale to support enterprise workloads.

For some enterprises, this means having a pipeline that can withstand the velocity and throughput of thousands of product releases, supporting tens of thousands of developers and distributed teams, hundreds of thousands of infrastructure nodes, multitudes of inter-dependent application components, or millions of builds and test-cases.

This scale poses unique challenges and implications for your pipeline design. This talk covers best practices for analyzing and (re)designing your software delivery pipeline – regardless of your chosen tool-set or technologies. Obtain tips and tools for ensuring your pipelines and DevOps infrastructure have the right architecture and feature-set to support your software production as it scales, while also ensuring manageability, governance, security, and compliance. 

Learn best practices for how to:

1) Plan for scale: how to project for the types of performance indicators/vectors you’d need to scale across.
2) How to design of your pipeline and supporting infrastructure and operations (such as data retention, artifact retrieval, monitoring, etc.).
3) Design your pipeline workflows and processes to allow reusability and standardization across the organization, while also enabling flexibility to support the needs of specific teams/apps.
4) Design your pipeline in a way that enables fast rollout- easy onboarding thousands of applications, across hundreds of teams
5) Incorporate security access controls, approval gates and compliance checks as part of your pipeline and have them standard across all releases
6) Ensure your architecture support HA, DR and business continuity.

talk.title: Pragmatic Architecture, Today.
talk.description:
Software development has evolved. Agile is now the de-facto standard. The role of an architect in an agile project is very different than the typical role in a more classic waterfall approach. Using an updated interpretation of ‘viewpoints and perspectives’, this talk will demonstrate how to make rapid, agile delivery sustainable in a constantly changing world. These viewpoints and perspectives will be linked to easy-to-produce models that can be used immediately in your projects. The talk will provide examples on how to determine which models are architecturally significant and worth the effort.

Developers have always been very important stakeholders of an architectural description. A good agile architect needs to strive for consensus and buy-in.
talk.notes:
Software architecture has a bad name. Developers often think that architects have no feeling with the actual application that they're building .. Sometimes they're right. But having no architecture is also a recipe for disaster.

I want to present a model (observe-orient-decide-act or OODA) with feedback loops that can lead to better quality software. Sharing ownership, making the architecture valuable for everyone is necessary to deliver successful software products. I've been using this approach for multiple projects and want to share how architecture, change and development methodologies go hand-in-hand.

Outline:
- What? (theoretical)
- Really? (practical, attractive example)
- Visual? (tips & tricks, focus on change)
- Why? (how much up-front, greenfield vs. existing)
- How? (OODA)
talk.abstract: Do we really need architecture in agile projects? What does an architect do? Can an architect help to make rapid, agile delivery sustainable in a constantly changing world?

talk.title: Predictive Business Analytics In the age of In Memory Computing
talk.description:
Disruptive Intelligence
====================
Never before in history, could we find a single largest contributor that has such a pervasive impact both on the bottom line as well as on customer relations.

Like beating a dead horse, traditional tactics to analytics has been delivering ample analysis only after the event. Business leaders who rely on information to make complex decisions in real time could not succeed as desired because technology could not cope up with their needs till today. This decades’ long wait has finally come to an end thanks to Artificial Intelligence and Real-time Analytics. Especially Real Time Analytics powered by In-Memory Computing (IMC) offers a way out from this rut. Further still, a truly disruptive hybrid model that shrewdly mixes both, “Relying on the past to predict the future” and “Real Time Analytics” is a fool proof approach for digital era analytics solutions. 
 
By embedding a select array of Artificial Intelligence techniques from cognitive research arena right into the core algorithms and using state of the art research projects such as SRI, CNTK and Google Tensor Flow, how we can leverage In Memory Computing to address predictive business analytics issues will be addressed in this session.

How to address complex and strategic decision needs in real time?
======================================================

By flexing and blending a variety of technologies within the realm of In Memory Computing, we can address all the three types of decisions, including Operational, Tactical and Strategic. While operational and tactical decisions tap into existing datamarts and datastores which house transactional, structured data, strategic decision making goes beyond the traditional stores and rely heavily on real time, unstructured data influx. 

Real time strategic decision making in digital era is impossible unless we shatter today’s speed and scale barriers. For speed, we can leverage In Memory Computing that tackles both latent and live streams of data. For planet scale, as the volume is huge and expected to grow exponentially, an on-demand, scalable infrastructure should be erected to contain the catastrophes. As strategic decisions need to factor in various parameters, an ensemble of machine-learning algorithms are employed to crunch data, to classify the outliers and recommend meaningful actions to deal with a specific problem at hand. An enormous number of simulations, trained models and tests are applied to the data which has been acquired and prepared before passed on to the intelligent analytics engine to arrive at precise real-time business decisions.

Applied IMC Use case - Customer Intimacy 
==================================

As the world is becoming more complex by the moment, strategic decision making in real time is also becoming extremely difficult and is compounded by the speed and scale with which information is generated and consumed. IMC furthers the decision-making process by employing cutting-edge tools, and conceiving and deploying disruptive models to address customer concerns. When it comes to meaningful engagement with customers, relying on heuristics and instinctive impulses for strategic making is no longer reliable, in today’s rapidly changing digital landscape.

This session is designed to shed some light on a practical use case on how to enhance customer intimacy using In-Memory Computing for business analytics.
talk.notes:
Functions and Algorithms
=====================

The driving force behind the use case is ‘enhancing customer experience’. With this is in mind, every customer interaction is funneled for use in a sentiment analysis. By examining every chat, email, tweet, voice transcript and logs, the attitudes, emotions, likes, preferences, habits behind the interactions are analysed using the following (indicative) machine and deep learning algorithms:
	
Naïve Bayes
Max ENT
SVM
CNN, HMM, GMM, 
DNN, RNN, LSTM

Architecture behind Real-Time In- Memory Analytics 
==========================================	
The following  architecture principles are applied in Predictive Real-Time Business Analytics :

* Real Time, In Memory Process.
* Loose coupling.
* Interoperability.
* Modularity.
* Scalability with built in CAPS.
* Cloud Centric.
* Mobile Centric.

By design Highly stable, open source products are plugged into the solution.

feedback.body:
Thank you for your submission. 

I believe authors and speakers should be careful with superlatives and absolutes. In your abstract, you say technology has miserably failed business leaders who wanted information to make complex decisions in real time. I'd rather say technology has often fallen short instead of failed miserably. Likewise, I think it's an overstatement to say that AI and real-time analytics are the single largest contributor to customer relations in history. What about the Internet? And another example of what sounds to me like an overstatement: "Real time strategic decision making in digital era is impossible unless we shatter today’s speed and scale barriers".

I have a few suggestions from the perspective of a conference participant looking at the conference program:

1) Description: The third paragraph under "Disruptive Intelligence" is one long sentence. Please try breaking it up. 

2) Description: The description uses too much space elaborating on the importance of real time strategic decision making, real time analytics and IMC. I think you should simplify the motivation part of the description and focus more on the technical presentation. And it turns out the technical part of the talk is a little vague. Are you going to talk about general solutions to real-time analytics and IMC? Or about a specific (of set of) solution/design/technology/framework/tool? Or is it a case study? 

3) Description: It's not clear what attendees will learn. For example, in the Notes you mention "Architecture behind Real-Time In-Memory Analytics". That would be an interesting topic for many attendees at SATURN, but is not mentioned in the talk Description (remember attendees see the Description, not the Notes).

In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

Hi Venkidapathy,

Thanks for your submission.  I think this seems like an interesting topic and one that many will find interesting.  There are a few things about the submitted abstract that I think can be improved.

* The overall tone seems overly enthusiastic for the solution you're proposing, almost to the point that it reads like a sales pitch.  Surely there are some negatives to what you're proposing?
* The topic is unclear and seems to touch on numerous areas.  Is this talk about AI? In memory data structures?  Streaming analytics?  Cloud? Mobile? Modular design?  I'm not seeing the theme or core lesson.  What will someone who attends your talk be able to do that they couldn't do before?
* This is a lot of material to cover in 15 minutes.  Perhaps you meant to assign this to a different time slot? There does seem to be a bug in papercall about this.

I think if you could clarify and tighten the abstract a bit this has potential to be a great topic.

Regards,

Michael

talk.title: Qualities are Very Complex
talk.description:
At the beginning of a software project, you should identify likely project risks.  Quality goals such as those for safety and security may be among them.  These goals must be defined, achieved, and verified.  We show that current quality models, such as ISO 25010, are simplistic and then describe a quality model of sufficient complexity.

We highlight the features of a quality knowledge base that outlines over 60 quality attributes, their support and conflict relationships, and their tactics for goal definition, achievement, and verification.  This knowledge base is freely available and enables you to identify your quality goals and strategies at the beginning of a project.  If you don’t use it, you may waste time and increase project risk.

feedback.body:
Hi David,

Thank-you for your submission.  I'm very interested in the topic of software quality, but I'm sorry to say that I'm finding your description a little perplexing.

The title is confusing me.  My initial thought was that you were saying "Software Quality Attributes Considered Harmful."

However, reading the introduction paragraph makes me think you are actually saying is "Poor Quality is Risky", or perhaps "A Little Quality Model is a Dangerous Thing" because you need one that is big enough to do the job properly.

By "essentially complex" do you mean "necessarily complex"?  i.e.  This is the level of complexity that is needed as a minimum, you cannot go any simpler than this?

When you say "essentially complex" do you actually mean that the model is complex by nature.  Complexity is often seen as a undesirable, , so complex nature could be a bad thing.

Reading on I see that you are presenting a quality knowledge base.  Am I right in thinking that this is the "Essentially complex quality model."  Since you are presenting it, then I assume it must be a good thing.  The title and introduction don't make this clear.

Also, you begin the second paragraph referring to "some at the SEI."  You then refer to "We".  Is the "We" the people at the SEI, or are you referring to the people ClearSpecs Enterprises? 

I hope you can understand my confusion and can help me clarify my understanding.

Regards, 


Ged

Sorry for the confusion. 

I changed the title to "Qualities are Very Complex" because that is my message.  I am using "essential complexity" as Fred Brooks does.  DNA, the London subway, and Einstein's theory of relativity are each more complex than a triangle or benzene molecule.  

"Essential complexity" is neither bad nor good.  It is a scalar characteristic, like weight.  By definition, if I build a model or solve a problem, the essential complexity of the thing being modeled or the problem being solved determines the essential complexity of an accurate model or an effective solution.

While understanding higher levels of essential complexity is very difficult, simplistic understanding can be dangerous.  If the software in a self-driving car is simplistic, people will die needlessly.  

“A Simplistic Quality Model is a Dangerous Thing” because you need one that is big enough to do the job properly. – Yes   Complexity is often seen as undesirable, [just like too much weight], so complex nature could be a bad thing – No [Human intelligence is not a bad thing, but unnecessary complexity is a bad thing.]  Reading on I see that you are presenting a quality knowledge base. Am I right in thinking that this is the “Essentially complex quality model.” – Yes

Here is the rewrite:  Qualities are Very Complex

At the beginning of a project, you should identify likely project risks.  Quality goals may be among them.  These goals must be defined, achieved, and verified.  We show that current quality models are simplistic and then describe a quality model of sufficient complexity.

We highlight the features of a quality knowledge base that outlines over 60 quality attributes, their support and conflict relationships, and their tactics for goal definition, achievement, and verification.  This knowledge base is freely available and enables you to identify your quality goals and strategies at the beginning of a project.  If you don’t use it, you may waste time and increase project risk.

Improvement suggestions much appreciated.  Thanks.

Thanks for the submission. I have a few suggestions from the perspective of a conference participant looking at the conference program:
1) The talk abstract sounds a little vague. Maybe you could say "software project" instead of just project. Maybe say "Quality goals, such as..."
2) It's not clear what you mean by quality models. Examples? 
3) Many software developers simply ignore quality attribute requirements. I think we need techniques that make specification, design, and validation of quality goals simple and practical. IMO, a "quality model of sufficient complexity" doesn't sound very enticing to the agile, framework-oriented developer of today. 

Also, in the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

Hi Paulo:

Great suggestions - see revision.  This talk is meant to fill the 15 min. slots that I thought were described in the CFP, even though this duration is not included in this online system.  I have a pdf of my 12 slides, but there is no provision for uploading files.  If you provide an email address, I will be happy to supply them.

You wrote: "Many software developers simply ignore quality attribute requirements. I think we need techniques that make specification, design, and validation of quality goals simple and practical. IMO, a “quality model of sufficient complexity” doesn’t sound very enticing to the agile, framework-oriented developer of today."

I agree with all but the word "simple".  The set of quality attributes and some individual attributes like safety and security are NOT simple (just like DNA).  Some attributes have entire books written about them. Their specification, design, and verification is NOT simple.

I understand that I am "selling" complexity (reality?), but the earth is not flat and orbits are not circular.  Simplistic models of quality attributes will never produce predictable quality.

As to enticing the Agile crowd, there are many problems.  I have written that "Agile is a Quality Antipattern" and "Fixing Agile".  "Pure" agile is simplistic.  It can work great as long as you ignore quality goals.  These goals don't fit the Agile paradigm because they should be identified and specified early and achieved and verified in every iteration.  In surveys of current Agile practice, over 50% of the responders don't following any coding standards.  These Agile projects build huge quality debt starting from the first increment.  True Agile believers are not my target audience,  Those using Agile, but concerned about quality, are.

talk.title: Quality Attribute Workshop in 2 hours
talk.description:
Our colleagues shared "Mini-QAW" presentation on SATURN-2016. I'd like to share not mini- , but nano-QAW approach best practices. 

Typical QAW is too massive for wide usage. That's why production reality of my global ISV company helped me to form shortened approach of QAW. I use this approach working with customers during architecture design, architecture assessment and other archtiectural activities. So, see how you can efficiently collect quality attributes and related metrics in, literally, couple of hours. I'll share best practices and real production case-study in this presentation.

So, efficiency comes from preliminary prepared list of quality attributes and related metrics. Being an expert you are doing your best guess to make initial draft cycle. And after that you are driving verification of your best guess vs opinion of representatives from customer. If you have representatives who are technical enough - they can provide you with good feed-back on your "guessed" attributes and improve your metrics. Business people are supposed to do final verification. 

So, if traditional approach based on "zero-cycle" with all stakeholders, this "nano" approach pushes from your expert opinion about what is important for customer in the future solution. And customer helps you to correct your guesses, customer representatives see the idea of QAW much faster in this case and you avoid draft steps and spending the time on them. 

At the same time, such approach is sensitive to the experience of the person who conducts nano-QAW and it is sensitive to competency of customer representatives.
talk.notes:
Presentation outlines:
1. Motivation for fast version of QAW
2. Nano-QAW approach in details
3. Nano-QAW approach best practices and artifacts
4. Production usage lessons learned
5. Case-study

What is the difference of nano-QAW from mini-QAW? See: 1. It is based on the experience of an Architect who prepares his/her best guesses about set of quality attributes and related metrics. 2. As the next step, Architect drives the workshop in a pretty dynamic manner, moving with technologists from customer side checking proposed list of attributes and metrics (by improving list of key attributes and getting threshold values from representatives' side). 3. Formed list of attributes is ranked by priority with technologists of customer. 4. Short meeting with business stakeholders is conducted in order to review formed list of attributes and metrics and checking priorities. 5. Work is done and list of attributes and related metrics is formed.

Such approach works extremely good when: 1. There are available technologists on customer side. 2. There are some ready-to-use expectations/understanding about future system performance/availability/etc on customer side.

See how you can efficiently collect quality attributes and related metrics in, literally, couple of hours. Best practices and real production case-study will be presented as well.

Sharing these kinds of stories was the reason SATURN was started in the first place.
The topic sounds interesting, but there isn't enough information in the submission to enable me to fully evaluate.
Nothing new under the sun here, but means to achieve better understanding of quality is important.

talk.title: Quality metrics: Nutritional Labels for Code
talk.description:
Software is an increasing part of our everyday lives. From the phones we carry, to the cars we drive, the thermostats that regulate our homes, even our lightbulbs - software is everywhere. But how much do we know about it? How secure is the banking app you use? What bugs might turn your home into a tropical paradise during your next winter trip? How convoluted is the code that runs your car? The last plane you took? The last traffic light you went through?

As consumers, we take nutrition labels on food for granted. A few simple, standard numbers let us make smart choices about the food we consume. Similarly, quality numbers should be routinely available for software, which is omnipresent and unavoidable in modern life. As consumers, we should have the data to make smart choices. After all, candy bars will only kill you slowly. Bad code could kill you very quickly.
talk.abstract: Nutrition labels give us the chance to make smart choices about the food we consume. But there's no data to help us make smart choices about the software we consume. Quality metrics are easy to collect and should be just as universally available as nutrition labels.
