talk.title: Rapid Specification of Quality Goals
talk.description:
Critical functional and quality goals and their conflicts must be understood in detail.  Unfortunately, many customers, managers, and developers have little understanding of how to specify, achieve, or verify quality goals.  Barry Boehm ranks qualities among his top 10 sources of serious project risk.

The SEI recommends that quality goals be identified in Quality Attribute Workshops (QAWs).  QAWs identify quality goals indirectly with scenarios and rely on “quality experts” to map scenarios onto quality goals.  Unfortunately, this indirect approach does not help customers make tradeoff decisions because of their poor understanding of quality relationships.  While scenarios are useful in describing some quality attributes, such as aspects of performance, they are not as useful for others, such as safety.

We propose an alternative approach based on the tailoring of a comprehensive quality attribute model to the needs of a project.  The model contains over 60 quality attributes.  Each attribute has over 30 characteristics including indicators and measures, supporting and conflicting qualities, threats and mitigations, and achievement and verification tactics.  The model also contains guidance on defining, achieving, and verifying quality goals.  The model is freely available at quality-aware.com.

This model distinguishes external qualities (visible to users e.g. reliability) from internal qualities (only visible to developers e.g. code readability).  We propose that goals for relevant external qualities be identified and defined in a tailoring workshop that includes most stakeholders.  Internal quality goals should be identified and defined in a meeting of technical management and senior developers.

This presentation will review the attributes model and simulate a tailoring workshop.
talk.abstract: Identification of quality goals is hindered by poor understanding of quality attributes.  We describe a specification strategy that relies on quality model tailoring.  This is compared to the development of scenarios in quality attribute workshops and the subsequent specification of quality goals.

talk.title: Refactoring with Cognitive Complexity, the new option for measuring understandability
talk.description:
For 40 years, Cyclomatic Complexity has been the de facto standard for measuring testability and maintainabiliy. While it's absolutely accurate for testability, the same can't be said for maintainability. Cognitive Complexity solves the problem, and returns "fair" relative measurements of control flow complexity. 

In this session, you'll learn what the Cognitive Complexity methodology is, and why you should add it to your metric suite, see how it applies to a number of code samples from open source projects on SonarQube.com, and learn how to use a method's Cognitive Complexity score as a guide to designing better code, and refactoring existing code to be simpler and, more maintainable.

Cognitive Complexity is already available as a new rule in some Sonar code analyzers, and should be available throughout the SonarQube ecosystem by the end of 2017.
talk.notes:
SonarSource (the company behind [SonarQube](http://sonarqube.org)) is introducing a new way of measuring complexity: [Cognitive Complexity](https://blog.sonarsource.com/cognitive-complexity-because-testability-understandability/), which gives a far more accurate measurement of the relative understandability of a method than Cyclomatic Complexity. 

I'll cover these topics:
* Cyclomatic Complexity: what it's good for and what's it's not, i.e. why a new standard/metric is needed
* Cognitive Complexity: motivations, specifics, benefits
* How to use Cognitive Complexity to guide refactoring. Hopefully I'll be able to use an IDE for this portion, but may have to fall back to slides, depending on what I can get the IDE to show.

I'll begin the presentation with slides and then hopefully switch to an IDE. Examples of code to be refactored will come from [sonarqube.com](https://sonarqube.com/issues#resolved=false|rules=squid%3AS3776).

I'm the best person to present this topic because, with the help and support of my SonarSource colleagues, I formulated Cognitive Complexity.
talk.abstract:
Cyclomatic Complexity measures testability, but not understandability. Cognitive Complexity fills the gap. 

You'll learn what the Cognitive Complexity methodology is, how it applies to a number of code samples, and how to use it as a guide to refactoring for simpler, more maintainable code.

ratings.comments: I support this one. I studied these old metrics long time ago, and as I understand it, cognitive complexity is at the heart of maintainability. Is the code readable and understandable.

Why yes:

- Author is indeed the #1 authority on the subject (cognitive complexity). She's also co-author of SonarQube in Action.

- Code quality has evolved since the 70s. "Clean code" (per Bob C. Martin teachings) is the norm today. This [blog post](https://blog.sonarsource.com/cognitive-complexity-because-testability-understandability/) makes a compelling case for cognitive complexity analysis. People at sonarsource apparently already vetted the idea. Presenting at SATURN and getting audience feedback would be mutually beneficial.

I'm familiar with cyclomatic complexity, we use sonarqube in our organization, and we follow the "automate all the things" motto. I was reading the description and wondering if cognitive complexity could be something analyzable by sonarqube (or other static code analysis tool). Every time someone opens your website on a mobile device and it’s not responsive, a toddler punches a kitten. Okay, not really, but you are providing the equivalent as your user experience. This hurts your SEO potential, and drives traffic away from your site.

Let’s get a quick rundown on what responsive web design actually means within the context of an ordinary website. This definition from Small Business Trends sums it up nicely:

Responsive Web design is an approach whereby a designer creates a Web page that “responds to” or resizes itself depending on the type of device it is being seen through. That could be an oversized desktop computer monitor, a laptop, a 10-inch tablet, a 7-inch tablet, or a 4-inch smartphone screen.

So with this in mind, let’s take a look at hypothetical look at a website on a few different devices.

Guys…. Stop thinking about coffee and let’s focus!

Maybe the importance of this isn’t really seeping in and maybe you’re more of a numbers person… Let’s try another route.

80% of internet users own a smartphone per Smart Insights. According to MicKinsey & Company, Google says 61% of users are unlikely to return to a mobile site they had trouble accessing and 40% visit a competitor’s site instead. A report by Wolfgang Jaegel found that 91% of mobile users say that access to content is very important.

In all seriousness, it is a big deal if your site does not work on mobile devices. Think about the kittens!! And if you’re thinking, “there aren’t THAT many devices out there,” and “it can’t be THAT hard to be responsive,” think about those kittens one final time.

I am sure there is a number out there on the internet waiting to be found telling us how many devices are web capable, and I am also sure it’s large. Keep in mind each device is designed differently, with different software requirements, default browsers, and different hardware specs. That means, as a developer, no matter what you’re building, you will likely find yourself daydreaming of how many kittens you’d prefer were being hit in the face, while you debug the fifth CSS error you encounter in Safari, that never existed in Chrome…Sorry, that got a bit personal.

As much as I would like to believe my iPhone is having an identity crisis, that’s not the actual case. There are standards out there for web design (sometimes sketchy ones), that are intended to help developers and browsers work within boundaries that help to simplify things. And I know what you’re thinking.

Thank you, mobile gods. We’re saved!

But we haven’t quite saved those kitties just yet.

You may still be thinking, “Why do you need to know all this?”

If you’re a business owner looking to increase your audience and you haven’t taken the responsive route, that should be the first thing on your to-do list. Online shopping is already a huge trend and still growing at this rate. If you’re trying to get your blog out there over a product, what better place for someone to read that than on their device while in the restroom? I mean really… we’ve all done it…

If you’re looking to get a better return on your investment (ROI), responsiveness is another way to do that. If you do not have a fully responsive design, you are throwing away potential page views and potential dollars pulled in from your mobile shoppers.

Now onto saving all those kittens!

If you’re not familiar with WordPress or its standards, there are these things called themes. I mean, to take it directly from the WordPress Codex:

A WordPress Theme is a collection of files that work together to produce a graphical interface with an underlying unifying design for a weblog. These files are called template files. A Theme modifies the way the site is displayed, without modifying the underlying software.

To put it simply, a theme is the look and feel of your site via functionality and design. It’s the idea that you can do anything with your content within the provided templates and have a consistent and clean flow.

Popular WordPress themes from Elegant Themes

There are thousands of themes out there to pick from. Whether you’re building a store front, a restaurant front and menu, a non-profit donation location, a blog, or an educational site, there is something out there for you. There are many free options, usually offered through the CMS that’s been installed, and paid options that tend to be found via outside sources.

So get to searching for the responsive theme that fits your needs, either through WordPress or through a seller like ThemeForest. The kittens will thank you.

If you go searching and nothing seems to catch your eye (insert joke about cats chasing the red dot of doom), there are always custom themes. This is the option for businesses that are looking for a specific look or functionality that they can’t find anywhere else. Being unique can be a huge benefit to a business with the right design and implementation. This is a costlier option but usually has a higher turn around on traffic and offers more options for Search Engine Optimization (SEO) and design tactics. Marketing teams usually love this option!

That’s it, that’s all you have to do.

As developers, we have to do much much MUCH more to make something like a custom theme or purchased theme modifications (maybe I’ll write about that in the future for all the dev-heads out there wanting to help the kitties), but as a website owner using WordPress, that’s all you have to do; find a theme that is responsive. You can look more into the Jetpack plugin to help with SEO as well (yet, again, maybe another post for the future).

So get out there and start saving those kittens! I believe you will make the right decision!

Also, if you need some emergency kittens, go here. You’re welcome.
talk.notes:
This talk is great for those who are just starting to learn CSS or web design, but still helpful to those who have been creating sites for a few years. I try to not push too far into the depth of CSS with this talk but push more the audience to think about their user and their experience across multiple devices. As someone who works first hand with clients at Grok Interactive, I hear about all the pain points of older sites making a move to mobile and how visitors are hard to bring in, due to a lack of intuitive design. 

I'm also the person who usually discovers the state of a site before Grok gets to work fixing sites. I usually find developers have a hard time with layout concepts, basic min/max widths and the prevention of overlapping or loss information when rendering on a mobile device. I have come to understand many of the methods that everyone should have learned in the beginning of the design or layout teachings. 

I like to keep my talks fun for the sake of remembering the content. Dry content is usually the first to be forgotten, no matter how useful it may have been.

Kim will then cover a set of light weight processes, practises and tools, that when combined have proven their value in:

1. Aiding high throughput (reducing time to market)
2. Significantly increasing quality (finding and removing bugs)
3. Without de-scoping  
  and all while reducing total project cost (fact).

If this sounds like breaking the laws of physics, or to good to be true, then this talk is for you.

Kim will finish off with the habits of top developers and how we can make them part of our lives.

* 10,000' View (what's in here)  
* Tooling (what's in here)

* Physical
* People

talk.title: Smelling out a bad security culture
talk.description:
Security challenges in the Age of Digitalization
=====================================

Some call it the fourth industrial revolution. Some call it the age of digitalization. No matter what you call it, we are harvesting more and more data about people and businesses. This data is then connected to other data and exposed as services which needs to be protected properly. As software architects, our primary security goal is to write secure software. Secure software has a technical aspect that is well covered (if not understood) in developer literature, but there is also a human and organizational aspect of security we as software architects must manage.  These aspects often go beyond the boundaries of the software development organization and are influenced by forces well beyond the company walls.

On the path to security there are a lot of trade-offs to be made, and some of these are made outside the IT organization. After working for more than 20 years in large organizations, I have found that there are certain signals that can be used to identify if you have a weak security culture. They do not necessarily identify security problems in themselves, but are indicators of topics that merit further investigation.

__In this talk I will cover topics such as:__

- Balancing prevention, detection and response
- Leadership
- Balancing Short term gains vs long time security impact
- Handling security incidents
- The importance of the curious mind
- Communicating security concerns beyond the IT organization
talk.notes:
__Note: This talk was originally submitted as a 30 minute talk. As I tried to edit some typos, the talk type options have changed to "non-SATURN"-variants. It is still intended as a 30 minute talk even if the submission shows something else.__

Security has been a long time interest and passion with me. Working for more than 20 years in the IT industry, I have seen security fail in the most spectacular ways. For the past year, the company I work for (Statoil, a global oil and gas company) has seen an increased focus on IT security in the wake of internal and external events. I have been part of a task force addressing some of these issues, and although the particulars are confidential, there are still general learning that can be made. Some of these learnings are technical, but a lot of them are organizational and are valid across organizations large and small. This talk will address the general learnings made as part of the task force, put into a context of more than 20 years experience as an industry practitioner.
talk.abstract: Security is many things. To developers it is mostly about developing secure code, but as architects it is so much more. In this talk I take a look at experiences from years of security observations that I find useful when identifying weak signals of a faulty security culture in a large organization.

ratings.comments: Really like the subject and the speaker seems to be knowledgeable. The plan for the talk is a bit vague though, as Paulo described well in his feedback to the speaker.

talk.title: Software Architecture as Systems Dissolve
talk.description:
The way we build systems is changing. From our history of monolithic systems, then distributed systems, to Internet connected systems, we are now entering the era of cloud-hosted, microservice based, pay-for-usage system development. What does the history of software architecture tell us about the challenges of this new environment? And how does our approach to software architecture need to evolve in order to meet them?

Software architecture has been a mainstream discipline since the 1990s and in that time has become a recognised, widely researched and often valued part of the software engineering process. However architecture approaches must reflect the technologies and priorities of the systems we are building and in this regard its future has never looked more uncertain or more exciting. 

From our history of monolithic compile time architecture, to many tiered distributed systems, to Internet connected services, we are now entering the era of cloud-hosted, microservice-based, pay-for-usage systems development. In this new world the boundaries of “my” system are no longer so clear and our systems are dissolving into complex webs of independently owned and evolved services, with nothing more in common than a shared credit card for billing and an agreement on the format of network requests. 

What can the history of software architecture tell us about the likely challenges in this environment? And how must it develop in order to meet them?
talk.notes:
The genesis of this session was an invited talk at OOP2016, exploring the history of software architecture, which I developed into this much more practical talk aimed at working architects, for GOTO London 2016, where it went down well.  Since then it has been presented at Endava a number of times and has always interested and engaged the audience.  It has not been presented in the USA yet.

The talk at present is 60 minutes and so I would suggest extending to 90 for SATURN with more detailed content and audience interaction.  However, if it fits better as a 30 minute talk, the essence of the message could be presented in that time (probably by dropping the detail on the historical context).
talk.abstract: We are rapidly moving from a capex oriented, static, monolithic version of computing to an opex, dynamic and fine grained component based world.  This talk explores the trend, what it means for software architects and how our practices need to change in response.

talk.title: SonarQube & SonarLint to spot bugs, code smells and vulnerabilities
talk.description: In this presentation, I'll start by demonstrating the kind of tricky bugs that can spotted in the IDE - while you type -  with SonarLint. Then the we'll look at an overview of the dataflow engine used in the SonarSource code analysers to find those bugs. And finally we'll see how to smoothly and cheaply integrate SonarQube in any software development lifecycle to track and manage quality issues in most of the popular languages:  Java, C#, JS, C++, COBOL, and so on.
talk.notes:
Time: 90 min

SonarLint and SonarQube are FLOSS projects.
talk.abstract: SonarLint can help you spot tricky bugs in the IDE as you type, and SonarQube can be easily integrated into any software development lifecycle to help you track quality issues in most popular languages.
talk.talk_format: Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes - please specify the exact time in the Notes section)

ratings.comments: While I use and appreciate the open source tools out there by SonarSource, this does read like a product pitch. I would have liked to see more thought on relevance to software architects.

As written the connection to architecture is not present. There is potential if there is discussion of the quality model, https://blog.sonarsource.com/bugs-and-vulnerabilities-are-1st-class-citizens-in-sonarqube-quality-model-along-with-code-smells/. The abstract and description would need to be revised if that is the presenters intent.

SonarQube is free and open source software that I see used and relevant for the analysis it does. It also provides a dashboard that some other analysis products plug into.

I am unable to find an architectural topic in the extremely short talk description, from SATURN 2017 call or other. Has the submitter copy-pasted a standard talk description from a developer event? 

I also see the risk that this will be a product pitch (or FLOSS pitch).

feedback.body: I'm familiar with SonarQube and how the reference in your title to bugs, code smells and vulnerabilities relates to quality attributes of reliability, maintainability, and security. Will you be covering how these flaws in code detected by SonarQube give insight into the design and/or architecture? If so (and I hope so!), the abstract and description need to be revised to make the relevance to architecture and the SATURN audience clear. If not, and this is focused on code/implementation quality for a developer event then the SATURN conference may not be the appropriate venue.

submissions.additional_info: Besides other venues, I spoke at SATURN several times in the past and I served as technical chair in 2016.

talk.title: Story of an Architect Growing up in Mr. Agile's Neighborhood
talk.description:
If the agile manifesto were a boy (born circa February 2001), he'd be a high school junior today getting ready for college. Based on the past 16 years of his life, there is no question about the genius of this kid; but not so much can be said about some of his entourage and followers. Missteps in his career threw shadows of doubt at times about his potential. However, as he matured and opened up to his parents’ wisdom and history, he’s been able to build a well-rounded experience that’s making him competitive for the next phase of his life.

I wrote my first full-fledge program (app in today’s term) in the Spring of 2001, around the same time Mr. Agile moved into my neighborhood. I didn’t get to know him until early 2004 when his entourage grew into a dedicated community of fans and followers. Back then, I had one trusted mentor and an old friend, Mr. Architecture. Becoming friends with Mr. Agile was new and exciting but brought about challenges to my relationship with my old friend. Therefore, my growing up as a software professional was about learning how I could maintain friendships with both, reconciling their differences, and being better at what I do because of it.  

In a nutshell, I grow up in this kid’s world. So what does that look like? 

In this DEV@SATURN talk, I’ll narrate the story about growing up as friends with Mr. Agile and Mr. Architecture. I don’t intend to indulge the “agile vs architecture” debate. On the contrary, I’ll annotate my story with examples from our journeys together, sharing experiences with some of Mr. Agile’s friends who advocated architecture sabotage, as well as situations where the outcomes were better because I had a foot in both camps and had won the internal struggle as to how to reconcile.

Come join me in this talk as I’m sure you’ll find resemblances to your own journey.
talk.notes:
BACKGROUND

This talk is inspired by Linda Northrop’s keynote last year when she gestured a fist-bump to her chest, a sign of regret, about the stall/damage agile movement did to the progress of architecture adoption. It made me reflect on how I’ve lived the collision of these two worlds. After discussing an early version of this draft with her, I thought I should write and share my experience in the form of a TED@SATURN talk. My starting thought was the fact that being close to agile movement from the beginning propelled my growth as a software professional, and my practice of software development have been better for it. However, this didn’t come without a struggle against an entourage littered with misunderstanding, incompetence, and lack of discipline. In retrospect, it’s clear that the agile pendulum swung too far in the beginning in a zeal to fix the ills of non-agile approaches. But like all physical pendulums, this one had to come back to equilibrium as agile original proponents began to realize that they overlooked some methodology-neutral principles key to developing quality software, including architectural principles. The punch line in this talk is that at this point agile is a reality. We are at a stage where we need to forgo the discussion about agile for agile sake OR architecture for architecture sake. We need to embrace this agile pendulum equilibrium in the making, and regain the role of those who think about appropriate practices, regardless of methodology, to build high quality software – Software that is fit for its intended use, where fitness has many dimensions beyond pure functionality. The vehicle for me to deliver this is through storytelling based on my own software journey. I'll try to dig out old pictures to put in the background to color the scene.

TALK STRUCTURE (DRAFT)

For the purposes of this segment of SATURN, my talk will feature a storyline emphasizing a classic story ingredients.

Origination

Year 2001. A dozen or so smart software engineers with stellar backgrounds are holding a collective grudge against waterfall-like processes, titles, and roles. Like many revolutions, a manifesto is crafted in a mysteriously remote venue, and subsequently shared with the world: Baby agile is born. At the same time, my induction into the world of software development occurs. A baby software developer is born. Scene – we live in the same neighborhood.

Building towards a crisis

Time is going to flyby quickly here.
  • In the ensuing 10 years, agile grows to garnish a movement that dominates all descending voices challenging it. It's cool; it’s the buzz; and it’s unstoppable.
  • I meet Mr. Agile for the first time. I’m fascinated (anecdotal incidence here). I go running to my old friend, Mr. Architecture. He’s less fascinated. (I get to know why later).
  • It turns out, architecture best practices (and a lot of common sense) are the colloquial baby that was thrown out with the bathwater. Architecture vs Agile debate begins to take place.
  • This makes me extremely uncomfortable. I like both my old friend and my new friend but how can I hang out with them both?
  • Affiliated agile revolutionaries weren't grounded as leaders in software engineering thereby resulting in a number of documented software atrocities. I witness some of these first hand in my neighborhood.
  • Moment of truth: Agile is widely accepted but now the epiphany – It isn't the silver bullet after all. Adults in the neighborhood have been saying so all along but the wave was too noisy.

Beginning of resolution

In the last five years, architectural thinking begins to permeate the conversation among agile leaders. Voices of reason, architecture and agile leaders together, have begun to take charge of the discourse again. They’re beginning to have serious conversations about the real software development challenges at hand with a common goal to build software in a way that is both flexible and sustainable. I’m getting really uncomfortable as I now get to go out and watch game with both my old and new friends. (Anecdotal incidence here). Great headways are achieved but also challenges remain with a hopeful future – that of bringing our community together and embracing each other’s strengths.

Ending Monolog

While I feel privileged to have grown up with this boy and met & learned from many of his clique, my work experiences led me to also work in many cases with the cronies. So I finish the story with a call to action for the audience to avoid the dichotomy of us versus them and to regain our role as the chaperons of quality as manifested in the end-products and artifacts regardless of the adopted software development methodology. Curtain close. Audience cheers. Lights off. :)
talk.abstract: If Agile Manifesto were a boy, he'd be a high school junior today. Based on the past 16 years of his life, there's no question about his genius. However, not the same can be said about some of his entourage and followers. Come listen to stories about growing up in this kid’s neighborhood.

ratings.comments: Promising entertaining talk of agile and architecture growing up.

feedback.body:
Summary:
The author proposes to use storytelling to describe the rise, inflated expectations, and eventual maturing of the agile movement in the light of architecture practice.

The good and to improve:
I like the idea of a life story as a way to narrate the evolution of agile and architecture. I do wonder, why agile is a boy, not a girl?

The story structure is well thought out and the proposal gives sufficient detail to believe it will be an entertaining talk. Unclear is what the lessons or take aways will be. The proposal mentions the punch line “at this point agile is a reality”. Please ensure that “beginning of resolution” part of the talk will enlighten many on how to be successful at both agile and architecture.

Idea:
I fully support visual storytelling as a presentation form. If the author is not yet familiar, I recommend looking at some of Garr Reynolds talks and ideas. I can also recommend pixabay.com as a source of CC images.

Thanks, Thijmen! Since it's a childhood personal story, I thought growing up with two other boys, Mr. Agile and Mr. Architecture, is more fitting. 

Listened to one of Garr's TEDTalks before about storytelling; thanks for the suggestion. I'm thinking about seeking help from my colleague sketch artists to see if they can help me sketch out some content for background slides. Will see if I can pull this off... Otherwise, I plan to use pictures/photos.

talk.title: Taking a byte of Java Bytecode
talk.description: Java, Scala, Groovy, Kotlin, JRuby, Jython, Clojure. What do all these languages have in common? They are all powered by Java Bytecode. With the current ecosystem of languages running on the JVM, it is becoming important to learn more about the least common denominator. This talk gives an introduction to Java Bytecode, with practical examples and an implementation of a very simple JVM based language.
talk.notes: 90 minutes

feedback.body:
Thank you for your submission.

1. SATURN is focused on software architecture. Java bytecode seems "low level" for people interested in architecture. So, I'd suggest drawing a connection between Java bytecode and quality attributes and design decisions. 

2. What are the learning outcomes? What types of software professionals would most benefit from learning JVM bytecode? 

3. In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

(The CFP is closed but authors can still *edit* their submissions.)

I second Paulo's remarks. Magnus, please take the opportunity to improve your proposal! This could be an awesome talk for the tech nerds in the audience, but we have to understand what you plan to teach us.

profile.name: Shai Yallin
profile.bio: I'm an engineering manager at the Wix Backend Group, where I have introduced and spread the use of the Scala programming language. talk.title: TDD: Cultivating a Beginner's Mind
talk.description:
Even though Agile has been around for more than 15 years, many software organizations still practice Big Design Up Front. A lot of focus is put on the *initial development* aspect, before the first delivery, and little attention is given to the *maintenance phase* of the software system. With more and more organizations shifting to SaaS models, creating long-lived Internet systems that aren’t forgiving to downtimes or cumbersome data migrations, maintenance becomes much more important and critical to the overall design of the system than the initial development.

Agile offers a different, *Emergent* method to design software, with small iterations that, when combined with continuous delivery and learning, results in a design that’s much more adaptive to changing requirements. Taken to the extreme, we shorten the initial development phase to a minimum and focus mostly on iterative maintenance steps. 

However, the conditions required to facilitate Emergent Design require that the development team refrain from over-engineering and YAGNI violations - two problems that are prevalent in the software industry, especially with less-experienced engineers. Outside-In Development is a methodology that helps us focus on the Semantics rather the Mechanics of our software, protect us from YAGNI violations, and thus facilitate Emergent Design. Practicing TDD helps us implement this methodology in the scope of a commercial software project, by helping us cultivate a Beginner’s Mind towards software design.
talk.notes:
I will start by describing the gap between how engineers usually view software design and how Internet-scale systems actually evolves. I will then make the point that software isn’t like bridges, cars or other “classical” engineering projects. I will use the biological analogy, talking about software as a garden and how we always build on existing system state, and how software engineering is an ongoing, evolving effort. I will claim that a paradigm shift is needed towards wide adoption of Emergent Design.

Next, I will explain why traditional software engineering training is deleterious to this paradigm shift, with people learning to think about static, rather than evolving, software design, and are taught more about the mechanics of software (design patterns, technology) and less about the semantics (creating the right abstractions). I will discuss Outside-In Development and explain how it helps stick to the YAGNI principle, and how this facilitates Emergent Design. I will explain that it’s hard to adopt outside-in due to the way engineers are trained and how cultivating a Beginner’s Mind helps us put aside these problems and achieve outside-in.

Finally, I will explain how practicing TDD helps us cultivate the Beginner’s Mind and facilitate outside-in, with test-first serving as the outside user of a system or subsystem, and how the Refactoring phase of TDD helps design emerge.

### Presentation History:
Initially developed in 2014 as an internal Wix.com tech talk. Presented in:
Reversim Summit Tel Aviv 2015 
Voxxed Days Vilnius 2015 
Clean Code Days Munich 2015 
Continuous Lifecycle London 2016
XP2016 Edinburgh
Testcon Vilnius 2016
talk.abstract: Everyone’s talking about Agile, but most of us actually do Scrumfall. The rise of SaaS systems calls for a paradigm shift in software design. In this talk, I will discuss Emergent Design using TDD as a way around the inherent problems in Big Design Up Front and our education as software engineers.
talk.talk_format: Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes - please specify the exact time in the Notes section)

ratings.comments:
TDD has been established for a while now, I am not sure what new angle this talk would provide. I would like to see a balance between up-front design and TDD at an architecture conference.

Update: after reading the conversation with the speaker, I understand more and agree with Michael's sentiment. However, I find it disturbing that the speaker uses many terms/acronyms without defining them, also in the 'public' abstract.

Generally I like everything the speaker proposes but the topic seems extremely introductory.  It does not seem like there is anything new here or much that directly relates to software architecture topics.

Update: Given some of the discussions with Shai and the emphasis on design over mechanics I think his has potential to be a good session.

feedback.body:
Hi Shai,

I am a huge supporter of TDD and 100% agree with most everything in your abstract.  With that said, this topic has been around for a while.  What is new your talk compared to the common or prevailing lessons for using and benefits of TDD?  How will you relate TDD directly to software architecture topics (opposed to typical design or programming topics)?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael,

Thanks for the feedback. First and foremost, I can't actually promise that anything I say is new to the audience of SATURN, although I have delivered this talk in earlier formats at various European conferences, including XP2016 in Edinburgh earlier this year, and got positive feedback.

One major difference is that I'm talking about Test-Driven *Design* rather than Test-Driven Development. Many talks and books deal with Test-Driven Development, focusing on the "how"s rather than the "why"s - how to write unit tests, for instance, rather than "what's in it for me". My talk, and to a greater extent my epiphany, has to do with our fallacies as software engineers, their origins, and how TDD, by helping us cultivate a beginner's mind, can aid in getting rid or taming these fallacies, which include YAGNI violation, over-engineering, pattern obsession and so on. 

While this talk doesn't relate to software architecture in the common sense (topology, microservices, databasesm etc), it does deal with how adhering to TDD as a methodology is beneficial for software organizations that develop web-scale, long-lived Internet systems, as was our experience at Wix.com.

Shai, Thanks for the update!  Thanks for explaining the nuance -- design over mechanics. TDD is a great way to dive into these topics and I think this would be the right approach for this conference.  Good luck in the review process!

Hi Shai,

I'm particularly interested in your emphasis on addressing the maintenance phase.  Is the approach you are describing something that can be applied to a system that is already in the maintenance phase?

In his book "Working Effectively with Legacy Code" Michael Feather describes a number of techniques for introducing tests to legacy code.  Are you talking about a similar approach here?

Or are you talking about anticipating the needs of maintenance during the initial phases?

Hi Ged,

I'm talking about anticipating the needs of maintenance during the initial phase. Furthermore, I'm claiming that the initial phase in itself is getting way too much attention, whereas the important bit of software development lies in maintenance. Taken to the extreme, an example would be deploying an empty application to production, then starting to add features to it ('Walking Skeleton' in GOOS lingua).

Shai
Hi Shai, from the YouTube video, it looks like a 30-minute talk. Is that correct? Thanks.

Hi Michele,
I'd say 40 minutes, 45 with Q&A. The video is edited a bit, and I was delivering after a sleepless night, which caused me to be really too fast.
Thanks! I'll tag it as 45 for the review committee's consideration. :)

talk.title: The Advanced Deterministic Random Number Generator (ADRNG) for the Linux Kernel
talk.description:
The Advanced Deterministic Random Number Generator (ADRNG)
======================================================

John F. Masinter, Intel Corporation 
Nathan R. Peterson, Intel Corporation

Summary
--------------

The Advanced Deterministic Random Number Generator (ADRNG) was developed at Intel Security for use with the many security products based upon the McAfee Linux OS platform. The ADRNG provides the NIST approved SP800-90A PRNG from the native Linux kernel API. It is continuously reseeded using high quality entropy bit data form the native Linux kernel Jitter entropy driver. This ADRNG is added to the Linux 4.4 kernel, and replaces the standard drivers for both /dev/random and /dev/urandom. The result is high quality random data delivered in high volume without call blocking.

Problem/Opportunity
-------------------------------

The ability to provide a high volume of quality random data is of interest to modern Linux server systems where a great deal of encryption requires a great deal of random data. A lack of large quantities of random data may cause encryption to run slowly. A lack of quality in the random data may cause encryption to be weak. 

The particular path that led us to develop this solution was increasing scrutiny of the NIST FIPS validation standards which are diving deeper into entropy quality. The ADRNG is based upon all the learning from a year long series of FIPS lab testing while validating McAfee Linux OS. 
Quality random data is in demande by all modern Linux servers, with or without FIPS requirements. By developing a standards based solution that plugs into the Linux kernel, we can easily share this solution with all groups at Intel, as well as making a significant contribution to the Linux kernel upstream.

Solution
-------------

The initial implementation of this idea was for the Linux 3.18 kernel. That kernel did not contain the native API for the SP800-90A PRNG nor the Jitter entropy driver. We back ported the Jitter enropy code from a later kernel, and adapted the SP800-90A routines from the Mozilla Network Security Services (NSS) open source crypto library. This worked very well, but we were concerned about the large delta of kernel code required for this method.

However since that time, we have moved to the Linux 4.4 kernel, which does contains both the SP800-90A PRNG and the Jitter entropy driver within the kernel native API. So we have updated our solution to use only the native kernel resources. This vastly reduces the size of code required, and also provides greater confidence for those that consume the solution.
Scope

The initial motivation to develop the ADRNG was to meet increasingly strict NIST FIPS standards. However we have enable this solution for all modes of the kernel. Thus all products based on McAfee Linux OS will benefit from the faster and higher quality random data. This results in faster and more secure encryption.

McAfee Linux OS is used by many products at Intel Security, and all of these products will implicitly inherit the advantages of the ADRNG as they each update to the lastest MLOS kernel. Increased security will benefit the reputation and sales of Intel Security products.
Engineering teams working with cryptography on Linux systems, as well as Product Managers attempting to satisfy NIST FIPS standards, would all benefit from learning more about the ADRNG.

Results
-----------

For measuring the results we quantify two values: Speed and Quality. 

### Speed Test
+ Dell PE-R610 / Xeon E5540 / 2.53GHz

.            64-Bytes  1K-Bytes  64K-Bytes  64Kx64-Bytes
/dev/random  0m0.002s  0m0.002s  1h,36m,13s 103h,19m,46s
/dev/urandom 0m0.002s  0m0.002s  0m0.008s   2m10.672s
ADRNG        0m0.002s  0m0.003s  0m0.036s   2m25.836s

The speed test was performed using this simple command for each algo and block size:
$ time dd if=/dev/random of=/tmp/64_random.dat bs=64 count=1

We used memory based file system (/tmp/) to reduce file i/o overhead.
We can assume file i/o overhead is consistent between all tests, since all tests have the same number and size of writes.

### Quality Test
•	Dell PE-R610 / Xeon E5540 / 2.53GHz

.             Entropy  Arithmetic-Mean     SCC
/dev/random   7.999580    127.5092         -0.001245
/dev/urandom  7.999960    127.4892         -0.000524
ADRNG         7.999962    127.5570         -0.001057

Entropy bits per byte of perfect randomness = 8.000000
Arithmetic mean of perfect randomness = 127.5
Serial Correlation Coefficient of totally uncorrelated data = 0.0

The quality test was performed using the “ent” program which applies various entropy quality tests to byte sequences. This test was run against the sum of all data produced by the speed test above, 4,260,928 bytes.

Conclusion
----------------

The ADRNG provides random data at the speed of /dev/urandom and with the quality of /dev/random. Thus crypto applications no longer need to choose between speed and quality, because the ADRNG provides both.

Leadership
----------------

The ADRNG will provide greater overall quality to all Intel products which incorporate it. The ISecG security products are measured in the industry by their speed and security. The ability to run encryption faster, and with higher quality, results is something that can be measured and leveredged by product marketing to maintain and extend the Intel Security market leadership.
 
Lessons Learned
There were so many lessons learned from the FIPS process that we could write a book on the subject. But in summary, to track and report quality, you must collect this info:

+ FOR EACH: RNG, RNG-Seed, RNG-init, Entropy, Entropy-Seed, Entropy-init
+ You must be able to show this info:
+ Origin of algo
+ Source code of algo
+ Quality tests of algo
+ Performance tests of algo on various hardware platforms
+ Papers and Certifications of algo

It is far better to collect this info as you go through development, rather than going back at the end and attempting to compile this info.

References
----------------

1.	ENT, a program which applies various entropy quality tests to byte sequences,   http://www.fourmilab.ch/random/
2.	NIST Special Publication 800-90A, Recommendation for Random Number Generation Using Deterministic Random Bit Generators, Jan 2012, http://csrc.nist.gov/publications/nistpubs/800-90A/SP800-90A.pdf
3.	CPU Time Jitter Based Non-Physical True Random Number Generator, 2014, Stephan Müller, https://www.kernel.org/doc/ols/2014/ols2014-mueller.pdf
talk.notes:
- I am the manager and co-founder of the McAfee Linux OS project at Intel Corp. (previously McAfee Inc.)
- I am the originator of the idea and effort at Intel to incorporate a standards based RNG into the Linux kernel.
- I have previously given talks within Intel about this subject.
- This has great benefit, as all products using our kernel will automatically benefit from higher quality random data.
- If selected, I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to reformat my paper for the SATURN desired publishing format. For example, HTML.

ratings.comments: Seems very specialized and likely only relevant to a small contingent of SATURN attendees.
This sounds interesting but I don't think it's the right fit for SATURN.

feedback.body:
Thank you for your submission. 

The Talk Abstract describes in two sentences the ADRNG. However, it does not describe the talk.  :^(

Here's what the conference submission web form says about the talk Description: "The description will be seen by reviewers during the CFP process and will eventually be seen by the attendees of the event. You should make the description of your talk as compelling and exciting as possible. Remember, you're selling both the organizers of the events to select your talk, as well as trying to convince attendees your talk is the one they should see."
I'm afraid your Talk Description does not describe a talk. It describes the ADRNG program, its motivation, technical requirements, compliance requirements, and even test benchmark results. 

Conference participants in general are not interested in a specific software product. But they want to learn from the experience, techniques, patterns, practices, tools and frameworks that were useful in any software project. So, I suggest you turn your talk description around. The focus of the conference is software architecture. Try to put together a talk proposal that covers:
- the design of your product. What design/architecture patterns were used? Any innovative design solutions?
- challenges to create, evaluate, check conformance of the architecture.

The talk description should indicate what attendees will learn from your talk. 

Clarification: there's no paper submission and publication for SATURN. You're submitting a proposal to give a presentation but no paper is required.

Typos in Talk Description: 
- "random data is in demand*e* by"
- "which does contain*s* both the"
- "However*,* we have enable*d* this solution for all modes of the kernel"
- " to the la*s*test MLOS kernel"

talk.title: The benefits of going Serverless
talk.description:
The "Serverless Architecture" has become massively popular this year, and for the right reasons. It’s zero-administration nature and pay-per-execution pricing model enable developers to manage less infrastructure and build more than ever.

So what are developers actually building with it?  What are the obvious use-cases and what use-cases aren't so obvious?  Here, we'll chat about the benefits of the Serverless Architecture and take a tour of the expected and unexpected use-cases these benefits are inspiring. From bitcoin trading platforms to garden monitoring tools to the automation of everything, we’ll explore the potential of serverless, and how empowering it can be for companies and individual developers alike.
talk.abstract: A brief overview of what serverless architecture is with a focus on real case studies of how developers and companies are using it to scale their cloud infrastructure.

talk.title: The Design of Intelligent Software Systems for Diagnosis & Decision Support in Cyber-Physical Systems
talk.description: In this presentation, the author shares the design of Intelligent Software Systems for Diagnosis and Decision Support in Cyber-Physical Systems. As Information Technology (IT) and Information Technology (OT) have been rapidly converging in recent years, new and emerging technologies have been introducing challenging issues to Cyber-Physical Systems, which play critical roles in Critical Infrastructure and Internet of Things (IoT). In addition, the visions of Smart City and Smart Industry demand core Cyber-Physical Systems technologies, including SCADA and M2M, to become more and more Mission-Critical.  To address complexity and uncertainty issues found in Cyber-Physical Systems, the author takes a systematic approach to study key requirements and constraints from Cyber, Physical and Human Factors perspectives, following System and Software Engineering’s principles. A number of key requirements, including availability, resilience, reliability, safety, security, and privacy, along with key constraints, such as dependency, performance, and scalability, are briefly discussed. The author then takes a holistic view to study and present the Cyber-Physical Systems’ Failure Model, which addresses Fault, Error, Failure, and their lifecycles, as well as their Risk Model, which focuses on Mental Model, Hazards and Accidents. The two models are then integrated into an Integrated View, from Cyber, Physical and Human Factor perspectives, to provide a foundation for the design of Intelligent Systems. Several key principles, including redundancy, diversity and human factors design, are applied to design for complexity and uncertainty issues. Two major functions of the designed Intelligent Systems, including Diagnosis and Decision Support, are then introduced. The designed system is then applied at an application scenario in Smart Traffic Management context. The author further discusses and reflects the design experience using model and simulation checking on the application scenario. This is followed by discussions on key lessons learnt, including limitations of the design. The presentation is concluded by introducing future research directions.
talk.notes:
The design experience of Intelligent Software Systems presented in this presentation is based on the author’s Master’s in Software Engineering thesis at Oxford University in UK. With more than a decade’s experience in SCADA and Critical Infrastructure, the author is well prepared to share his professional experience and insight with the audience.  
A high level outline of the proposed presentation is listed below: 
1. Motivations & Objectives
(Discusses the Converging IT / OT Systems and Development of Emerging Technologies)
2. Key Challenges
(The CPS’s operating context is discussed from System of System perspectives)
3. Cyber-Physical Systems
(High level overview of Embedded Systems, Cyber-Physical Systems, Sensors, and Actuators)
4. Feedback & Control Loops 
(Also discusses Human in Loops, and issues in decision making and human errors)
5. SCADA & M2M Systems
6. Technical Architecture
(A brief introduction to SOA, middleware, semantics, Web Services, and cloud)
7. Critical Infrastructure & Internet of Things
8. Smart City & Smart Factory
9. System Analysis for Intelligent Systems 
(Discusses Complexity & Uncertainty issues from Cyber and Physical perspectives. Also discusses Human Factors perspectives)
10. Key Requirements & Constraints
(Issues including Availability, Resilience, Reliability, Security, Privacy, Safety, Dependency, Performance, and Scalability etc. Also briefly introduces relevant metrics)
11. System Failure Model
(Discusses faults, errors, failures states, and the classification and failure lifecycle)
12. System Risk Model
(Discusses modelling issues, mental models, hazards, accident issues)
13. The Integrated View & Situational Awareness
(Discusses integrating Failure and Risk Models into an integrated view. Also introduces Situational Awareness)
14. System Design for Intelligent Systems
(Discusses the design for Complexity and Uncertainty)
15. Design with Redundancy and Diversity
16. Design for Human Factors
17. Overall Design & Prototype of Intelligent Systems
(Demonstrate the high level architecture for the designed Intelligent Systems)
18. Reflections on the Design
19. Future Directions
20. Conclusions
talk.abstract: Technologies of Critical Infrastructure and Internet of Things (IoT) have been changing the world. While it's exciting to imagine a better future, what would happen if the systems fail to work? What can we do to address their complexity and uncertainty issues ? talk.title: The future of delivery messenger channels with SMS-fallback.
talk.description: Probably everyone remembers earlier days, when SMS was one of the most used means of communication. This times, the dissemination of SMS in private communication is decreasing whereas SMS is still often used for commercial communication especially for one-directional distribution of information from company to customer. In the future, the SMS may also lose this position and then will only serve as fallback. New channels, especially internet-based messengers like Facebook Messenger, WhatsApp or Threema, will become more and more important and will compete with SMS. Instead of sending SMS to customers, companies will start using the same channels for commercial conversation as their customers for private. SMS then will only be used in case an internet-based channel is not available or for time critical services.
talk.abstract: Internet-based messengers like Facebook Messenger, Threema and WhatsApp will more and more compete with SMS in one-directional commercial communication. SMS will then only be used as fallback or in case of time critical services.

ratings.comments: Feel this runs at risk of a sales pitch for the author's company, too little information in the submission to judge.

A discussion around performance or availability degradation scenarios is important and interesting. 

As a DEV@ talk, I think this could be interesting.  There could be something longer here, but without more in the abstract I feel it's a bit of a leap of faith.

feedback.body:
Hi Karina,

Thanks for your submission!  Given many of the recent events we've seen with the refugee crisis in Europe I think this is a timely topic for architects to consider.  Not everyone in the world has access to wireless internet and high bandwidth signals all the time.

How much technical detail do you plan to cover in your talk?  What will attendees know or be able to do by the end of your talk?  We have a strong preference at SATURN for talks that explore "how" to do something over "what" something is.

Also, I see that you submitted this talk to the DEV@ track.  I just want to confirm that you know DEV@ talks are a 15 minute time slot on the main stage (200+ people).

Regards,

Michael

Good morning, Michael, once again, 

Yes, you are totally right, we can see a strong increase of customers, who uses SMS services during refugees movements.

As we work very closely with different messenger solutions, their APIs plus also have our own routing system and provide testing and fall back options, I can put lots of technical stuff inside and do it a hands-on technical session for longer than 15 min on how to integrate different solutions together, if you are interested in it. Please let me know which format of this session you would be interested in. 

Regards,
Karina

Summary: 
The talk will shed light on the changing role of SMS in human communications towards a fallback option.

The good and to improve:
The topic is highly current and relevant to the community. I would like to know more about the learnings the audience could take away. What is the idea worth spreading? Why is it relevant for the architecture community.

The proposal does not include a talk outline, and the abstract fails to put its finger on the relevance to development and architecture practice.

Idea:
Please have a look at the proposal writing tips and add a bit more information to enable a more information decision for the reviewers.

talk.title: The Influential Architect: Succeeding At Scale Among Fully Autonomous Teams
talk.description:
Being the only software architect in a company with many fully autonomous and agile development teams can be an exasperating exercise. The role looks simple on paper: drive good, technical solutions to business problems. But with so much going on at any given moment and constant iteration, staying on top of and affecting outcomes across the board is practically impossible. If you can't even keep up, how can you find time to engage in the decision-making process?

In this environment, a 'command-and-control' style architect can encounter significant opposition and find themselves ineffective. Instead, we may consider exploring an entirely different approach. The Influential Architect is fusion of advisor, mentor, facilitator, communicator, and storyteller. As an Influential Architect, our aim is to improve outcomes across the organisation without the organisation becoming reliant on us making key decisions. To achieve this, we have to change the level of abstraction: where previously our purview has been decisions, we must now focus on people. When we can't be in every room where decisions are being made, we must affect the people who are and the process they use.

In this talk, we'll explore what it means to be an Influential Architect, as well as some of the tools and techniques we can use to succeed. We'll cover:

* Transparent Decision-making.
    * How may we efficiently document and communicate our intentions with regards to technical solutions and what would those documents look like?
    * How may we incorporate other development teams into our feedback cycle without creating bottlenecks?
* The Light on the Hill.
    * What is a technical vision and how does it help both the team and the wider organisation?
    * How do we go about establishing a technical vision and who needs to be involved in this process?
    * How do we hold teams accountable to technical visions, in order to ensure they work towards the same long-term goals?
* Visual Storytelling.
    * How can we effectively communicate technical outcomes to non-technical stakeholders?
    * What are the key components of a good story and how does a story help communicate intentions?
    * What does an example of a visual story that communicates a technical initiative look like?
* Architectural Principles.
    * What are architectural principles and why do we need them?
    * How and in what format are architectural principles articulated?
    * What does the process of establishing them look like to optimise for creating buy-in among technical teams?
    * How may we hold teams accountable to the architectural principles we've established?
* Sensible Defaults.
    * How can we use sensible defaults to avoid reinventing the wheel while at the same time not hinder innovation?
    * How do we go about establishing sensible defaults in an open and inclusive process?
    * How do teams incorporate using sensible defaults in their work process?
* Strategic Thinking.
    * How can we champion long-term concerns in an iterative agile process?

In the longer version of the talk, we'll expand on the aforementioned tools by going through them in greater detail with several real-life examples, and also cover:

* A case study of failures.
    * What were the approaches that didn't work so well?
    * Why did they fail and what can we learn from them?
* Team suitability.
    * Are there any _team_ characteristics that are necessary in order for an Influential Architect to be effective?
    * What can we do to prepare teams for greater autonomy if they are not ready for it?
* Architect suitability.
    * Are there any _personal_ characteristics that significantly make this type of role easier to fulfil for the Influential Architect?
* Evaluating outcomes.
    * How do we measure our own success in influencing teams?
    * How do we know which teams need more (or less) support than others?
    * Under what circumstances might it be acceptable to stray from the technical vision?
talk.notes:
This is probably best suited as a 30 minute talk, but can be expanded into a 90 minute talk if so desired. The presentation has no technical requirements other than a projector for the slides.

My presentations tend to be fun and engaging. I strive to offer ideas people can implement as soon as they get back from the conference, interwoven with self-deprecating humour. I gave a talk about Event Sourcing at last year's SATURN which was well received: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_TeMYF_JjNg

Having lived and breathed the role of Influential Architect at Envato in Melbourne, Australia, I'm well-positioned to talk through the lessons I've learned throughout my journey. At Envato, we have 18 autonomous engineering teams working on several products in the digital marketplaces industry. Over 120 people are directly involved in the day-to-day development and delivery of software projects. As the only person with Software Architecture in my job title, I guide these teams and people to ensure that we are making sound technical descision and are all working towards the same technical vision.

The Influence approach we've been trialling at Envato has been very successful, with a transparent decision-making process and better outcomes. For the first time ever, we have a coherent long-term architectural vision that is understood and frequently referenced by both technical and non-technical stakeholders. Teams are able to move faster, with the reassurance of knowing they are heading in the same direction as everyone else.

I'm excited to share what I've learned about the role of a Software Architect at scale. The presentation is packed with advice on what's worked and what hasn't, and has concrete real-world examples rather than abstract ones. There should be interesting content for all types of architects even if they work in very different environments.
talk.abstract: In a company at scale with many fully autonomous and agile development teams, the architect's role is more about preventing entropy than it is setting direction. How can an architect succeed in assuring good technical outcomes through exerting influence rather than command-and-control?
talk.talk_format: Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes - please specify the exact time in the Notes section)

ratings.comments: Great topic, great speaker.  I almost wish this was a DEV@talk instead so everyone could hear it.

This talk addresses the very real problem of having to meet expectations for architecture while having no authority or control over development teams. It may sound like a crazy situation to some, but it hits home with me. It's a great topic. My confidence in the talk is good based on the topics Sebastian proposes to cover. These are spot on.

If Sebastian can provide more detail (for example, an outline), I would like to consider a longer presentation.
Sebastian is a good speaker as can be evidenced by his talk on Event Sourcing from last year. Given that, and the topic in this proposal which I think seems very relevant and interesting, I vote Yes.

feedback.body:
Thank you for your submission. This submission addresses a very real situation that many of us face -- operating through influence, not control, with teams that are not required to listen.

The bulleted list hits on many relevant topics. You've hit on what I'd like to hear about (being in a similar situation). I like the proposed use of real-world examples.

I'd like to see this expanded to a longer talk but would need to have more information to review it as such. The topic presents lots of opportunity to share lessons learned, strategies, tactics, etc. In this regard, an outline would be most helpful, perhaps just adding some detail to the existing bulleted list.

I'm also interested in how you document and communicate the resultant architecture information so that it is used by developers, not forgotten. Do you use models, text documents, process descriptions, etc.? How do you make this information attractive to the development teams? Any explanations on these things are appreciated.

Hi Conrad,

Thanks for your submission.  Overall I like the topic and think this could be a good talk at SATURN.  But I'm going to play devil's advocate in the review.  If accepted, I hope you're able to use the review to help improve the talk.

You assert that "a ‘command-and-control’ style architect is destined to fail" and yet we (the broader community) has managed to ship complex software under situations like this and have for decades.  There must be something other than leadership style at play?

How much does the team culture and experience play into success of the adopted leadership style?  What about the architect's experience?

You discuss only the positive benefits of this style of leadership.  I would think that empowering the team can have a downside if you don't find the right balance of vision and guidance.  How do you determine if your team is doing well with this approach or needs more oversight?

I do not believe all teams are ready for this leadership approach.  How do you know if a team is ready and how do you prepare them to handle greater autonomy?

Regards,

Michael
Sebastian, apologies, I don't usually address people only by their last names -- I was moving too fast and read the wrong text!

Anthony, 

Thank you for your comments. I'm very happy to hear that you think the talk is relevant to your interests! I have amended the submission with some additional information you might find useful. It's not a full outline, per se, but hopefully will give you enough context to understand what I intend to cover.

A longer version of the talk would allow me to go into each area in greater detail, but also cover additional topics. I have listed those in the talk description.

Thanks again for the feedback, and let me know if there is anything I can clarify further!

Michael,

Many thanks for your constructive feedback! I have made some alterations to the description, and I hope to be able to cover as many of the points you raised.

Regarding the "destined to fail" assertion you called out, I will happily concede that was probably erring too far on the side of hyperbole. I've edited that sentence (and the one following it) to use somewhat softer language that I hope more accurately communicates what I actually meant.

Thanks again for your comments, and for taking the time to consider my submission.

talk.title: The Intentional Architect
talk.description:
The title architect has been confusing for IT for years: enterprise architect, solution architect, systems architect, software architect, middleware architect, delivery architect. Whether you have been a "boxes and lines" or a "hands on keyboard" resource, the skills needed to an impactful architect are changing. You must make some intentional changes to keep your skills relevant:
  • Platforms over Projects - The resurgence of modularity as a focus is being fueled by cloud computing paradigm. Architects are often the "urban planner" identifying and stitching together right fit of components/modules and services for the enterprise instead of the monolithic design approach of the past. The result is a focus on design of platforms and frameworks that can absorb organic change in business needs over time.
  • Patterns and Pragmatism - Patterns have been around for over two decades and the rise of the API economy and platform focused design is shining a spot light on identifying the right fit patterns. Patterns are provided to the Developers and Designers freeing them to focus on building business features. The challenge is to avoid ivory-tower syndrome pragmatically apply patterns that will make them most impact and reduce risk.
  • Master Craftsman and Apprentice - The architect has a responsibility to mentor other techs. With the pace of change, the architect has to be open to being the apprentice as new ideas and techniques surface through the curious developers and passionate designers.
  • Master Communicator - Whether an junior architect in training in training or a well-seasoned senior arch, the ability to communicate crisply and succinctly is an imperative whether written or spoken.
talk.notes: I've been an architect for over 22 years and have continually reinvented and retooled myself.  I am seeing many mid-career and late-career architects struggle as they look through their old lens.  Especially for the enterprise, there needs to be a mind set shift away from monolithic solutions and toward modular platforms.  See bio for additional background.  This is a 30 minute session and participants will leave with a clear understanding of the imperative and a set of personal career guiding principles to keep them relevant and enable them as intentional architects.
talk.abstract: What does it take to be a software architect nowadays?  It means being an intentional focus on becoming a polymath who designs platforms and frameworks instead of projects, a focus on patterns and mastering the art of planning for organic growth.  This is the next evolution for our profession.

ratings.comments: This abstract is very confusing and the message is not clear. I am not sure if the author is advocating patterns or against it? Not all projects can be platform architectures? What is the context that these lessons apply in?

Highly relevant topic, promising session title. So I had high expectations when opening the submission description. 

Regrettably, the submission fails to convince me that the submitter will be able to deliver a convincing presentation:  the abstract is almost content.free, and the talk description is loaded with buzzwords, but does not contain concrete examples of what the "Intentional Architect" would be and do.

talk.title: The life and times of an architecture - Architectural decision making throughout the solution life cycle
talk.description:
Over the last decade, the architecture discipline has matured from up-front design to a stream of architectural decisions that address the concerns related to ever-evolving software systems. The word “stream” implies a continuous process, but in real life that stream is far from homogeneous. Architects (or whoever else owns the design decisions) find themselves making decisions with widely varying impact, based on information with differing levels of uncertainty, throughout the life of a software solution. On top of that, the way these decisions and their impact are communicated evolves as the audience and the focus of the architectural communication change.

In this tutorial, we explore the metaphor of a human lifetime to illustrate various aspects of architectural decision making, throughout a software solution’s life cycle. Amid all the fluidity of the stream of design decisions, we will look for anchor points with common concerns to address and recurring communication needs. We will see how the nature of architectural decisions changes when we go from birth (the first architectural outline) to graduation (making the business case), and find guidance on communicating the architecture at times of life-defining milestones like marriage (committing to the architecture) and revolutionary changes to the solution. The points will be illustrated by real-life examples from an interesting case study.

The tutorial is based on Risk- and Cost-Driven Architecture, a popular approach to improve architecture practices in both traditional and agile contexts, with the aim of providing “just enough anticipation” in the architecture. No prior knowledge of RCDA is required to attend.
talk.notes:
This is a 90-minute tutorial.

During the product lifecycle, key aspects of architectural decisions change, depending on the life stage:

* level of risk and cost control: the cone of uncertainty
* available information to base architectural decisions on
* impact of architectural decisions
* number of architectural decisions
* cost of change to the architecture

Certain milestones like graduation (approving the business case for the solution) and marriage (the moment after which it becomes very expensive to change the architecture) occur in every solution life cycle. Such milesones lead to standard stakeholder concerns, like affordability, level of risk control and predictability. We use the commonality of these concerns to provide the architect with standard views in their documentation, enabling them to show how the architecture addresses these common concerns.

Contents
-----------

1. Introduction: 
 * Architecture as a stream of design decisions
 * Cone of uncertainty
 * Project vs. product life cycle
2. Birth:
 * From stakeholder need to solution concept
3. Graduation:
 * Making the business case
4. Marriage:
 * Committing to the architecture
5. Career and home life:
 * Fulfilling the architecture
 * Emergent architecture
 * Evolutionary changes
 * Health and debt control
6. Children:
 * Revolutionary changes
7. Legacy
talk.abstract: Explore the metaphor of a human lifetime to illustrate various aspects of architectural decision making throughout a software system's life cycle. Find guidance on communicating your architecture at birth, graduation and marriage, after which changing the architecture becomes very expensive...

ratings.comments: Looks like a highly relevant talk to me. I am not an expert, and I have not studied RCDA myself, but I think the questions it raises are at the core of architecture, even though its always a danger that it all become too academic to be practical useful.

This looks to be an interesting topic under the theme of applying techniques and patterns.  

I am new to RCDA and the approach of viewing the subject across the lifetime of the product promises to provide an engaging introduction.

Eltjo always gives a great, informative, engaging presentation but we've seen RCDA topics for going on 4 years or more.  I would be more enthused if someone other than Eltjo were talking about their experiences with it.  Is RCDA gaining traction?

This is a weak "maybe", mostly because I'm holding out for something completely new.  That being said, Eltjo and this talk would likely be a great addition to the program.

Update: Based on Eltjo's additional comments, this seems different enough from past talks that I think it would be good to have in the program.

feedback.body:
Hi Eltjo,

I have read you submission with interest.  The topic is interesting and your rhetorical use of metaphor looks to make it a memorable talk.

Can I ask how much prior knowledge the audience needs to have regarding RCDA?  I see that you delivered a talk on this topic at SATURN 2013, which included four key principles and a set of practices.

In your outline I do not see any direct reference to any of these.  Are you assuming that the audience is already familiar with them or will you be weaving them into your narrative across the whole talk?

Regards, 


Ged

Hi Ged, no prior knowledge of RCDA is required. The RCDA principles and practices that I use (like the "Architecture as a stream of design decisions" principle and the "Architectural Decision Making" practice) will be explained as needed in the tutorial. I will clarify this in the description.

Hi Eltjo,

I agree with Ged, this looks great.  Knowing that you've presented on these topics before, what's new or different in this talk that we haven't seen before?  It appears that this is similar material presented in a completely new way from previous talks on this topic.  Is that a fair characterization?   Is there more to it than that?

Regards,

Michael

Michael, I'd say that is a pretty fair characterization.  There's new material about how these practices change over the lifetime of the architecture. The life stage especially impacts decision making and documentation practices, and the tutorial teaches architects to recognize this and act accordingly.

Thanks, Eltjo!  It sounds like this is more related to application of the method rather than the method itself (other than covering necessary background).  To me this is a minor but important distinction.  Thanks for the extra information!
